[He]114-mr. woodstock rose and stood with [his]114-mr. woodstock hands behind [him]114-mr. woodstock , watching [her]101-ida . [Ida]101-ida made what haste [she]101-ida could to the door , and sped out into [the street]340-the street .

CHAPTER III

ANTECEDENTS

It would not have been easy to find another instance of a union of keen intellect and cold heart so singular as that displayed in the character of [Abraham Woodstock]490-abraham woodstock . [The man]491-the man s life had been strongly consistent from the beginning ; from boyhood a powerful will had borne [him]491-the man triumphantly over every difficulty , and in each decisive instance [his]491-the man will had been directed by a shrewd intelligence which knew at once the strength of its own resources and the multiplied weaknesses of [the vast majority of men]492-the vast majority of men . In the pursuit of [his]491-the man ends [he]491-the man would tolerate no obstacle which [his]491-the man strength would suffice to remove . In boyhood and early manhood the exuberance of [his]491-the man physical power was wo nt to manifest itself in brutal self - assertion . At [school]306-school [he]491-the man was [the worst kind of bully]494-the worst kind of bully , [his]491-the man ferociousness tempered by no cowardice . Later on , [he]491-the man learned that a too demonstrative bearing would on many occasions interfere with [his]491-the man success in life ; [he]491-the man toned down [his]491-the man love of muscular victory , and only allowed [himself]491-the man an outbreak every now and then , when [he]491-the man felt [he]491-the man could afford the indulgence . Put early into [[an accountant]468-an accountant 's office]496-an accountant 's office , and losing [[his]491-the man father]497-his father about the same time [the parent]498-the parent , who had a diseased heart , was killed by an outburst of fury to which [Abraham]115-abraham gave way on some trivial occasion , [he]491-the man had henceforth to fight [his]491-the man own battle , and showed [himself]491-the man very capable of winning it . In many strange ways [he]491-the man accumulated a little capital , and the development of commercial genius put [him]491-the man at a comparatively early age on the road to fortune . [He]491-the man kept to the business of [an accountant]468-an accountant , and by degrees added several other distinct callings . [He]491-the man became [a lender of money]500-a lender of money in several shapes , keeping both [a loan - office]501-a loan - office and [[a pawnbroker]502-a pawnbroker 's shop]503-a pawnbroker 's shop . In middle age [he]491-the man frequented the race - course , but , for sufficient reasons , dropped that pursuit entirely before [he]491-the man had turned [his]491-the man fiftieth year . As [a youth]504-a youth [he]491-the man had made a good thing of games of skill , but did not pursue them as a means of profit when [he]491-the man no longer needed the resource .

[He]491-the man married at the age of thirty . This , like every other step [he]491-the man took , was well planned ; [[his]491-the man wife]505-his wife brought [him]491-the man several thousand pounds , being [the daughter of [a retired publican with whom [Woodstock]115-abraham had had business relations]507-a retired publican with whom woodstock had had business relations]506-the daughter of a retired publican with whom woodstock had had business relations .

Two years after [his]491-the man marriage was born [[his]491-the man first and only child]508-his first and only child , [a girl whom [they]510-they called [Lotty]110-lotty]509-a girl whom they called lotty . [Lotty]110-lotty , as [she]110-lotty grew up , gradually developed an unfortunate combination of [[her]110-lotty parents]511-her parents ' qualities ; [she]110-lotty had [[her]110-lotty mother]377-her mother 's weakness of mind , without [[her]110-lotty mother]377-her mother 's moral sense , and from [[her]110-lotty father]514-her father [she]110-lotty derived an ingrained stubbornness , which had nothing in common with strength of character . Doubly unhappy was it that [she]110-lotty lost [[her]110-lotty mother]377-her mother so early ; the loss deprived [her]110-lotty of gentle guidance during [her]110-lotty youth , and left [her]110-lotty without resource against [[her]110-lotty father]514-her father 's coldness or harshness . The result was that the softer elements of [her]110-lotty character unavoidably degenerated and found expression in qualities not at all admirable , whilst [her]110-lotty obstinacy grew the ally of the weakness from which [she]110-lotty had most to fear .

[Lotty]110-lotty was sent to [a day - school]517-a day - school till the age of thirteen , then had to become [[[her]110-lotty father]514-her father 's housekeeper]519-her father 's housekeeper . [[Her]110-lotty friends]520-her friends were very few , none of [them]520-her friends likely to be of use to [her]110-lotty . Left very much to [her]110-lotty own control , [she]110-lotty made an acquaintance which led to secret intimacy and open disaster . Rather than face [[her]110-lotty father]514-her father with such a disclosure , [she]110-lotty left [home]3157-home , and threw [herself]110-lotty upon the mercy of [the man who had assisted [her]110-lotty to go astray]523-the man who had assisted her to go astray . [He]523-the man who had assisted her to go astray was generous enough to support [her]110-lotty for about a year , during which time [[her]110-lotty child]524-her child was born . Then [his]523-the man who had assisted her to go astray help ceased .

The familiar choice lay before [[her]110-lotty home]379-her home again , [the streets]3169-the streets , or starvation . Hardship [she]110-lotty could not bear ; the second alternative [she]110-lotty shrank from on account of [[her]110-lotty child]524-her child ; [she]110-lotty determined to face [[her]110-lotty father]514-her father . For [him]514-her father [she]110-lotty had no affection , and knew that [he]514-her father did not love [her]110-lotty ; only desperation could drive [her]110-lotty back . [She]110-lotty came one Sunday evening , found [Mr. Woodstock]114-mr. woodstock at [home]3157-home , and , without letting [the servant]289-the servant say who was come , went up and entered [his]514-her father presence , [the child]320-the child in [her]110-lotty arms . [Abraham]115-abraham rose and looked at [her]110-lotty calmly . [Her]110-lotty disappearance had not troubled [him]514-her father , though [he]514-her father had exerted [himself]514-her father to discover why and whither [she]110-lotty was gone , and [her]110-lotty return did not visibly affect [him]514-her father . [She]110-lotty was [a rebel against [his]514-her father authority]532-a rebel against his authority so [he]514-her father viewed the matter and consequently quite beyond the range of [his]514-her father sympathies . [He]514-her father listened to all [she]110-lotty had to say , beheld unmoved [her]110-lotty miserable tears , and , when [she]110-lotty became silent , coolly delivered [his]514-her father ultimatum . For [her]110-lotty [he]514-her father would procure a situation , whereby [she]110-lotty could earn [her]110-lotty living , and therewith [his]514-her father relations to [her]110-lotty would end ; [the child]320-the child [he]514-her father would put into other hands and have it cared for , but [Lotty]110-lotty would lose sight of it for ever . [The girl]316-the girl hesitated , but the maternal instinct was very strong in [her]316-the girl ; [the little one]535-the little one began to cry , as if fearing separation from [[its]535-the little one mother]536-its mother ; [she]316-the girl decided to refuse .

" Then [I]316-the girl shall go on [the streets]3169-the streets ! "[316-the girl] [she]316-the girl exclaimed passionately . " There 's nothing else left for [me]316-the girl . "[316-the girl]

" [You]316-the girl can go where [you]316-the girl please , "[115-abraham] returned [Abraham]115-abraham .

[She]316-the girl tried to obtain work , of course fruitlessly . [She]316-the girl got into debt with [[her]316-the girl landlady]537-her landlady , and only took the fatal step when at length absolutely turned adrift .

That was not quite ten years gone by ; [she]316-the girl was then but eighteen . Let [her]316-the girl have lost [[her]316-the girl child]524-her child , and [she]316-the girl would speedily have fallen into the last stages of degradation . But [the little one]535-the little one lived . [She]316-the girl had called it [Ida]101-ida , a name chosen from some tale in the penny weeklies , which were the solace of [her]316-the girl misery . [She]316-the girl [herself]316-the girl took the name of [Starr]101-ida , also from a page of fiction .

Balancing the good and evil of this life in [her]316-the girl dark little mind , [Lotty]110-lotty determined that one thing there was for which it was worth while to make sacrifices , one end which [she]316-the girl felt strong enough to keep persistently in view . [Ida]101-ida should be brought up " respectably "[101-ida] it was [her]101-ida own word ; [she]101-ida should be kept absolutely free from the contamination of [[her]101-ida mother]377-her mother 's way of living ; nay , should , when the time came , go to [school]306-school , and have good chances . And at the end of all this was a far - off hope , a dim vision of possibilities , a vague trust that [[her]316-the girl daughter]542-her daughter might perchance prove for [her]101-ida a means of returning to that world of " respectability "[316-the girl] from which [she]101-ida was at present so hopelessly shut out . [She]316-the girl would keep making efforts to get into an honest livelihood as often as an occasion presented itself ; and [Ida]101-ida should always live with " [respectable "[316-the girl] people]3265-respectable " people , cost what it might .

The last resolution was only adhered to for a few months . [Lotty]110-lotty could not do without [[her]316-the girl little one]543-her little one , and eventually brought [it]543-her little one back to [[her]316-the girl own home]544-her own home . It is not an infrequent thing to find [little children]545-little children living in [disorderly houses]546-disorderly houses . In the profession [Lotty]110-lotty had chosen there are , as in all professions , grades and differences . [She]110-lotty was by no means [a vicious girl]547-a vicious girl , [she]110-lotty had no love of riot for its own sake ; [she]110-lotty would greatly have preferred a decent mode of life , had it seemed practicable . Hence [she]110-lotty did not associate [herself]110-lotty with the rank and file of [abandoned women]548-abandoned women ; [[her]110-lotty resorts]549-her resorts were not [the crowded centres]550-the crowded centres ; [[her]110-lotty abode]551-her abode was not in [the quarters consecrated to [her]110-lotty business]552-the quarters consecrated to her business . In [all parts of [London]3-london]553-all parts of london there are quiet by - streets of [houses given up to lodging - letting]554-houses given up to lodging - letting , wherein are to be found [many landladies]555-many landladies , who , [good easy souls]556-good easy souls , trouble little about the private morals of [[their]555-many landladies lodgers]557-their lodgers , so long as no positive disorder comes about and no public scandal is occasioned . [A girl who says that [she]558-a girl who says that she is occupied in a workroom is occupied in [a workroom]559-a workroom]558-a girl who says that she is occupied in a workroom is never presumed to be able to afford the luxury of strict virtue , and if [such a one]560-such a one , on taking [a room]561-a room , says that ' [she]558-a girl who says that she is occupied in a workroom supposes [she]558-a girl who says that she is occupied in a workroom may have [friends]562-friends come to see [her]558-a girl who says that she is occupied in a workroom ? " [the landlady]386-the landlady will understand quite well what is meant , and will either accept or refuse [her]558-a girl who says that she is occupied in a workroom for [a lodger]3267-a lodger as [she]558-a girl who says that she is occupied in a workroom sees good . To [such houses as these [Lotty]110-lotty]3268-such houses as these lotty confined [herself]110-lotty . After some three or four years of various experiences , [she]110-lotty hit upon [the abode in [Milton Street]6-milton street]3269-the abode in milton street , and there had dwelt ever since . [She]110-lotty got on well with [Mrs. Ledward]108-mrs. ledward , and had been able to make comfortable arrangements for [Ida]101-ida . [The other lodgers in [the house]288-the house]3270-the other lodgers in the house were generally very quiet and [orderly people]3272-orderly people , and [she]110-lotty [herself]110-lotty was quite successful in arranging [her]110-lotty affairs so as to create no disturbance . [She]110-lotty had [[her]110-lotty regular clientele]3273-her regular clientele ; [she]110-lotty frequented [the roads about [Regent 's Park]5-regent 's park and [Primrose Hill]11-primrose hill]3274-the roads about regent 's park and primrose hill ; and [she]110-lotty supported [herself]110-lotty and [[her]110-lotty child]524-her child .[562-friends]

[Ida Starr]101-ida 's bringing up was in no respect inferior to that [she]101-ida would have received in [the home of [the average [London]3-london artisan or [small tradesman]565-small tradesman]564-the average london artisan or small tradesman]563-the home of the average london artisan or small tradesman . At five years old [she]101-ida had begun to go to [school]306-school ; [[Mrs. Ledward]108-mrs. ledward 's daughter]567-mrs. ledward 's daughter , [a girl of seventeen]568-a girl of seventeen , took [her]101-ida backwards and forwards every day . At [this school]298-this school [she]101-ida remained three years and a half ; then [[her]101-ida mother]377-her mother took [her]101-ida away , and put [her]101-ida under the care of [Miss Rutherford]98-miss rutherford , [a better teacher]571-a better teacher . When at [home]3157-home , [she]101-ida either amused [herself]101-ida in [[Lotty]110-lotty 's room]573-lotty 's room , or , when that was engaged , made [herself]101-ida comfortable with [[Mrs. Ledward]108-mrs. ledward 's family]574-mrs. ledward 's family , with [one or other of whom [she]101-ida generally passed the night]575-one or other of whom she generally passed the night . [She]101-ida heard no bad language , saw nothing improper , listened to no worse conversation than [any of [the other children at [Miss Rutherford]98-miss rutherford 's]577-the other children at miss rutherford 's]576-any of the other children at miss rutherford 's . Even at [her]101-ida present age of ten it never occurred to [her]101-ida to inquire how [[her]101-ida mother]377-her mother supported [herself]377-her mother . The charges brought by [Harriet Smales]99-harriet conveyed to [her]101-ida mind no conception of their true meaning ; they were to [her]101-ida mere general calumnies of vague application . [[Her]101-ida mother]377-her mother " bad , "[377-her mother] indeed ! If so , then what was the meaning of goodness ? For poor [Lotty]110-lotty 's devotion to [the child]320-the child had received its due reward herein , that [she]101-ida was loved as purely and intensely as [any most virtuous parent]581-any most virtuous parent could hope to be ; so little regard has nature for social codes , so utterly is [she]101-ida often opposed to all the precepts of respectability . This phrase of [Harriet]99-harriet 's was the very first breathing against [[her]101-ida mother]377-her mother 's character that [Ida]101-ida had ever heard . [Lotty]110-lotty had invented fables , for [the child]320-the child 's amusement , about [her]110-lotty own earlier days . The legend was , that [[her]110-lotty husband]584-her husband had died about a year after marriage . Of course [Ida]101-ida implicitly believed all this . [Her]101-ida mind contained pictures of [a beautiful little house]585-a beautiful little house [just outside [London]3-london in which [[her]101-ida mother]377-her mother had once lived , and [her]101-ida imagination busied itself with the time when [they]588-they would both live in just that same way]586-just outside london in which her mother had once lived , and her imagination busied itself with the time when they would both live in just that same way . [She]101-ida was going to be [a teacher]589-a teacher , so it had been decided in confidential chats , and would one day have [a school of [her]101-ida own]590-a school of her own . In such a future [Lotty]110-lotty [herself]110-lotty really believed . [The child]320-the child seemed to [her]110-lotty extraordinarily clover , and in four more years [she]320-the child would be as old as [a girl who had assisted with the little ones in [the first school [she]320-the child went to]593-the first school she went to]592-a girl who had assisted with the little ones in the first school she went to . [Lotty]110-lotty was ambitious . [Offers of Mrs. Ledward]108-mrs. ledward to teach [Ida]101-ida dressmaking , [she]377-her mother had put aside ; it was not good enough .

Yet [Ida]101-ida was not in reality remarkable either for industry or quickness in learning . At both schools [she]101-ida had frequently to be dealt with somewhat severely . Ability [she]101-ida showed from time to time , but in application [she]101-ida was sadly lacking . Books were distasteful to [her]101-ida , more even than to [most children]594-most children ; [she]101-ida learned sometimes by listening to [the teacher]325-the teacher , but seldom the lessons given [her]101-ida to prepare . At [home]3157-home there were no books to tempt [her]101-ida to read for [herself]101-ida ; [[her]101-ida mother]377-her mother never read , and would not have known how to set about giving [[her]377-her mother child]524-her child a love for such occupation , even had [she]377-her mother deemed it needful . And yet [Ida]101-ida always seemed to have abundance to think about ; [she]101-ida would sit by [herself]101-ida for hours , without any childlike employment , and still not seem weary . When asked what [her]101-ida thoughts ran upon , [she]101-ida could not give very satisfactory answers ; [she]101-ida was always rather slow in expressing [herself]101-ida , and never chattered , even to [[her]101-ida mother]377-her mother . One queer and most unchildlike habit [she]101-ida had , which , as if thinking it wrong , [she]101-ida only indulged when quite alone ; [she]101-ida loved to sit before a looking - glass and gaze into [her]101-ida own face . At such times [her]101-ida little countenance became very sad without any understood reason .

The past summer had been to [her]101-ida a time of happiness , for there had come comparatively little bad weather , and sunshine was like wine to [Ida]101-ida . The proximity of [the park]600-the park was a great advantage . During the weeks of summer holiday , [she]101-ida spent whole days wandering about [the large , grassy tracts]601-the large , grassy tracts by [herself]101-ida , rejoicing in the sensation of freedom from task - work . If [she]101-ida were especially in luck , a dog would come and play about [her]101-ida , deserting for a minute [[its]602-its lawful master]603-its lawful master or [mistress]604-mistress , and [the child]320-the child would roll upon the grass in delighted sport . Or [she]101-ida would find out a warm , shady nook quite near to [the borders of [the Zoological Gardens]607-the zoological gardens]606-the borders of the zoological gardens , and would lie there with ear eager to catch the occasional sounds from the animals within . The roar of the lion thrilled [her]101-ida with an exquisite trembling ; the calls of the birds made [her]101-ida laugh with joy . Once , three years ago , [[her]101-ida mother]377-her mother had taken [her]101-ida to [Hastings]12-hastings for a week , and when [she]101-ida now caught the cry of the captive sea - gulls , it brought back marvellous memories of [the ocean]609-the ocean flashing in the sun , of the music of breakers , of the fresh smell of the brine .

Now there had come upon [her]101-ida the first great grief . [She]101-ida had caused [[her]101-ida mother]377-her mother bitter suffering , and [her]101-ida own heart was filled with a commensurate pain . Had [she]101-ida been a little older [she]101-ida would already have been troubled by another anxiety ; for the last two years [[her]101-ida mother]377-her mother 's health had been falling away ; every now and then had come a fit of illness , and at other times [Lotty]110-lotty suffered from a depression of spirits which left [her]110-lotty no energy to move about . [Ida]101-ida knew that [[her]101-ida mother]377-her mother was often unhappy , but naturally could not dwell long on this as soon as each successive occasion had passed away . Indeed , in [her]101-ida heart , [she]101-ida almost welcomed such times , since [she]101-ida was then allowed to sleep [upstairs]434-upstairs , one of [her]101-ida greatest joys . [Lotty]110-lotty was only too well aware of the physical weakness which was gaining upon [her]110-lotty . [She]110-lotty was mentally troubled , moreover . [Ida]101-ida was growing up ; there would come a time , and that very shortly , when it would be necessary either for [them]614-them to part , or else for [herself]101-ida to change [her]101-ida mode of life . Indeed , [she]101-ida had never from the first quite lost sight of [her]101-ida intention to seek for an honest means of support ; and of late years the consciousness of [her]101-ida hopeless position had grown to an ever - recurring trouble . [She]101-ida knew the proposed step was in reality impossible to [her]101-ida , yet [she]101-ida persistently thought and talked of it . To [Mrs. Ledward]108-mrs. ledward [she]101-ida confided at least once a week , generally when [she]101-ida paid [her]101-ida rent , [her]101-ida settled intention to go and find work of some kind in the course of the next two or three days ; till at length this had become a standing joke with [the landlady , who laughed merrily as often as the subject]615-the landlady , who laughed merrily as often as the subject was mentioned . [Lotty]110-lotty had of late let [her]110-lotty thoughts turn to [[her]110-lotty father , whom [she]110-lotty had never seen since [their]614-them parting]616-her father , whom she had never seen since their parting . Not with any affection did [she]110-lotty think of [him]616-her father , whom she had never seen since their parting , but , in [her]110-lotty despairing moments , it seemed to [her]110-lotty impossible that [he]616-her father , whom she had never seen since their parting should still refuse aid if [she]110-lotty appealed to [him]616-her father , whom she had never seen since their parting for it . Several times of late [she]110-lotty had been on the point of putting [her]110-lotty conviction to the test . [She]110-lotty had passed [[his]616-her father , whom she had never seen since their parting house]617-his house from time to time , and knew that [he]616-her father , whom she had never seen since their parting still lived [there]3249-there . Perhaps the real reason of [her]110-lotty hesitation was , not fear of [him]616-her father , whom she had never seen since their parting , but a dread , which [she]110-lotty would not confess to [herself]110-lotty , lest [he]616-her father , whom she had never seen since their parting should indeed prove obdurate , and so put an end to [her]110-lotty last hope . For what would become of [her]110-lotty and of [Ida]101-ida if [her]110-lotty health absolutely failed ? [The poor creature]619-the poor creature shrank from the thought in horror . The hope connected with [[her]110-lotty father]514-her father grew more and more strong . But it needed some very decided crisis to bring [her]110-lotty to the point of overcoming all the apprehensions which lay in the way of an appeal to [the stern old man]621-the stern old man This crisis had arrived . The illness which was now upon [her]110-lotty [she]110-lotty felt to be more serious than any [she]110-lotty had yet suffered . Suppose [she]110-lotty were to die , and [Ida]101-ida to be left alone in [the world]622-the world Even before [she]110-lotty heard of [the child]320-the child 's dismissal from [school]306-school [she]110-lotty had all but made up [her]110-lotty mind to write to [[her]110-lotty father]514-her father , and the shock of that event gave [her]110-lotty the last impulse . [She]110-lotty wrote a letter of pitiful entreaty . Would [he]514-her father help [her]110-lotty to some means of earning a living for [herself]110-lotty and [[her]110-lotty child]524-her child ? [She]110-lotty could not part from [Ida]101-ida . Perhaps [she]110-lotty had not long to live , and to ask [her]110-lotty to give up [[her]110-lotty child]524-her child would be too cruel . [She]110-lotty would do anything , would go into service , perform the hardest and coarsest toil . [She]110-lotty told [him]514-her father how [Ida]101-ida had been brought up , and implored [his]514-her father pity for [the child , who at all events]628-the child , who at all events was innocent .

When [Ida]101-ida reached [home]3157-home from [her]101-ida visit to [the City]463-the city , [she]101-ida saw [[her]101-ida mother]377-her mother risen and sitting by the fire . [Lotty]110-lotty had found the suspense insupportable as [she]377-her mother lay still , and , though the pains in [her]377-her mother chest grew worse and the feeling of lassitude was gaining upon [her]377-her mother , [she]377-her mother had half - dressed , and even tried to move about . Just before [the child]320-the child 's appearance , [she]377-her mother seemed to have sunk into something of a doze on [her]377-her mother chair , for , as the door opened , [she]377-her mother started and looked about [her]377-her mother in doubt .

" Where have [you]320-the child been so long ? "[377-her mother] [she]377-her mother asked impatiently .

" [I]101-ida got back as quickly as [I]101-ida could , [mother]375-mother , "[101-ida] said [Ida]101-ida , in some surprise .

" Got back ? Is [school]306-school over ? "[101-ida]

" From [the the place [you]110-lotty sent [me]377-her mother to]3278-the the place you sent me to , [mother]375-mother . "[377-her mother]

" What am [I]110-lotty thinking of ! "[110-lotty] exclaimed [Lotty]110-lotty , starting to consciousness . " Come here , and tell [me]110-lotty . Did [you]320-the child see see [him]320-the child , [Ida]101-ida ? [Mr. Woodstock]114-mr. woodstock , [you]320-the child know . "[110-lotty]

" Yes , [mother]375-mother , "[320-the child] began [the child]320-the child , with pale face , " and [he]320-the child [he]320-the child said [I]320-the child was to tell [you]375-mother "[320-the child]

[She]101-ida burst into tears , and flew to [[her]101-ida mother]377-her mother 's neck .

" Oh , [you]375-mother wo n't send [me]110-lotty away from [you]320-the child , [mother dear]3213-mother dear ? [I]110-lotty ca n't go away from [you]320-the child ! "[110-lotty]

[Lotty]110-lotty felt [she]110-lotty knew what this meant . Fear and trouble wrought with [her]110-lotty physical weakness to drive [her]110-lotty almost distracted . [She]110-lotty sprang up , caught [the child]320-the child by the shoulders , and shook [her]320-the child as if in anger .

" Tell [me]110-lotty , ca n't [you]320-the child ? "[110-lotty] [she]110-lotty cried , straining [her]110-lotty weak voice . " What did [he]3282-he say ? Do n't be [a little fool]3283-a little fool ! Ca n't [the child]320-the child speak ? "[110-lotty]

[She]110-lotty fell back again , seized with a cough which choked [her]110-lotty . [Ida]101-ida stayed [her]110-lotty sobbing , and looked on in terror . [[Her]101-ida mother]377-her mother motioned constantly to [her]101-ida to proceed .

" [The gentleman]3285-the gentleman said , "[101-ida] [Ida]101-ida continued , with calm which was the result of extreme self - control , " that [he]3282-he would take [me]101-ida ; but that [you]320-the child were never to see [me]101-ida again . "[101-ida]

" Did [he]3282-he say anything else about [me]110-lotty ? "[110-lotty] whispered [Lotty]110-lotty .

" No , nothing else . "[101-ida]

" Go go and tell [him]3282-he [you]320-the child 'll come , [you]320-the child 'll leave [me]101-ida . "[101-ida]

[Ida]101-ida stood in anguish , speechless and motionless . All at once [[her]101-ida mother]377-her mother seemed to forget what [she]377-her mother was saying , and sat still , staring into the fire . Several times [she]377-her mother shivered . [Her]377-her mother hands lay listlessly on [her]377-her mother lap ; [she]377-her mother breathed with difficulty .

Shortly afterwards , [the landlady]386-the landlady came into [the room]255-the room . [She]386-the landlady was alarmed at [Lotty]110-lotty 's condition . [Her]386-the landlady attempts to arouse [the sick woman]455-the sick woman to consciousness were only partly successful . [She]386-the landlady went [downstairs]445-downstairs again , and returned with [another woman]642-another woman , [a lodger in [the house]288-the house]643-a lodger in the house . [These two]645-these two talked together in low tones . The result of [their]645-these two colloquy was that [Mrs. Ledward]108-mrs. ledward dressed [Lotty]110-lotty as well as [she]108-mrs. ledward could , whilst [the other]449-the other left [the house]288-the house and returned with [a cab]648-a cab .

" [We]645-these two 're going to take [[your]320-the child mother]3184-your mother to [the hospital]3287-the hospital , "[108-mrs. ledward] said [Mrs. Ledward]108-mrs. ledward to [the child]320-the child . " [You]320-the child wait here till [we]645-these two come back , there 's [a good girl]3179-a good girl . Now , hold up a bit , [Lotty]110-lotty ; try and walk [downstairs]445-downstairs . That 's better , [[my]108-mrs. ledward girl]3290-my girl . "[108-mrs. ledward]

[Ida]101-ida was left alone .

CHAPTER IV

CHRISTMAS IN [TWO HOMES]650-two homes

When [Ida Starr]101-ida was dismissed from [school]306-school [it]652-it wanted but a few days to the vacations . The day which followed [[her]101-ida mother]377-her mother 's removal to [the hospital]3287-the hospital was Christmas Eve . For two hours on the afternoon of Christmas Day , [Ida]101-ida sat in silence by the bedside in [the ward]655-the ward , holding [[her]101-ida mother]377-her mother 's hand . [The patient]657-the patient was not allowed to speak , seemed indeed unable to do so . [The child]320-the child might not even kiss [her]657-the patient . [The Sister]659-the sister and [the nurse]660-the nurse looked pityingly at [Ida]101-ida when [they]661-they passed by , and , when [the visitors]662-the visitors ' time was at an end , and [she]101-ida had to rise and go , [the Sister]659-the sister put an orange into [her]101-ida hand , and spoke a few hopeful words .

Night was setting in as [she]101-ida walked homewards ; it was cold , and the sky threatened snow . [She]101-ida had only gone a few yards , when there came by [a little girl of [her]664-a little girl of her own age own age]664-a little girl of her own age , walking with [some one who looked like [a nurse - maid]666-a nurse - maid]665-some one who looked like a nurse - maid . [They]667-they were passing ; but all at once [the child]320-the child sprang to [Ida]101-ida 's side with a cry of recognition . It was [little Maud Enderby]103-maud .

" Where have [you]101-ida been , [Ida]101-ida ? Where are [you]101-ida going ? Oh , [I]103-maud 'm so glad ; [I]103-maud wanted so to see [you]101-ida . [Miss Rutherford]98-miss rutherford told [us]667-they [you]101-ida 'd left [school]306-school , and [you]101-ida were n't coming back again . Are n't [you]101-ida really ? And sha'n't [I]103-maud see [you]101-ida ? "[103-maud]

" [I]101-ida do n't know , [I]101-ida think not , "[101-ida] said [Ida]101-ida . In [her]101-ida premature trouble [she]101-ida seemed so much older than [[her]101-ida friend]669-her friend .

" [I]103-maud told [Miss Rutherford]98-miss rutherford [you]101-ida were n't to blame , "[103-maud] went on [Maud]103-maud eagerly . " [I]103-maud told [her]98-miss rutherford it was [Harriet]99-harriet 's own fault , and how shockingly [she]98-miss rutherford 'd behaved to [you]101-ida . [I]103-maud expect [you]101-ida 'll come back again after the holidays , do n't [you]101-ida ? "[103-maud]

[Ida]101-ida shook [her]101-ida head , and said nothing .

" But [I]670-the little maid shall see [you]101-ida again ? "[670-the little maid] pleaded [the little maid]670-the little maid . " [You]101-ida know [we]672-they 're always going to be [friends]562-friends , are n't [we]672-they ? Who shall [I]670-the little maid tell all [my]670-the little maid dreams to , if [I]670-the little maid lose [you]101-ida ? "[670-the little maid]

Dreams , in the literal sense of the word . Seldom a week went by , but [Maud]103-maud had some weird vision of the night to recount to [[her]103-maud friend]669-her friend , the meaning of which [they]672-they would together try to puzzle out ; for it was an article of faith with both that there were meanings to be discovered , and deep ones .

[Ida]101-ida promised that [she]101-ida would not allow [herself]101-ida to be lost to [[her]101-ida friend]669-her friend , and [they]672-they kissed , and went [their]672-they several ways .

Throughout the day the door of [[Mr. Smales]106-mr. smales 's shop]674-mr. smales 's shop had been open , though the shutters were up . But at nightfall it was closed , and [the family]675-the family drew around the tea - table in the parlour which smelt so of drugs . It was [[their]675-the family only sitting - room]676-their only sitting - room , for as much of [the house]288-the house as could be was let to [another family]678-another family . Besides [Mr. Smales]106-mr. smales and [[his]106-mr. smales daughter]679-his daughter [Harriet]99-harriet , there sat at the table a lad of about thirteen , with a dark , handsome face , which had something of a foreign cast [His]680-his eyes gleamed at all times with the light of a frank joyousness ; [he]680-his laughed with the unrestraint of a perfectly happy nature . [His]680-his countenance was capable , too , of a thoughtfulness beyond [his]680-his years , a gravity which seemed to come of high thoughts or rich imagination . [He]680-his bore no trace of resemblance to either [the chemist]362-the chemist or [[his]106-mr. smales daughter]679-his daughter , yet was [[their]672-they relative]683-their relative . [Mr. Smales]106-mr. smales had had [a sister]684-a sister , who at an early age became [a public singer]685-a public singer , and so far prospered as to gain some little distinction in two or three opera seasons . Whilst thus engaged , [she]684-a sister made the acquaintance of [an Italian]686-an italian , [Casti]116-mr. casti by name , fell in love with [him]686-an italian , and subsequently followed [him]686-an italian to [Italy]13-italy . [Her]684-a sister courage was rewarded , for there [she]684-a sister became [[the singer]687-the singer 's wife]688-the singer 's wife . [They]672-they travelled for two years , during which time [a son]689-a son was born to [them]672-they . [The mother]403-the mother 's health failed ; [she]403-the mother was unable henceforth to travel with [[her]403-the mother husband]584-her husband , and , after living in [Rome]14-rome for nearly four years , [she]403-the mother died [there]3249-there . [The boy]693-the boy was shortly brought back to [England]15-england by [[his]693-the boy father]497-his father , and placed in the care of [Mr. Smales]106-mr. smales , on the understanding that a sum of money should be paid yearly for [his]106-mr. smales support and education . From that day to the present nothing more had been heard of [Signor Casti]117-signor casti , and all the care of [[[his]106-mr. smales sister]695-his sister 's child]696-his sister 's child had fallen upon [[poor Smales]106-mr. smales , who was not too well provided with means to support [[his]106-mr. smales own small household]698-his own small household]697-poor smales , who was not too well provided with means to support his own small household . However , [he]106-mr. smales had not failed in the duty , and [Julian]118-julian [his]118-julian name had been Englished was still going to school at [[his]118-julian uncle]699-his uncle 's expense . It was by this time understood that , on leaving [school]306-school , [he]118-julian should come into [the shop]361-the shop , and there qualify [himself]118-julian for the business of [a chemist]344-a chemist .

Had it not been for [Julian]118-julian , [the back parlour]703-the back parlour would have seen but little cheerfulness to - night . [Mr. Smales]106-mr. smales [himself]106-mr. smales was always depressed in mind and ailing in body . Life had proved too much for [him]106-mr. smales ; the burden of the recurring daylight was beyond [his]106-mr. smales strength . There was plainly no lack of kindliness in [his]106-mr. smales disposition , and this never failed to come strongly into [his]106-mr. smales countenance as often as [he]106-mr. smales looked at [Harriet]99-harriet . [She]99-harriet was [[his]106-mr. smales only child]704-his only child . [[Her]99-harriet mother]377-her mother had died of consumption early in [their]706-their married life , and it was [his]106-mr. smales perpetual dread lest [he]106-mr. smales should discover in [Harriet]99-harriet a disposition to the same malady .

[His]106-mr. smales fears had but too much stimulus to keep [them]707-them alive . [Harriet]99-harriet had passed through a sickly childhood , and was growing up with a feeble constitution . Body and mind were alike unhealthy . Of [all the people who came in contact with [her]99-harriet]708-all the people who came in contact with her , [[her]99-harriet father]514-her father alone was blind to [her]99-harriet distorted sense of right , [her]99-harriet baseless resentments , [her]99-harriet malicious pleasures , [her]99-harriet depraved intellect . [His]106-mr. smales affection [she]99-harriet repaid with indifference . At present , [the only person [she]99-harriet appeared to really like]710-the only person she appeared to really like was [the servant [Sarah]105-sally]711-the servant sarah , [a girl of vicious character]712-a girl of vicious character .

[Harriet]99-harriet had suffered more from [Ida]101-ida 's blow than had at first appeared likely . The wound would not heal well , and [she]99-harriet had had several feverish nights . For [her]99-harriet convenience , the couch had been drawn up between the fire and the table ; and , reclining here , [she]99-harriet every now and then threw out a petulant word in reply to [[her]99-harriet father]514-her father 's or [Julian]118-julian 's well - meant cheerfulness . But for [the boy]693-the boy , the gloomy silence would seldom have been broken . [He]693-the boy , however , was full to - night of a favourite subject , and kept up a steady flow of bright narrative . At [school]306-school [he]693-the boy was much engaged just now with the history of [Rome]14-rome , and it was [his]693-the boy greatest delight to tell [the listeners]716-the listeners at [home]3157-home the glorious stories which were [his]693-the boy latest acquisitions . All to - day [he]693-the boy had been reading [Plutarch]119-plutarch . The enthusiasm with which [he]693-the boy spoke of [these old heroes]718-these old heroes and [their]718-these old heroes deeds went beyond mere boyish admiration of valour and delight in bloodshed ; [he]693-the boy seemed to be strongly sensible of the real features of greatness in [these men]719-these men 's lives , and invested [his]693-the boy stories with a glow of poetical colour which found little appreciation in [either of [[his]693-the boy hearers]721-his hearers]720-either of his hearers .

" And [I]693-the boy was born in [Rome]14-rome , was n't [I]693-the boy , [uncle]3293-uncle ? "[693-the boy] [he]693-the boy exclaimed at last . " [I]693-the boy am [a Roman]3294-a roman ; Romanus sum ! "[693-the boy]

Then [he]693-the boy laughed with [his]693-the boy wonted bright gleefulness . It was half in jest , but for all that there was a genuine warmth on [his]693-the boy cheek , and lustre in [his]693-the boy fine eyes .

" Some day [I]693-the boy will go to [Rome]14-rome again , "[693-the boy] [he]693-the boy said , " and both of [you]3293-uncle shall go with [me]693-the boy . [We]3295-we shall see [the Forum]16-the forum and [the Capitol]3296-the capitol ! Sha'n't [you]3293-uncle shout when [you]3293-uncle see [the Capitol]3296-the capitol , [uncle]3293-uncle ? "[693-the boy]

[Poor Smales]120-poor smales only smiled sadly and shook [his]120-poor smales head . It was a long way from [Marylebone]17-marylebone to [Rome]14-rome ; greater still the distance between [the boy]693-the boy 's mind and that of [[his]693-the boy uncle]699-his uncle .

[Sarah]105-sally took [Harriet]99-harriet to bed early . [Julian]118-julian had got hold of [his]118-julian Plutarch again , and read snatches of it aloud every now and then . [[His]693-the boy uncle]699-his uncle paid no heed , was sunk in dull reverie . When [they]725-they had sat thus for more than an hour , [Mr. Smales]106-mr. smales began to exhibit a wish to talk .

" Put the book away , and draw up to the fire , [[my]106-mr. smales boy]3299-my boy , "[106-mr. smales] [he]106-mr. smales said , with as near an approach to heartiness as [he]106-mr. smales was capable of . " It 's Christmas time , and Christmas only comes once a year . "[106-mr. smales]

[He]106-mr. smales rubbed [his]106-mr. smales palms together , then began to twist the corners of [his]106-mr. smales handkerchief .

" Well , [Julian]118-julian , "[106-mr. smales] [he]106-mr. smales went on , leaning feebly forward to the fire , " a year more school , [I]106-mr. smales suppose , and then business ; what ? "[106-mr. smales]

" Yes , [uncle]3293-uncle . "[106-mr. smales]

[The boy]693-the boy spoke cheerfully , but yet not in the same natural way as before .

" [I]693-the boy wish [I]693-the boy could afford to make [you]118-julian something better , [[my]693-the boy lad]3301-my lad ; [you]118-julian ought to be something better by rights . And [I]693-the boy do n't well know what [you]118-julian 'll find to do in [this little shop]3302-this little shop . The business might be better ; yes , might be better . [You]118-julian wo n't have much practice in dispensing , [I]693-the boy 'm afraid , unless things improve . It is mostly hair - oil , and the patent medicines . It 's a poor look - out for [you]118-julian , [Julian]118-julian . "[693-the boy]

There was a silence .

" [Harriet]99-harriet is n't quite well yet , is [she]99-harriet ? "[99-harriet] [Smales]99-harriet went on , half to [himself]99-harriet .

" No , [she]99-harriet looked poorly to - night . "[99-harriet]

" [Julian]118-julian , "[449-the other] began [the other]449-the other , but paused , rubbing [his]449-the other hands more nervously than ever .

" Yes , [uncle]3293-uncle ? "[99-harriet]

" [I]99-harriet wonder what ' ud become of [her]99-harriet if [I]99-harriet if [I]99-harriet died now ? [You]118-julian 're growing up , and [you]118-julian 're [a clever lad]3304-a clever lad ; [you]118-julian 'll soon be able to shift for [yourself]118-julian . But what 'll [Harriet]99-harriet do ? If only [she]99-harriet had [her]99-harriet health . And [I]99-harriet shall have nothing to leave either [her]99-harriet or [you]118-julian , [Julian]118-julian , nothing , nothing ! [She]99-harriet 'll have to get [her]99-harriet living somehow . [I]99-harriet must think of some easy business for [her]99-harriet , [I]99-harriet must . " Yes , [uncle]3293-uncle ? "[99-harriet]

" [You]118-julian [you]118-julian are old enough to understand things , [[my]699-his uncle boy]3299-my boy , "[699-his uncle] went on [[his]728-his uncle]699-his uncle , with quavering voice . [His]693-the boy voice trembled with generous emotion .

Silence came upon [them]731-them again .

In [the same district]732-the same district , in one of [a row of [semi - detached houses]734-semi - detached houses standing in [gardens]735-gardens]733-a row of semi - detached houses standing in gardens , lived [[Ida]101-ida 's little friend]736-ida 's little friend , [Maud Enderby]103-maud , with [[her]103-maud aunt]737-her aunt , [Miss Bygrave]121-miss bygrave , [a lady of forty - two or forty - three]738-a lady of forty - two or forty - three . [The rooms]739-the rooms were small and dark ; the furniture sparse , old - fashioned , and much worn ; there were no ornaments in any of [the rooms]739-the rooms , with the exception of a few pictures representing the saddest incidents in the life of [Christ]122-christ . On entering the front door [you]741-you were oppressed by the chill , damp atmosphere , and by a certain unnatural stillness . [The stairs]742-the stairs were not carpeted , but stained a dark colour ; a footfall upon [them]742-the stairs , however light , echoed strangely as if from [empty chambers above]743-empty chambers above . There was no sign of lack of repair ; perfect order and cleanliness wherever the eye penetrated ; yet the general effect was an unspeakable desolation .

[Maud Enderby]103-maud , on reaching [home]3157-home after [her]103-maud meeting with [Ida]101-ida , entered [the front parlour]745-the front parlour , and sat down in silence near the window , where faint daylight yet glimmered . [The room]255-the room was without fire . Over the mantelpiece hung an engraving of the Crucifixion ; on the opposite wall were the Agony in [the Garden]747-the garden , and an Entombment ; all after [old masters]748-old masters . The centre table , a few chairs , and a small sideboard were the sole articles of furniture . The table was spread with a white cloth ; upon it were a loaf of bread , a pitcher containing milk , two plates , and two glasses .

[Maud]103-maud sat in [the cold room]749-the cold room for a quarter of an hour ; it became quite dark . Then was heard a soft footstep descending [the stairs]742-the stairs ; the door opened , and [a lady]3171-a lady came in , bearing a lighted lamp , which [she]3171-a lady stood upon the table . [She]3171-a lady was tall , very slender , and with a face which [a painter]752-a painter might have used to personify the spiritual life . Its outlines were of severe perfection ; its expression a confirmed grief , subdued by , and made subordinate to , the consciousness of an inward strength which could convert suffering into triumph . [Her]3171-a lady garment was black , of the simplest possible design . In looking at [Maud]103-maud , as [the child]320-the child rose from the chair , it was scarcely affection that [her]3171-a lady eyes expressed , rather a grave compassion . [Maud]103-maud took a seat at the table without speaking ; [[her]103-maud aunt]737-her aunt sat down over against [her]103-maud . In perfect silence [they]755-they partook of the milk and the bread . [Miss Bygrave]121-miss bygrave then cleared the table with [her]121-miss bygrave own hands , and took the things out of [the room]255-the room . [Maud]103-maud still kept [her]103-maud place . [The child]320-the child 's manner was not at all constrained ; [she]320-the child was evidently behaving in [her]320-the child wonted way . [Her]320-the child eyes wandered about [the room]255-the room with rather a dreamy gaze , and , as often as they fell upon [[her]103-maud aunt]737-her aunt 's face , became very serious , though in no degree expressive of fear or even awe .

[Miss Bygrave]121-miss bygrave returned , and seated [herself]121-miss bygrave near [the little girl]760-the little girl ; then remained thoughtful for some minutes . The breath from [their]755-they lips was plainly visible on the air . [Maud]103-maud almost shivered now and then , but forced [herself]103-maud to suppress the impulse . [[Her]103-maud aunt]737-her aunt presently broke the silence , speaking in a low voice , which had nothing of tenderness , but was most impressive in its earnest calm .

" [I]737-her aunt wish to speak to [you]103-maud before [you]103-maud go [upstairs]434-upstairs , [Maud]103-maud ; to speak of things which [you]103-maud can not understand fully as yet , but which [you]103-maud are old enough to begin to think about . "[737-her aunt]

[Maud]103-maud was surprised . It was the first time that [[her]103-maud aunt]737-her aunt had ever addressed [her]103-maud in this serious way . [She]103-maud was used to being all but ignored , though never in a manner which made [her]103-maud feel that [she]103-maud was treated unkindly . There was nothing like confidence between [them]755-they ; only in care for [her]103-maud bodily wants did [Miss Bygrave]121-miss bygrave fill the place of [the mother whose affection [the child]320-the child had never known]763-the mother whose affection the child had never known . [Maud]103-maud crossed [her]103-maud hands on [her]103-maud lap , and looked up with respectful attention upon [her]737-her aunt pale sweet little face .

" Do [you]103-maud wonder at all , "[121-miss bygrave] [Miss Bygrave]121-miss bygrave went on , " why [we]3315-we never spend Christmas like [[your]103-maud friends]3316-your friends do in [[their]3316-your friends homes]3317-their homes , with eating and drinking and all sorts of merriment ? "[121-miss bygrave]

" Yes , [aunt]3318-aunt , [I]121-miss bygrave do . "[121-miss bygrave]

It was evidently the truth , and given with the simple directness which characterised [the child]320-the child .

" [You]103-maud know what Christmas Day means , [Maud]103-maud ? "[121-miss bygrave]

" It is the day on which [Christ]122-christ was born . "[121-miss bygrave]

" And for what purpose did [Christ]122-christ come as [a child]378-a child on [earth]3320-earth ? "[121-miss bygrave]

[Maud]103-maud thought for a moment . [She]103-maud had never had any direct religious teaching ; all [she]103-maud knew of these matters was gathered from [her]103-maud regular attendance at [church]766-church . [She]103-maud replied in a phrase which had rested in [her]103-maud mind , though probably conveying little if any meaning to [her]103-maud .

" [He]122-christ came to make [us]3321-us free from sin . "[103-maud]

" And so [we]3321-us should rejoice at [His]122-christ coming . But would it please [Him]122-christ , do [you]121-miss bygrave think , to see [us]3321-us showing [our]3321-us joy by indulging in those very sins from which [He]122-christ came to free [us]3321-us ? "[103-maud]

[Maud]103-maud looked with puzzled countenance .

" Is it a sin to like cake and sweet things , [aunt]3318-aunt ? "[103-maud]

The gravity of the question brought a smile to [Miss Bygrave]121-miss bygrave 's close , strong lips .

" Listen , [Maud]103-maud , "[121-miss bygrave] [she]121-miss bygrave said , " and [I]121-miss bygrave will tell [you]103-maud what [I]121-miss bygrave mean . For [you]103-maud to like such things is no sin , as long as [you]103-maud are still too young to have it explained to [you]103-maud why [you]103-maud should overcome that liking . As [I]121-miss bygrave said , [you]103-maud are now old enough to begin to think of more than [a child]378-a child 's foolishness , to ask [yourself]103-maud what is the meaning of the life which has been given [you]103-maud , what duties [you]103-maud must set before [yourself]103-maud as [you]103-maud grow up to be [a woman]3216-a woman . When once these duties have become clear to [you]103-maud , when [you]103-maud understand what the end of life is , and how [you]103-maud should seek to gain it , then many things become sinful which were not so before , and many duties must be performed which previously [you]103-maud were not ready for . "[121-miss bygrave]

[Miss Bygrave]121-miss bygrave spoke with effort , as if [she]121-miss bygrave found it difficult to express [herself]121-miss bygrave in sufficiently simple phraseology . Speaking , [she]121-miss bygrave did not look at [the child]320-the child ; and , when the pause came , [her]121-miss bygrave eyes were still fixed absently on the picture above the mantelpiece .

" Keep in mind what [I]121-miss bygrave shall tell [you]103-maud , "[121-miss bygrave] [she]121-miss bygrave proceeded with growing solemnity , " and some day [you]103-maud will better understand its meaning than [you]103-maud can now . The sin which [Christ]122-christ came to free [us]3325-we from was fondness for [the world]622-the world , enjoyment of what [we]3325-we call pleasure , desire for happiness on [earth]3320-earth . [He]122-christ [Himself]122-christ came to set [us]3325-we the example of one to whom [the world]622-the world was nothing , who could put aside every joy , and make [His]122-christ life a life of sorrows . Even that was not enough . When the time had come , and [He]122-christ had finished [His]122-christ teaching of [the disciples whom [He]122-christ chose]3329-the disciples whom he chose , [He]122-christ willingly underwent the most cruel of all deaths , to prove that [His]122-christ teaching had been the truth , and to show [us]3325-we that [we]3325-we must face any most dreadful suffering rather than desert what [we]3325-we believe to be right . "[121-miss bygrave]

[She]768-she pointed to [the crucified figure]769-the crucified figure , and [Maud]103-maud followed the direction of [her]768-she hand with awed gaze .

" And this , "[121-miss bygrave] said [Miss Bygrave]121-miss bygrave , " is why [I]121-miss bygrave think it wrong to make Christmas a time of merriment . In the true Christian , every enjoyment which comes from the body is a sin . If [you]3330-you feel [you]3330-you like this or that , it is a sign that [you]3330-you must renounce it , give it up . If [you]3330-you feel fond of life , [you]3330-you must force [yourself]3330-you to hate it ; for life is sin . Life is given to [us]3325-we that [we]3325-we may conquer [ourselves]3325-we . [We]3325-we are placed in the midst of sin that [we]3325-we may struggle against its temptations . There is temptation in the very breath [you]3330-you draw , since [you]3330-you feel a dread if it is checked . [You]3330-you must live so as to be ready at any moment to give up [your]3330-you life with gladness , as a burden which it has been appointed [you]3330-you to bear for a time . There is temptation in the love [you]3330-you feel for those around [you]3330-you ; it makes [you]3330-you cling to life ; [you]3330-you are tempted to grieve if [you]3330-you lose [them]3331-them , whereas death is the greatest blessing in the gift of [God]123-god . And just because it is so , [we]3325-we must not snatch at it before [our]3325-we time ; it would be a sin to kill [ourselves]3325-we , since that would be to escape from the tasks set [us]3325-we . Many pleasures would seem to be innocent , but even these it is better to renounce , since for that purpose does every pleasure exist . [I]121-miss bygrave speak of the pleasures of [the world]622-the world . One joy there is which [we]3325-we may and must pursue , the joy of sacrifice . The more the body suffers , the greater should be the delight of the soul ; and the only moment of perfect happiness should be that when [the world]622-the world grows dark around [us]3325-we , and [we]3325-we feel the hand of death upon [our]3325-we hearts . "[121-miss bygrave]

[She]770-she was silent , and [both]771-both sat in [the cold room]749-the cold room without word or motion .

CHAPTER V

POSSIBILITIES

Christmas passed , and the beginning of the New Year drew nigh . And , one morning , as [Mr. Woodstock]114-mr. woodstock was glancing up and down the pages of a ledger , a telegram was delivered to [him]114-mr. woodstock . It was from [a hospital in [the north - west of [London]3-london]299-the north - west of london]773-a hospital in the north - west of london . " [[Your]114-mr. woodstock daughter]3334-your daughter is dying , and wishes to see [you]114-mr. woodstock . Please come at once . "[110-lotty]

[Lotty]110-lotty 's ailment had declared itself as pneumonia . [She]110-lotty was frequently delirious , and the substance of [her]110-lotty talk at such times led [the attendant Sister]775-the attendant sister to ask [her]110-lotty , when reason returned , whether [she]110-lotty did not wish [any relative]776-any relative to be sent for . [Lotty]110-lotty was frightened , but , as long as [she]110-lotty was told that there was still hope of recovery , declined to mention any name . The stubborn independence which had supported [her]110-lotty through these long years asserted itself again , as a reaction after [her]110-lotty fruitless appeal ; at moments [she]110-lotty felt that [she]110-lotty could die with [her]110-lotty lips closed , and let what might happen to [[her]110-lotty child]524-her child . But when [she]110-lotty at length read upon the faces of those about [her]110-lotty that [her]110-lotty fate hung in the balance , and when [she]110-lotty saw the face of [little Ida]101-ida , come [there]3249-there [she]110-lotty knew not how , looking upon [her]110-lotty from the bedside , then [her]110-lotty purpose yielded , and in a whisper [she]110-lotty told [[her]110-lotty father]514-her father 's address , and begged that [he]514-her father might be apprised of [her]110-lotty state .

[Abraham Woodstock]780-abraham woodstock arrived at [the hospital]3287-the hospital , but to no purpose . [Lotty]110-lotty had lost [her]110-lotty consciousness . [He]780-abraham woodstock waited for some hours ; there was no return of sensibility . When it had been long dark , and [he]780-abraham woodstock had withdrawn from [the ward]655-the ward for a little , [he]780-abraham woodstock was all at once hastily summoned back . [He]780-abraham woodstock stood by the bedside , [his]780-abraham woodstock hands behind [his]780-abraham woodstock back , [his]780-abraham woodstock face set in a hard gaze upon the pale features on the pillow . Opposite to [him]780-abraham woodstock stood [the medical man]783-the medical man , and a screen placed around the bed shut [them]784-them off from the rest of [the ward]655-the ward . All at once [Lotty]110-lotty 's eyes opened . It seemed as though [she]110-lotty recognised [[her]110-lotty father]514-her father , for a look of surprise came to [her]110-lotty countenance . Then there was a gasping for breath , a struggle , and the eyes saw no more , for all [their]784-them staring .

[Mr. Woodstock]114-mr. woodstock left [the hospital]3287-the hospital . At [the first public - house]788-the first public - house [he]114-mr. woodstock reached [he]114-mr. woodstock entered and drank a glass of whisky . [The barman]789-the barman had forgotten the piece of lemon , and was rewarded with an oath considerably stronger than the occasion seemed to warrant . Arrived at [certain cross - ways]790-certain cross - ways , [Mr. Woodstock]114-mr. woodstock paused . [His]114-mr. woodstock eyes were turned downwards ; [he]114-mr. woodstock did not seem dubious of [his]114-mr. woodstock way , so much as in hesitation as to a choice of directions . [He]114-mr. woodstock took a few steps hither , then back ; began to wend thither , and again turned . When [he]114-mr. woodstock at length decided , [[his]114-mr. woodstock road]791-his road brought [him]114-mr. woodstock to [Milton Street]6-milton street , and up to the door on which stood the name of [Mrs. Ledward]108-mrs. ledward .

[He]114-mr. woodstock knocked loudly , and [the landlady]386-the landlady [herself]386-the landlady opened .

" [A Mrs. Starr]107-mrs. starr lived [here]3335-here , [I]114-mr. woodstock believe ? "[114-mr. woodstock] [he]114-mr. woodstock asked .

" [She]107-mrs. starr does live [here]3335-here , [sir]3257-sir , but [she]107-mrs. starr 's in [the orspital]3338-the orspital at present , [I]114-mr. woodstock 'm sorry to say . "[114-mr. woodstock]

" Is [[her]107-mrs. starr child]524-her child at [home]3157-home ? "[114-mr. woodstock]

" [She]107-mrs. starr is , [sir]3257-sir . "[114-mr. woodstock]

" Let [me]114-mr. woodstock see [her]107-mrs. starr , will [you]3257-sir ? In [some room]3342-some room , if [you]3257-sir please . "[114-mr. woodstock]

[Mrs. Ledward]108-mrs. ledward 's squinting eyes took shrewd stock of [this gentleman]793-this gentleman , and , with much politeness , [she]108-mrs. ledward showed [him]793-this gentleman into [[her]108-mrs. ledward own parlour]794-her own parlour . Then [she]108-mrs. ledward summoned [Ida]101-ida from [upstairs]434-upstairs , and , the door being closed upon [the two]273-the two , [she]108-mrs. ledward held [her]108-mrs. ledward ear as closely as possible to the keyhole .

[Ida]101-ida recognised [[her]101-ida visitor]797-her visitor with a start , and drew back a little . There were both fear and dislike in [her]101-ida face , fear perhaps predominating .

" [You]101-ida remember coming to see [me]114-mr. woodstock , "[114-mr. woodstock] said [Mr. Woodstock]114-mr. woodstock , looking down upon [the child]320-the child , and a trifle askance .

" Yes , [sir]3257-sir , "[101-ida] was [Ida]101-ida 's reply .

" [I]114-mr. woodstock have just been at [the hospital]3287-the hospital . [[Your]320-the child mother]3184-your mother is dead . "[114-mr. woodstock]

[His]114-mr. woodstock voice gave way a little between the first and the last letter of the last word . Perhaps the sound was more to [his]114-mr. woodstock ear than the thought had been to [his]114-mr. woodstock mind . Perhaps , also , [he]114-mr. woodstock felt when it was too late that [he]114-mr. woodstock ought to have made this announcement with something more of preparation . [Ida]101-ida 's eyes were fixed upon [his]114-mr. woodstock face , and seemed expanding as [they]799-they gazed ; [her]101-ida lips had parted ; [she]101-ida was the image of sudden dread . [He]114-mr. woodstock tried to look away from [her]101-ida , but somehow could not . Then two great tears dropped upon [her]101-ida cheeks , and [her]101-ida mouth began to quiver . [She]101-ida put [her]101-ida hands up to [her]101-ida face , and sobbed as [a grown woman]800-a grown woman might have done .

[Mr. Woodstock]114-mr. woodstock turned away for a minute , and fingered a china ornament on the mantelpiece . [He]114-mr. woodstock heard the sobs forcibly checked , and , when there was silence , again faced [[his]114-mr. woodstock grandchild]801-his grandchild .

" [You]101-ida 'll be left all alone now , [you]101-ida see , "[114-mr. woodstock] [he]114-mr. woodstock said , [his]114-mr. woodstock voice less hard . " [I]114-mr. woodstock was [a friend of [[your]101-ida mother]3184-your mother 's]3346-a friend of your mother 's , and [I]114-mr. woodstock 'll do what [I]114-mr. woodstock can for [you]101-ida . [You]101-ida 'd better come with [me]114-mr. woodstock to [[my]114-mr. woodstock house]3348-my house . "[114-mr. woodstock]

[Ida]101-ida looked at [him]114-mr. woodstock in surprise , tempered with indignation .

" If [you]115-abraham were [a friend of [mother]375-mother 's]3349-a friend of mother 's , "[101-ida] [she]101-ida said , " why did [you]115-abraham want to take [me]101-ida away from [her]3184-your mother and never let [her]3184-your mother see [me]101-ida again ? "[101-ida]

" Well , [you]101-ida 've nothing to do with that , "[115-abraham] said [Abraham]115-abraham roughly . " Go and put [your]101-ida things on , and come with [me]115-abraham . "[115-abraham]

" No , "[101-ida] replied [Ida]101-ida firmly . " [I]101-ida do n't want to go with [you]115-abraham . "[101-ida]

" What [you]101-ida want has nothing to do with it . [You]101-ida will do as [I]115-abraham tell [you]101-ida . "[115-abraham]

[Abraham]115-abraham felt strangely in this interview . It was as though time were repeating itself , and [he]802-he was once more at issue with [[his]802-he daughter]679-his daughter 's childish wilfulness .

[Ida]101-ida did not move .

" Why wo n't [you]101-ida come ? "[114-mr. woodstock] asked [Mr. Woodstock]114-mr. woodstock sharply .

" [I]101-ida do n't want to , "[101-ida] was [Ida]101-ida 's answer .

" Look here , then , "[449-the other] said [the other]449-the other , after a brief consideration . " [You]101-ida have the choice , and [you]101-ida 're old enough to see what it means . [You]101-ida can either come with [me]449-the other and be well cared for , or stay here and shift as best [you]101-ida can ; now , be sharp and make up [your]101-ida mind . "[449-the other]

" [I]114-mr. woodstock do n't wish to go with [you]114-mr. woodstock , [I]114-mr. woodstock 'll stay here and do [my]114-mr. woodstock best . "[114-mr. woodstock]

" Very well . "[449-the other]

[Mr. Woodstock]114-mr. woodstock whistled a bar of an air , stepped from [the room]255-the room , and thence out into [the streets]3169-the streets .

It was not [his]114-mr. woodstock intention really to go at once . [Irritation]124-irritation had made it impossible for [him]114-mr. woodstock to speak longer with [the child]320-the child ; [he]114-mr. woodstock would walk the length of [the street]340-the street and return to give [her]320-the child one more chance . Distracted in purpose as [he]114-mr. woodstock had never been in [his]114-mr. woodstock life before , [he]114-mr. woodstock reached [Marylebone Road]18-marylebone road ; rain was just beginning to fall , and [he]114-mr. woodstock had no umbrella with [him]114-mr. woodstock . [He]114-mr. woodstock stood and looked back . [Ida]101-ida once out of [his]114-mr. woodstock sight , that impatient tenderness which [her]101-ida face inspired failed before the recollection of [her]101-ida stubbornness . [She]101-ida had matched [her]101-ida will with [his]114-mr. woodstock , as bad an omen as well could be . What was [the child]320-the child to [him]114-mr. woodstock , or [he]114-mr. woodstock to [her]101-ida ? [He]114-mr. woodstock did not feel capable of trying to make [her]101-ida like [him]114-mr. woodstock ; what good in renewing the old conflicts and upsetting the position of freedom [he]114-mr. woodstock had attained ? Doubtless [she]101-ida inherited a fatal disposition . In [his]114-mr. woodstock mind lurked the foreknowledge that [he]114-mr. woodstock might come to be fond of [this little outcast]810-this little outcast , but [Woodstock]114-mr. woodstock was incapable as yet of understanding that love must and will be its own reward . The rain fell heavier , and at this moment an omnibus came up . [He]114-mr. woodstock hailed it , saying to [himself]114-mr. woodstock that [he]114-mr. woodstock would think the matter over and come back on the morrow . The first part of [his]114-mr. woodstock purpose [he]114-mr. woodstock fulfilled ; but to [Milton Street]6-milton street [he]114-mr. woodstock never returned .

As soon as [he]114-mr. woodstock had left [the house]288-the house , [Mrs. Ledward]108-mrs. ledward bounced into [the room where [Ida]101-ida stood]812-the room where ida stood .

" [You]101-ida little idjot ! "[108-mrs. ledward] [she]108-mrs. ledward exclaimed . " What do [you]101-ida mean by refusing a offer like that ! Why , [the gentleman]3285-the gentleman 's [[your]101-ida own father]3352-your own father . "[108-mrs. ledward]

" [[My]101-ida father]3353-my father ! "[101-ida] repeated [Ida]101-ida , in scornful astonishment . " [[My]101-ida father]3353-my father died when [I]101-ida was [a baby]3355-a baby . [Mother]126-mother 's told [me]101-ida so often . "[101-ida]

" If [you]101-ida believe all [[your]101-ida mother]3184-your mother told [you]101-ida , Well , well , [you]101-ida have been a little wooden - head . What made [you]101-ida behave like that to [him]3285-the gentleman ? Where does [he]3285-the gentleman live , eh ? "[108-mrs. ledward]

" [I]101-ida do n't know . "[101-ida]

" [You]101-ida do know . Why , [I]108-mrs. ledward heard [him]3285-the gentleman say [you]101-ida 'd been to see [him]3285-the gentleman . And what are [you]101-ida going to do , [I]108-mrs. ledward 'd like to know ? [You]101-ida do n't expect [me]108-mrs. ledward to keep [you]101-ida , [I]108-mrs. ledward s'pose . Tell [me]108-mrs. ledward at once where [the gentleman]3285-the gentleman lives , and let [me]108-mrs. ledward take [you]101-ida [there]3249-there . The idea of [your]101-ida turning against [[your]101-ida own father]3352-your own father ! "[108-mrs. ledward]

" [He]3285-the gentleman 's not [[my]101-ida father]3353-my father ! "[101-ida] cried [Ida]101-ida passionately . " [[My]101-ida father]3353-my father is dead ; and now [mother]375-mother 's dead , and [I]101-ida 'm alone . "[101-ida] [She]101-ida turned and went from [the room]255-the room , weeping bitterly .

CHAPTER VI

AN ADVERTISEMENT

In a morning newspaper of March 187 , that is to chapter , appeared a singular advertisement .

" WANTED , [human companionship]3363-human companionship . [A young man of four - and - twenty]3364-a young man of four - and - twenty wishes to find [a congenial associate of about [his]3364-a young man of four - and - twenty own age]3365-a congenial associate of about his own age . [He]3364-a young man of four - and - twenty is [a student of ancient and modern literatures]3366-a student of ancient and modern literatures , [a free - thinker in religion]3367-a free - thinker in religion , [a lover of art in all its forms]3368-a lover of art in all its forms , [a hater of conventionalism]3369-a hater of conventionalism . Would like to correspond in the first instance . Address O. W. , [City News Rooms]3370-city news rooms , W.C. "[108-mrs. ledward]

An advertisement which , naturally , might mean much or little , might be the outcome of an idle whim , or the despairing cry of a hungry heart . It could not be expected to elicit many replies ; and brought indeed but one .

Behind the counter of [[a chemist]344-a chemist 's shop in [Oxford Street]19-oxford street]815-a chemist 's shop in oxford street there served , day after day , [a young assistant]816-a young assistant much observed of [female customers]817-female customers . [The young man]818-the young man was handsome , and not with that vulgar handsomeness which is fairly common among [the better kind of shop - walkers]819-the better kind of shop - walkers and [counter - keepers]820-counter - keepers . [He]818-the young man had rather long black hair , which arranged itself in silky ripples about a face of perfectly clear , though rather dark , complexion . When [he]818-the young man smiled , as [he]818-the young man frequently did , the effect was very pleasant . [He]818-the young man spoke , too , with that musical intonation which is always more or less suggestive of musical thought . [He]818-the young man did not seem by any means ideally adapted to [the place [he]818-the young man occupied [here]3335-here]821-the place he occupied here , yet filled [it]821-the place he occupied here without suspicion of constraint or uneasiness : there was nothing in [him]818-the young man to make [one]318-one suppose that [he]818-the young man had ever been accustomed to a better sphere of life .

[He]818-the young man lived in [the house above [the shop]361-the shop]824-the house above the shop , and had done so for about two years ; previously [he]818-the young man had held a like position in [a more modest establishment]826-a more modest establishment . [[His]818-the young man bed - room]827-his bed - room , which had to serve [him]818-the young man as sitting - room also during [his]818-the young man free hours , gave indications of a taste not ordinarily found in [chemists ' assistants]828-chemists ' assistants . On the walls were several engravings of views in [Rome]14-rome , ancient and modern ; and there were two bookcases filled with literature which had evidently known the second - hand stall , most of [the Latin poets]829-the latin poets , a few Italian books , and some English classics . Not a trace anywhere of the habits and predilections not unfairly associated with [the youth of [the shop]361-the shop]830-the youth of the shop , not even a pipe or a cigar - holder . It was while sitting alone here one evening , half musing , half engaged in glancing over the advertisements in a paper two days old , that [the assistant]832-the assistant had been attracted by the insertion just quoted . [He]832-the assistant read and re - read it , became more thoughtful , sighed slightly . Then [he]832-the assistant moved to the table and took some note - paper out of a writing - case . Still [he]818-the young man seemed to be in doubt , hesitated in pressing a pen against [his]818-the young man thumb - nail , was on the point of putting the note - paper away again . Ultimately , however , [he]818-the young man sat down to write . [He]818-the young man covered four pages with a letter , which [he]818-the young man then proceeded deliberately to correct and alter , till [he]818-the young man had cut it down by about half . Then came another period of doubt before [he]818-the young man decided to make a fair copy . But it was finally made , and the signature at the foot was : [Julian Casti]118-julian .

[He]818-the young man went out at once to the post .

Two days later [he]818-the young man received a reply , somewhat longer than [his]818-the young man own epistle . [The writer]833-the writer was clearly keeping [himself]833-the writer in a tentative attitude . Still , [he]833-the writer wrote something about [his]833-the writer own position and [his]833-the writer needs . [He]833-the writer was [a teacher in [a school in [South London]20-south london]835-a school in south london , living in [lodgings]836-lodgings , with [his]833-the writer evenings mostly unoccupied]834-a teacher in a school in south london , living in lodgings , with his evenings mostly unoccupied . [His]833-the writer habits , [he]833-the writer declared , were [Bohemian]127-bohemian . Suppose , by way of testing each other 's dispositions , [they]837-they were to interchange views on some book with which both were likely to be acquainted : say , [Keats]128-keats 's poems ? In conclusion , the " O. W. "[838-himself] of the advertisement signed [himself]838-himself [Osmond Waymark]129-waymark .

The result was that , a week after , [Casti]118-julian received an invitation to call on [Waymark]129-waymark , at [the latter 's lodgings in [Walcot Square]21-walcot square , [Kennington]22-kennington]839-the latter 's lodgings in walcot square , kennington . [He]118-julian arrived on a Saturday evening , just after eight o'clock . [The house]288-the house [he]118-julian sought proved to be one of very modest appearance ; small , apparently not too clean , generally uninviting . But [a decent - looking woman]841-a decent - looking woman opened the door , and said that [Mr. Waymark]130-waymark would be found in response to a knock at the first - floor front . [The visitor]842-the visitor made [his]842-the visitor way up the dark , narrow stair - case , and knocked as bidden . A firm voice summoned [him]842-the visitor to enter .

From a seat by a table which was placed as near as possible to a very large fire rose [a young man whose age might have been either twenty - three or twenty - six]843-a young man whose age might have been either twenty - three or twenty - six . [Most people]844-most people would have inclined to give [him]843-a young man whose age might have been either twenty - three or twenty - six the latter figure . [He]843-a young man whose age might have been either twenty - three or twenty - six was rather above the average stature , and showed well - hung limbs , with a habit of holding [himself]843-a young man whose age might have been either twenty - three or twenty - six which suggested considerable toughness of sinews ; [he]843-a young man whose age might have been either twenty - three or twenty - six moved gracefully , and with head well held up . [His]843-a young man whose age might have been either twenty - three or twenty - six attire spoke sedentary habits ; would have been decidedly shabby , but for its evident adaptation to easy - chair and fireside . The pure linen and general tone of cleanliness were reassuring ; the hand , too , which [he]843-a young man whose age might have been either twenty - three or twenty - six extended , was soft , delicate , and finely formed . The head was striking , strongly individual , set solidly on a rather long and shapely neck ; a fine forehead , irregular nose , rather prominent jaw - bones , lips just a little sensual , but speaking good - humour and intellectual character . A heavy moustache ; no beard . Eyes dark , keen , very capable of tenderness , but perhaps more often shrewdly discerning or cynically speculative . [One]131-one felt that the present expression of genial friendliness was unfamiliar to the face , though it by no means failed in pleasantness . The lips had the look of being frequently gnawed in intense thought or strong feeling . In the cheeks no healthy colour , but an extreme sallowness on all the features . Smiling , [he]843-a young man whose age might have been either twenty - three or twenty - six showed imperfect teeth . Altogether , [a young man upon whom [one felt it difficult to pronounce in the earlier stages of acquaintance]846-one felt it difficult to pronounce in the earlier stages of acquaintance ; whose intimacy but [few men]847-few men would exert [themselves]847-few men to seek ; who in all likelihood was chary of exhibiting [his]843-a young man whose age might have been either twenty - three or twenty - six true self save when secure of being understood]845-a young man upon whom one felt it difficult to pronounce in the earlier stages of acquaintance ; whose intimacy but few men would exert themselves to seek ; who in all likelihood was chary of exhibiting his true self save when secure of being understood .

[Julian Casti]118-julian was timid with [strangers]477-strangers ; [his]118-julian eyes fell before the other 's look , and [he]118-julian shook hands without speaking . The contrast in mere appearance between [the two]273-the two was very pronounced ; [both]771-both seemed in some degree to be aware of it . [Waymark]130-waymark seemed more rugged than in ordinary companionship ; the slightly effeminate beauty of [Casti]118-julian , and [his]118-julian diffident , shyly graceful manners , were more noticeable than usual . [Waymark]130-waymark inspected [[his]130-waymark visitor]851-his visitor closely and directly ; [the latter]425-the latter only ventured upon one or two quick side glances . Yet the results were , on the whole , mutually satisfactory .

[Julian]118-julian 's eyes glistened at the sight of two goodly bookcases , reaching from floor to ceiling . There were , too , pictures of other than [the lodging - house type]853-the lodging - house type ; engraved heads of [the great in art and science]854-the great in art and science , and a few reproductions in pencil or chalk of known subjects , perchance [[their]425-the latter possessor]855-their possessor 's own work . On the table lay traces of literary occupation , sheets of manuscript , open books , and the like . On another table stood a tray , with cups and saucers . A kettle was boiling on the fire .
