Leisure is the one thing that all desire , but [they]3195-men strive for it so blindly that [they]3195-men frustrate [one another]257-one another 's hope . And so at length [they]3195-men have come to lose the end in the means ; are mad enough to set the means before [them]3195-men as in itself an end . "[101-ida]

" [We]3884-we must work to forget [our]3884-we troubles , "[1325-his companion] said [[his]129-waymark companion]1325-his companion simply .

" Why , yes , and those very troubles are the fit reward of [our]3884-we folly . [We]3884-we have not been content to live in the simple happiness of [our]3884-we senses . [We]3884-we must be learned and wise , forsooth . [We]3884-we were not content to enjoy the beauty of the greater and the lesser light . [We]3884-we must understand whence [they]3195-men come and whither [they]3195-men go after that , what [they]3195-men are made of and how much [they]3195-men weigh . [We]3884-we thought for such a long time that [our]3884-we toil would end in something ; that [we]3884-we might become as [gods]3885-gods , knowing good and evil . Now [we]3884-we are at the end of [our]3884-we tether , [we]3884-we see clearly enough that it has all been worse than vain ; how good if [we]3884-we could unlearn it all , scatter the building of phantasmal knowledge in which [we]3884-we dwell so uncomfortably ! It is too late . [The gods]3886-the gods never take back [their]3886-the gods gifts ; [we]3884-we wearied [them]3886-the gods with [our]3884-we prayers into granting [us]3884-we this one , and now [they]3886-the gods sit in the clouds and mock [us]3884-we . "[1325-his companion]

[Ida]101-ida looked , and kept silent ; perhaps scarcely understood .

" [People]3402-people kill [themselves]3402-people in despair , "[129-waymark] [Waymark]129-waymark went on , " that is , when [they]3402-people have drunk to the very dregs the cup of life 's bitterness . If [they]3402-people were wise , [they]3402-people would die at that moment if it ever comes when joy seems supreme and stable . Life can give nothing further , and it has no more hellish misery than disillusion following upon delight . "[129-waymark]

" Did [you]129-waymark ever seriously think of killing [yourself]129-waymark ? "[101-ida] [Ida]101-ida asked , gazing at [him]129-waymark closely .

" Yes . [I]129-waymark have reached at times the point when [I]129-waymark would not have moved a muscle to escape death , and from that it is not far to suicide . But [my]129-waymark joy had never come , and it is hard to go away without that one draught . And [you]129-waymark ! "[129-waymark]

" [I]129-waymark went so far once as to buy poison . But neither had [I]129-waymark tasted any happiness , and [I]129-waymark could not help hoping . "[129-waymark]

" And [you]129-waymark still wait still hope ? "[129-waymark]

[Ida]101-ida made no direct answer . [She]101-ida gazed far off at [the indistinguishable border - land of sea and sky]1702-the indistinguishable border - land of sea and sky , and when [she]101-ida spoke it was in a softened tone .

" When [I]101-ida was here last , [I]101-ida was seven years old . Now [I]101-ida am not quite nineteen . How long [I]101-ida have lived since then how long ! Yet [my]101-ida life did not really begin till [I]101-ida was about eleven . Till then [I]101-ida was [a happy child]3888-a happy child , understanding nothing . Between then and now , if [I]101-ida have discovered little good either in [myself]101-ida or in [others]256-others , [I]101-ida have learned by heart everything that is bad in [the world]622-the world . Nothing in meanness or vileness or wretchedness is a secret to [me]101-ida . Compare [me]101-ida with [other girls of nineteen perhaps still at school]3891-other girls of nineteen perhaps still at school . What sort of [a companion]3892-a companion should [I]101-ida be for one of those , [I]101-ida wonder ! What strange thoughts [I]101-ida should have , if ever [I]101-ida talked with [such a girl]3893-such a girl ; how old [I]101-ida should feel [myself]101-ida beside [her]3893-such a girl ! "[101-ida]

" [Your]3894-your knowledge is better in [my]1703-my eyes than [their]3891-other girls of nineteen perhaps still at school ignorance . [[My]1703-my ideal woman]3895-my ideal woman is [the one who , knowing every darkest secret of life]3896-the one who , knowing every darkest secret of life , keeps yet a pure mind as [you]3894-your do , [Ida]101-ida . "[1703-my]

[She]1703-my was silent so long that [Waymark]129-waymark spoke again .

" [[Your]101-ida mother]3184-your mother died when [you]101-ida were eleven ! "[129-waymark]

" Yes , and that was when [my]129-waymark life began . [[My]129-waymark mother]3876-my mother was very poor , but [she]3876-my mother managed to send [me]129-waymark to [a pretty good school]3899-a pretty good school . But for that , [my]129-waymark life would have been very different ; [I]129-waymark should not have understood [myself]129-waymark as well as [I]129-waymark always have done . [Poor mother]3900-poor mother , [good , good mother]3901-good , good mother ! Oh , if [I]129-waymark could but have [her]3184-your mother now , and thank [her]3184-your mother for all [her]3184-your mother love , and give [her]3184-your mother but one year of quiet happiness . To think that [I]129-waymark can see [her]3184-your mother as if [she]3184-your mother were standing before [me]129-waymark , and yet that [she]3184-your mother is gone , is nowhere , never to be brought back to [me]129-waymark if [I]129-waymark break [my]129-waymark heart with longing ! "[129-waymark]

Tears stood in [her]1704-her eyes . They meant more than [she]1704-her could ever say to [another]921-another , however close and dear to [her]1704-her . The secret of [[her]1704-her mother]377-her mother 's life lay in the grave and in [her]1704-her own mind ; [the one]1707-the one would render it up as soon as the other . For never would [Ida]101-ida tell in words of that moment when there had come to [her]101-ida maturing intelligence clear insight into [[her]1704-her mother]377-her mother 's history , when the fables of childhood had no longer availed to blind [her]101-ida , and every recalled circumstance pointed but to one miserable truth .

" [She]377-her mother 's happier than [we]3902-we are , "[129-waymark] [Waymark]129-waymark said solemnly . " Think how long [she]377-her mother has been resting . "[129-waymark]

[Ida]101-ida became silent , and presently spoke with a firmer voice .

" [They]3903-they took [her]377-her mother to [a hospital]3904-a hospital in [her]377-her mother last illness , and [she]377-her mother died [there]3249-there . [I]101-ida do n't know where [her]377-her mother grave is . "[101-ida]

" And what became of [you]101-ida ? Had [you]101-ida [friends]562-friends to go to ? "[129-waymark]

" [No one]3702-no one ; [I]101-ida was quite alone . [We]3902-we had been living in [lodgings]836-lodgings . [The landlady]386-the landlady told [me]101-ida that of course [I]101-ida could n't stay on [there]3249-there ; [she]386-the landlady could n't afford to keep [me]101-ida ; [I]101-ida must go and find a home somewhere . Try and think what that meant to [me]101-ida . [I]101-ida was so young and ignorant that such an idea as that [I]101-ida might one day have to earn [my]101-ida own living had never entered [my]101-ida mind . [I]101-ida was fed and clothed like [every one else]3911-every one else , a good deal better , indeed , than [some of [the children at school]3913-the children at school]3912-some of the children at school , and [I]101-ida did n't know why it should n't always be so . Besides , [I]101-ida was [a vain child]3914-a vain child ; [I]101-ida thought [myself]101-ida clever ; [I]101-ida had even begun to look at [myself]101-ida in the glass and think [I]101-ida was handsome . It seemed quite natural that [every one]3915-every one should be kind and indulgent to [me]101-ida . [I]101-ida shall never forget the feeling [I]101-ida had when [the landlady]386-the landlady spoke to [me]101-ida in that hard , sharp way . [My]101-ida whole idea of [the world]622-the world was overset all at once ; [I]101-ida seemed to be in a miserable dream . [I]101-ida sat in [[[my]101-ida mother]3876-my mother 's bedroom]3919-my mother 's bedroom hour after hour , and , every step [I]101-ida heard on the stairs , [I]101-ida thought it must be [[my]101-ida mother]3876-my mother coming back [home]3157-home to [me]101-ida ; it was impossible to believe that [I]101-ida was left alone , and could look to [no one]3702-no one for help and comfort . "[101-ida]

" Next morning [the landlady]386-the landlady came up to [me]129-waymark again , and said , if [I]129-waymark liked , [she]386-the landlady could tell [me]129-waymark of a way of earning [my]129-waymark living . It was by going as [a servant]3924-a servant to [an eating - house in [a street close by]3926-a street close by]3925-an eating - house in a street close by , where [they]3927-them wanted [some one]3153-some one to wash up dishes and do different kinds of work not too hard for [a child like [me]129-waymark]3929-a child like me . [I]129-waymark could only do as [I]129-waymark was advised ; [I]129-waymark went at once , and was engaged . [They]3927-them took off the dress [I]129-waymark was wearing , which was far too good for [me]129-waymark then , and gave [me]129-waymark a dirty , ragged one ; then [I]129-waymark was set to work at once to clean some knives . Nothing was said about wages or anything of that kind ; only [I]129-waymark understood that [I]129-waymark should live in [the house]288-the house , and have all given [me]129-waymark that [I]129-waymark needed . Of course [I]129-waymark was very awkward . [I]129-waymark tried [my]129-waymark very hardest to do everything that was set [me]129-waymark , but only got scolding for [my]129-waymark pains ; and it soon came to boxes on the ear , and even kicks . [The place]3248-the place was kept by [a man]1260-a man and [wife]3838-wife ; [they]3927-them had [a daughter older than [I]129-waymark]3934-a daughter older than i , and [they]3927-them treated [her]3934-a daughter older than i just like [a hired servant]3935-a hired servant . [I]129-waymark used to sleep with [the girl]316-the girl in [a wretched kitchen underground]3937-a wretched kitchen underground , and the poor thing kept [me]129-waymark awake every night with crying and complaining of [her]3934-a daughter older than i hard life . It was no harder than [mine]129-waymark , and [I]129-waymark ca n't think [she]3934-a daughter older than i felt it more ; but [I]129-waymark had even then a kind of stubborn pride which kept [me]129-waymark from showing what [I]129-waymark suffered . [I]129-waymark could n't have borne to let [them]3927-them see what a terrible change it was for [me]129-waymark , all this drudgery and unkindness ; [I]129-waymark felt it would have been like taking [them]3927-them into [my]129-waymark confidence , opening [my]129-waymark heart to [them]3927-them , and [I]129-waymark despised [them]3927-them too much for that . [I]129-waymark even tried to talk in a rough rude way , as if [I]129-waymark had never been used to anything better "[129-waymark]

" That was fine , that was heroic ! "[129-waymark] broke in [Waymark]129-waymark admiringly .

" [I]181-jane only know it was miserable enough . And things got worse instead of better . [The master]3938-the master was [a coarse drunken brute]3939-a coarse drunken brute , and [he]3938-the master and [[his]3938-the master wife]505-his wife used to quarrel fearfully . [I]181-jane have seen [them]3927-them throw knives at [each other]459-each other , and do worse things than that , too . [The woman]448-the woman seemed somehow to have a spite against [me]181-jane from the first , and the way [[her]448-the woman husband]584-her husband behaved to [me]181-jane made [her]448-the woman hate [me]181-jane still more . [Child]3152-child as [I]181-jane was , [he]584-her husband did and said things which made [her]448-the woman jealous . Often when [she]448-the woman had gone out of an evening , [I]181-jane had to defend [myself]181-jane against [him]584-her husband , and call [the daughter]404-the daughter to protect [me]181-jane . And so it went on , till , what with fear of [him]584-her husband , and fear of [her]448-the woman , and misery and weariness , [I]181-jane resolved to go away , become of [me]181-jane what might . One night , instead of undressing for bed as usual , [I]181-jane told [Jane]181-jane that was [the daughter]404-the daughter that [I]181-jane could n't bear it any longer , and was going away , as soon as [I]181-jane thought [the house]288-the house was quiet . [She]181-jane looked at [me]181-jane in astonishment , and asked [me]181-jane if [I]181-jane had anywhere to go to . Will [you]3948-you believe that [I]181-jane said yes , [I]181-jane had ? [I]181-jane suppose [I]181-jane spoke in a way which did n't encourage [her]181-jane to ask questions ; [she]181-jane only lay down on the bed and cried as usual . "[181-jane] [Jane]181-jane , " [I]181-jane said , in a little , "[181-jane] if [I]0-i were [you]181-jane , [I]0-i 'd run away as well . " "[0-i] [I]0-i will , " [she]181-jane cried out , starting up , "[0-i] [I]0-i will this very night ! [We]1709-we 'll go out together . " It was [my]1709-we turn to ask [her]181-jane if [she]181-jane had anywhere to go to . [She]181-jane said [she]181-jane knew [a girl who lived in [a good home at [Tottenham]62-tottenham]3950-a good home at tottenham , and who 'd do something for [her]181-jane , [she]181-jane thought . At any rate [she]181-jane 'd rather go to [the workhouse]3951-the workhouse than stay where [she]181-jane was]3949-a girl who lived in a good home at tottenham , and who 'd do something for her , she thought . at any rate she 'd rather go to the workhouse than stay where she was . So , about one o'clock , [we]1709-we both crept out by a back way , and ran into [Edgware Road]63-edgware road . There [we]1709-we said good - bye , and [she]181-jane went one way , and [I]1709-we another .[1709-we]

" All that night [I]129-waymark walked about , for fear of being noticed loitering by [a policeman]1119-a policeman . When it was morning , [I]129-waymark had come round to [Hyde Park]32-hyde park , and , though it was terribly cold just in March [I]129-waymark went to sleep on a seat . [I]129-waymark woke about ten o'clock , and walked off into [the town]1023-the town , seeking [a poor part , where [I]129-waymark thought it more likely [I]129-waymark might find something to do]3954-a poor part , where i thought it more likely i might find something to do . Of course [I]129-waymark asked first of all at [eating - houses]3955-eating - houses , but [no one]3702-no one wanted [me]129-waymark . It was nearly dark , and [I]129-waymark had n't tasted anything . Then [I]129-waymark begged of [one or two people]3957-one or two people [I]129-waymark forgot everything but [my]129-waymark hunger and [they]3957-one or two people gave [me]129-waymark a few coppers . [I]129-waymark bought some bread , and still wandered about . There are [some streets into which [I]129-waymark can never bear to go now]3958-some streets into which i can never bear to go now ; the thought of walking about them eight years ago is too terrible to [me]129-waymark . Well , [I]129-waymark walked till midnight , and then could stand up no longer . [I]129-waymark found [myself]129-waymark in [a dirty little street where the house doors stood open all night]3959-a dirty little street where the house doors stood open all night ; [I]129-waymark went into one , and walked up as far as [the first landing]3960-the first landing , and there fell down in a corner and slept all night . "[129-waymark]

" [Poor child]3961-poor child ! "[129-waymark] said [Waymark]129-waymark , looking into [her]1710-her face , which had become very animated as the details of the story succeeded each other in [her]1710-her mind .

" [I]101-ida must have looked [a terrible little savage]3962-a terrible little savage on that next morning , "[101-ida] [Ida]101-ida went on , smiling sadly . " Oh , how hungry [I]101-ida was ! [I]101-ida was awoke by [a woman who came out of one of [the rooms]739-the rooms]3963-a woman who came out of one of the rooms , and [I]101-ida asked [her]3963-a woman who came out of one of the rooms if [she]3963-a woman who came out of one of the rooms 'd give [me]101-ida something to eat . [She]3963-a woman who came out of one of the rooms said [she]3963-a woman who came out of one of the rooms would , if [I]101-ida 'd light [her]3963-a woman who came out of one of the rooms fire for [her]3963-a woman who came out of one of the rooms , and clean up the grate . [I]101-ida did this , gladly enough . Then [she]3963-a woman who came out of one of the rooms pretended [I]101-ida had done it badly , and gave [me]101-ida one miserable little dry crust , and told [me]101-ida to be off . Well , that day [I]101-ida found [another woman who said [she]3963-a woman who came out of one of the rooms 'd give [me]101-ida one meal and twopence a day for helping [her]3963-a woman who came out of one of the rooms to chop wood and wash vegetables]3965-another woman who said she 'd give me one meal and twopence a day for helping her to chop wood and wash vegetables ; [she]3963-a woman who came out of one of the rooms had [a son]689-a son who was [a costermonger]3967-a costermonger , and the stuff [he]689-a son sold had to be cleaned each day . [I]101-ida took the work gladly . [She]3963-a woman who came out of one of the rooms never asked [me]101-ida where [I]101-ida spent the night ; the truth was [I]101-ida chose [a different house]3968-a different house each night , where [I]101-ida found the door open , and went up and slept on the stairs . [I]101-ida often found [several people]3969-several people doing the same thing , and [no one]3702-no one disturbed [us]3971-us .[101-ida]

" [I]129-waymark lived so for a fortnight , then [I]129-waymark was lucky enough to get into [another eating - house]3972-another eating - house . [I]129-waymark lived [there]3249-there nearly two months , and had to leave for the very same reason as at the first place . [I]129-waymark only half understood the meaning of what [I]129-waymark had to resist , but [my]129-waymark resistance led to other unbearable cruelties , and again [I]129-waymark ran away . [I]129-waymark went about eight o'clock in the evening . The thought of going back to [my]129-waymark old sleeping places on the stairs was horrible . Besides , for some days a strange idea had been in [my]129-waymark head . [I]129-waymark had not forgotten [[my]129-waymark friend]3429-my friend [Jane]181-jane , and [I]129-waymark wondered whether , if [I]129-waymark went to [Tottenham]62-tottenham , it would be possible to find [her]181-jane . Perhaps [she]181-jane might be well off there , and could help [me]129-waymark . [I]129-waymark had made inquiries about the way to [Tottenham]62-tottenham , and the distance , and when [I]129-waymark left [the eating - house]3975-the eating - house [I]129-waymark had made up [my]129-waymark mind to walk straight [there]3249-there . [I]129-waymark started from [Hoxton]64-hoxton , and went on and on , till [I]129-waymark had left [the big streets]3977-the big streets behind . [I]129-waymark kept asking [my]129-waymark way , but often went long distances in the wrong direction . [I]129-waymark knew that [Tottenham]62-tottenham was quite in [the country]3594-the country , and [my]129-waymark idea was to find [a sleeping - place]3979-a sleeping - place in [some field]3980-some field , then to begin [my]129-waymark search on the next day . It was summer , but still [I]129-waymark began to feel cold , and this drew [me]129-waymark away out of [[my]129-waymark straight road]3981-my straight road to a fire which [I]129-waymark saw burning a little way off . [I]129-waymark thought it would be nice to sit down by it and rest . [I]129-waymark found that [the road]1271-the road was being mended , and by the fire lay [a watchman]3983-a watchman in a big tub . Just as [I]129-waymark came up [he]3983-a watchman was eating [his]3983-a watchman supper . [He]3983-a watchman was [a great , rough man]3984-a great , rough man , but [I]129-waymark looked in [his]3983-a watchman face and thought it seemed good , so [I]129-waymark asked [him]3983-a watchman if [he]3983-a watchman 'd let [me]129-waymark rest a little . Of course [he]3983-a watchman was surprised at seeing [me]129-waymark there , for it must have been midnight , and when [he]3983-a watchman asked [me]129-waymark about [myself]129-waymark [I]129-waymark told [him]3983-a watchman the truth , because [he]3983-a watchman spoke in a kind way . Then [he]3983-a watchman stopped eating and gave [me]129-waymark what was left ; it was a bit of fat bacon and some cold potatoes ; but how good it was , and how good [he]3983-a watchman was ! To this moment [I]129-waymark can see [that man]3985-that man 's face . [He]3983-a watchman got out of [his]3983-a watchman tub and made [me]129-waymark take [[his]3983-a watchman place]3986-his place , and [he]3983-a watchman wrapped [me]129-waymark up in something [he]3983-a watchman had there . Then [he]3983-a watchman sat by the fire , and kept looking at [me]129-waymark , [I]129-waymark thought , in a sad sort of way ; and [he]3983-a watchman said , over and over again , ' Ay , it 's bad to be born [a little girl]266-a little girl ; it 's bad to be born [a little girl]266-a little girl ; pity [you]129-waymark was n't [a boy]3219-a boy . ' Oh , how well [I]129-waymark can hear [his]3983-a watchman voice this moment ! And as [he]3983-a watchman kept saying this , [I]129-waymark went off to sleep . "[129-waymark]

[She]1711-she stopped , and played with the pebbles .

" And in the morning ? "[129-waymark] asked [Waymark]129-waymark .

" Well , when [I]129-waymark woke up , it was light , and there were [a lot of other men]3990-a lot of other men about , beginning [their]3990-a lot of other men work on [the road]1271-the road . [I]129-waymark crept out of the tub , and when [they]3990-a lot of other men saw [me]129-waymark , [they]3990-a lot of other men laughed in a kind sort of way , and gave [me]129-waymark some breakfast . [I]129-waymark suppose [I]129-waymark thanked [them]3990-a lot of other men , [I]129-waymark hope [I]129-waymark did ; [the watchman]3992-the watchman was gone , but no doubt [he]3983-a watchman had told [the others]3162-the others [my]129-waymark story , for [they]3990-a lot of other men showed [me]129-waymark the way to [Tottenham]62-tottenham , and wished [me]129-waymark luck . "[129-waymark]

" And [you]129-waymark found [[your]129-waymark friend]3729-your friend [Jane]181-jane ! "[129-waymark]

" No , no ; how was it likely [I]129-waymark should ? [I]129-waymark wandered about till [I]129-waymark could stand no longer , and then [I]129-waymark went up to the door of [a house which stood in [a garden]3996-a garden]3995-a house which stood in a garden , and begged for something to eat . [The servant who opened was sending [me]129-waymark away , when [[her]3997-the servant who opened was sending me away , when her mistress mistress]3998-her mistress]3997-the servant who opened was sending me away , when her mistress heard , and came to the door . [She]3998-her mistress stood looking at [me]129-waymark for some time , and then told [me]129-waymark to come in . [I]129-waymark went into [the kitchen]3999-the kitchen , and [she]3998-her mistress asked [me]129-waymark all about [myself]129-waymark . [I]129-waymark told [her]3998-her mistress the truth ; [I]129-waymark was too miserable now to do anything else . Well , the result was [she]3998-her mistress kept [me]129-waymark [there]3249-there . "[129-waymark]

" For good ? "[129-waymark]

" Indeed , for good . In [that very house]4001-that very house [I]129-waymark lived for six years . Oh ; [she]3998-her mistress was [the queerest and kindest little body]4002-the queerest and kindest little body ! At first [I]129-waymark helped [[her]3998-her mistress servant]4003-her servant in [the kitchen]3999-the kitchen , [she]3998-her mistress lived quite by [herself]3998-her mistress , with [one servant]4005-one servant , but little by little [she]3998-her mistress made [me]129-waymark [a sort of [lady]4007-lady 's maid]4006-a sort of lady 's maid , and [I]129-waymark did no more rough work . [You]4008-you would n't believe the ridiculous fancies of [that dear old woman]4009-that dear old woman ! [She]3998-her mistress thought [herself]3998-her mistress [a great beauty]4010-a great beauty , and often told [me]129-waymark so very plainly , and [she]3998-her mistress used to talk to [me]129-waymark about [her]3998-her mistress chances of being married to this and [the other person in [the neighbourhood]297-the neighbourhood]4011-the other person in the neighbourhood . And the result of all this was that [she]3998-her mistress had to spend [I]129-waymark do n't know how long every day in dressing [herself]3998-her mistress , and then looking at [herself]3998-her mistress in the glass . And [I]129-waymark had to learn how to do [her]3998-her mistress hair , and put paint and powder on [her]3998-her mistress face , and all sorts of wonderful things . [She]3998-her mistress was as good to [me]129-waymark as [she]3998-her mistress could be , and [I]129-waymark never wanted for anything . And so six years passed , and one morning [she]3998-her mistress was found dead in [her]3998-her mistress bed .[129-waymark]

" Well , that was the end of the happiest time of [my]129-waymark life . In a day or two [some relatives]4013-some relatives came to look after things , and [I]129-waymark had to go . [They]4013-some relatives were kind to [me]129-waymark , however ; [they]4013-some relatives gave [me]129-waymark money , and told [me]129-waymark [I]129-waymark might refer to [them]4013-some relatives if [I]129-waymark needed to . [I]129-waymark came to [London]3-london , and took [a room]561-a room , and wondered what [I]129-waymark should do .[129-waymark]

" [I]129-waymark advertised , and answered advertisements , but nothing came . [My]129-waymark money was going , and [I]129-waymark should soon be as badly off as ever . [I]129-waymark began to do what [I]129-waymark had always thought of as the very last thing , look for needlework , either for [home]3157-home or in [a workroom]559-a workroom . [I]129-waymark do n't know how it is that [I]129-waymark have always hated sewing . For one thing , [I]129-waymark really ca n't sew . [I]129-waymark was never taught as [a child]378-a child , and [few girls]4018-few girls are as clumsy with a needle as [I]129-waymark am . [I]129-waymark 've always looked upon [a work - girl]4019-a work - girl 's life as the most horrible drudgery ; [I]129-waymark 'd far rather scrub floors . [I]129-waymark suppose [I]129-waymark 've a rebellious disposition , and just because sewing is looked upon as [a woman]3216-a woman 's natural slavery , [I]129-waymark rebelled against it .[129-waymark]

" By this time [I]129-waymark was actually starving . [I]129-waymark had one day to tell [[my]129-waymark landlady]3391-my landlady [I]129-waymark could n't pay [my]129-waymark rent . [She]3391-my landlady was [a very decent woman]4022-a very decent woman , and [she]3391-my landlady talked to [me]129-waymark in a kind way . What was better , [she]3391-my landlady gave [me]129-waymark help . [She]3391-my landlady had [a sister who kept a laundry]4023-a sister who kept a laundry , and [she]3391-my landlady thought [I]129-waymark might perhaps get something to do [there]3249-there ; at all events [she]3391-my landlady would go and see . The result was [I]129-waymark got work . [I]129-waymark was in the laundry nearly six months , and became quite clever in getting up linen . Now this was a kind of work [I]129-waymark liked . [You]4025-you ca n't think what a pleasure it was to [me]129-waymark to see shirts and collars turning out so spotless and sweet "[129-waymark]

[Waymark]129-waymark laughed .

" Oh , but [you]4025-you do n't understand . [I]129-waymark do so like cleanliness ! [I]129-waymark have a sort of feeling when [I]129-waymark 'm washing anything , that [I]129-waymark 'm really doing good in [the world]622-the world , and the dazzling white of linen after [I]129-waymark 'd ironed it seemed to thank [me]129-waymark for [my]129-waymark work . "[129-waymark]

" Yes , yes , [I]129-waymark understand well enough , "[129-waymark] said [Waymark]129-waymark earnestly .

" For all that [I]1712-i could n't stay . [I]1712-i was restless . [I]1712-i had a foolish notion that [I]1712-i should like to be with [a better kind of people]4027-a better kind of people again [I]1712-i mean people in a higher position . [I]1712-i still kept answering advertisements for [[[a lady]3171-a lady 's maid]4029-a lady 's maid 's place]4030-a lady 's maid 's place , and at last [I]1712-i got what [I]1712-i wanted . Oh yes , [I]1712-i got it . "[1712-i]

[She]1712-i broke off ' laughing bitterly , and remained silent . [Waymark]129-waymark would not urge [her]1712-i to continue . For a minute it seemed as if [she]1712-i would tell no more ; [she]1712-i looked at [her]1712-i watch , and half arose .

" Oh , [I]1712-i may as well tell [you]4031-you all , now [I]1712-i 've begun , "[1712-i] [she]1712-i said , falling back again in a careless way . " [You]4031-you know what the end 's going to be ; never mind , at all events [I]1712-i 'll try and make [you]4031-you understand how it came .[1712-i]

" [The family [I]129-waymark got into]4032-the family i got into was [a lady]3171-a lady and [[her]3171-a lady two grown - up daughters]4034-her two grown - up daughters , and [a son of about five - and - twenty]4035-a son of about five - and - twenty . [They]4032-the family i got into lived in [a small house at [Shepherd 's Bush]65-shepherd 's bush]4036-a small house at shepherd 's bush . [My]129-waymark wages were very small , and [I]129-waymark soon found out that [they]4032-the family i got into were [a kind of people who keep up a great deal of show on very little means]4037-a kind of people who keep up a great deal of show on very little means . Of course [I]129-waymark had to be let into all the secrets of [their]4032-the family i got into miserable shifts for dressing well on next to nothing at all , and [they]4032-the family i got into expected [[me]129-waymark mother]4038-me mother and [daughters]4039-daughters to do the most wonderful and impossible things . [I]129-waymark had to turn old rags into smart new costumes , to trim worn - out hats into all manner of gaudy shapes , even to patch up boots in a way [you]4040-you could n't imagine . And [they]4032-the family i got into used to send [me]129-waymark with money to buy things [they]4032-the family i got into were ashamed to go and buy [themselves]4032-the family i got into ; then , if [I]129-waymark had n't laid out [their]4032-the family i got into few pence with marvellous result , [they]4032-the family i got into all but accused [me]129-waymark of having used some of the money for [myself]129-waymark . [I]129-waymark had fortunately learnt a great deal with [the old lady in [Tottenham]62-tottenham]4041-the old lady in tottenham , or [I]129-waymark could n't have satisfied [them]4032-the family i got into for a day . [I]129-waymark 'm sure [I]129-waymark did what [few people]3416-few people could have done , and for all that [they]4032-the family i got into treated [me]129-waymark from almost the first very badly . [I]129-waymark had to be [housemaid]4043-housemaid as well as [[lady]4007-lady 's maid]4045-lady 's maid ; the slavery left [me]129-waymark every night worn out with exhaustion . And [I]129-waymark had n't even enough to eat . As time went on , [they]4032-the family i got into treated [me]129-waymark worse and worse . [They]4032-the family i got into spoke to [me]129-waymark often in a way that made [my]129-waymark heart boil , as if [they]4032-the family i got into were [so many queens]4046-so many queens , and [I]129-waymark was [some poor mean wretch who was honoured by being allowed to toil for [them]4032-the family i got into]4047-some poor mean wretch who was honoured by being allowed to toil for them . Then [they]4032-the family i got into quarrelled among [themselves]4032-the family i got into unceasingly , and of course [I]129-waymark had to bear all the bad temper . [I]129-waymark never saw [people]3402-people hate [one another]257-one another like [those three]4050-those three did ; [the sisters]4051-the sisters even scratched [each other]459-each other 's faces in [their]4051-the sisters fits of jealousy , and sometimes [they]4032-the family i got into both stormed at [[their]4032-the family i got into mother]1069-their mother till [she]1069-their mother went into hysterics , just because [she]1069-their mother could n't give [them]4032-the family i got into more money . [The only one in [the house]288-the house who ever spoke decently to [me]129-waymark]4054-the only one in the house who ever spoke decently to me was [the son [Alfred Bolter]198-alfred bolter]4056-the son alfred bolter , [his]4056-the son alfred bolter name was . [I]129-waymark suppose [I]129-waymark felt grateful to [him]4056-the son alfred bolter . Once or twice , when [he]4056-the son alfred bolter met [me]129-waymark on the stairs , [he]4056-the son alfred bolter kissed [me]129-waymark . [I]129-waymark was too miserable even to resent it .[129-waymark]

" [I]1712-i went about , day after day , in a dazed state , trying to make up [my]1712-i mind to leave [the people]3247-the people , but [I]1712-i could n't . [I]1712-i do n't know how it was , [I]1712-i had never felt so afraid of being thrown out into [the world]622-the world again . [I]1712-i suppose it was bodily weakness , want of proper food , and overwork . [I]1712-i began to feel that [the whole world]4059-the whole world was wronging [me]1712-i . Was there never to be anything for [me]1712-i but slaving ? Was [I]1712-i never to have any enjoyment of life , like [other people]4060-other people ? [I]1712-i felt a need of pleasure , [I]1712-i did n't care how or what . [I]1712-i was always in a fever ; everything was exaggerated to [me]1712-i . What was going to be [my]1712-i future ? [I]1712-i kept asking [myself]1712-i . Was it only to be hard work , miserably paid , till [I]1712-i died ? And [I]1712-i should die at last without having known what it was to enjoy [my]1712-i life . When [I]1712-i was allowed to go out it was very seldom [I]1712-i walked aimlessly about [the streets]3169-the streets , watching [all the girls [I]1712-i passed]4062-all the girls i passed , and fancying [they]4062-all the girls i passed all looked so happy , all enjoying [their]4062-all the girls i passed life so . [I]1712-i was growing thin and pale . [I]1712-i coughed , and began to think [I]1712-i was consumptive . A little more of it and [I]1712-i believe [I]1712-i should have become so really .[1712-i]

" It came to an end , suddenly and unexpectedly . [All three]1612-all three , [mother]375-mother and [daughters]4039-daughters , had been worrying [me]129-waymark through a whole morning , and at last one of [them]1612-all three called [me]129-waymark [a downright fool]4066-a downright fool , and said [I]129-waymark was n't worth the bread [I]129-waymark ate . [I]129-waymark turned on [them]1612-all three . [I]129-waymark ca n't remember a word [I]129-waymark said , but speak [I]129-waymark did , and in a way that astonished [them]1612-all three ; [they]1612-all three shrank back from [me]129-waymark , looking pale and frightened . [I]129-waymark felt in that moment that [I]129-waymark was a thousand times [[their]1612-all three superior]4067-their superior ; [I]129-waymark believe [I]129-waymark told [them]1612-all three so . Then [I]129-waymark rushed up to [[my]129-waymark room]3634-my room , packed [my]129-waymark box , and went out into [the street]340-the street .[129-waymark]

" [I]1712-i had just turned a corner , when [some one]3153-some one came up to [me]1712-i , and it was [Mr. Bolter]199-mr. bolter . [He]199-mr. bolter had followed [me]1712-i from [the house]288-the house . [He]199-mr. bolter laughed , said [I]1712-i had done quite right , and asked [me]1712-i if [I]1712-i had any money . [I]1712-i shook [my]1712-i head . [He]199-mr. bolter walked on by [me]1712-i , and talked . The end was , that [he]199-mr. bolter found [me]1712-i rooms , and provided for [me]1712-i .[1712-i]

" [I]129-waymark had not the least affection for [him]199-mr. bolter , but [he]199-mr. bolter had pleasant , gentlemanly ways , and it scarcely even occurred to [me]129-waymark to refuse [his]199-mr. bolter offers . [I]129-waymark was reckless ; what happened to [me]129-waymark mattered little , as long as [I]129-waymark had not to face hard work . [I]129-waymark needed rest . For one in [my]129-waymark position there was , [I]129-waymark saw well enough , only one way of getting it . [I]129-waymark took that way . "[129-waymark]

[Ida]101-ida had told this in a straightforward , unhesitating manner , not meeting [[her]101-ida companion]1082-her companion 's gaze , yet not turning away . [One]318-one would have said that judgments upon [her]101-ida story were indifferent to [her]101-ida ; [she]101-ida simply related past events . In a moment , [she]101-ida resumed .

" Do [you]129-waymark remember , on the night when [you]129-waymark first met [me]101-ida , [a man following [us]4073-we in [the street]340-the street]4072-a man following us in the street ? "[101-ida]

[Waymark]129-waymark nodded .

" [He]4072-a man following us in the street was [a friend of [Alfred Bolter]198-alfred bolter 's]4075-a friend of alfred bolter 's , and sometimes [we]4073-we met [him]4072-a man following us in the street when [we]4073-we went to [the theatre]1025-the theatre , and such places . That is [the only person [I]101-ida ever hated]4077-the only person i ever hated from the first sight , hated and dreaded in a way [I]101-ida could not possibly explain . "[101-ida]

" But why do [you]101-ida mention [him]4072-a man following us in the street ? "[129-waymark] asked [Waymark]129-waymark . " What is [his]4072-a man following us in the street name ? "[129-waymark]

" [His]4072-a man following us in the street name is [Edwards]200-edwards , "[101-ida] returned [Ida]101-ida , pronouncing it as if the sound excited loathing in [her]101-ida . " [I]101-ida had been living in this way for nearly half - a - year , when one day [this man]4078-this man called and came up to [[my]101-ida sitting - room]3158-my sitting - room . [He]4078-this man said [he]4078-this man had an appointment with [Mr. Bolter]199-mr. bolter , who would come presently . [I]101-ida sat scarcely speaking , but [he]4078-this man talked on . Presently , [Mr. Bolter]199-mr. bolter came . [He]199-mr. bolter seemed surprised to find [the other man]4080-the other man with [me]101-ida , and almost at once turned round and went out again . [Edwards]200-edwards followed [him]199-mr. bolter , saying to [me]101-ida that [he]200-edwards wondered what it all meant . The meaning was made clear to [me]101-ida a few hours after . There came a short note from [Mr. Bolter]199-mr. bolter , saying that [he]1715-he had suspected that something was wrong , and that under the circumstances [he]1715-he could of course only say good - bye .[101-ida]

[I]0-i ca n't say that [I]0-i was sorry ; [I]0-i ca n't say that [I]0-i was glad . [I]0-i despised [him]1715-he for [his]1715-he meanness , not even troubling [myself]0-i to try and make sure of what had happened . The same night [Edwards]200-edwards came to see [me]0-i again , made excuses , blamed [[his]200-edwards friend]876-his friend , shuffled here and there , and gave [me]0-i clearly to understand what [he]200-edwards wanted . [I]0-i scarcely spoke , only told [him]200-edwards to go away , and that [he]200-edwards need never speak to [me]0-i anywhere or at any time ; it would be useless . Well , [I]0-i changed [[my]0-i lodgings]1717-my lodgings for those [I]0-i now have , and simply began the life [I]0-i now the life [I]0-i have been leading . Work was more impossible for [me]0-i than ever , and [I]0-i had to feed and clothe [myself]0-i . "[0-i]

" How long ago was that ? "[129-waymark] asked [Waymark]129-waymark , without looking up .

" Four months . "[0-i]

[Ida]101-ida rose from [the beach]1718-the beach . The tide had gone down some distance ; there were stretches of smooth sand , already dry in the sunshine .

" Let [us]4081-us walk back on [the sands]4082-the sands , "[101-ida] [she]101-ida said , pointing .

" [You]129-waymark are going [home]3157-home ? "[101-ida]

" Yes , [I]101-ida want to rest a little . [I]101-ida will meet [you]129-waymark again about eight o'clock , if [you]129-waymark like . "[101-ida]

[Waymark]129-waymark accompanied [her]101-ida as far as the door , then strolled on to [[his]129-waymark own lodgings]1719-his own lodgings , which were near at hand . It was only the second day that [they]1720-they had been in [Hastings]12-hastings , yet it seemed to [him]129-waymark as if [he]129-waymark had been walking about on [the seashore]1721-the seashore with [Ida]101-ida for weeks . For all that , [he]129-waymark felt that [he]129-waymark was not as near to [her]101-ida now as [he]129-waymark had been on certain evenings in [London]3-london , when [his]129-waymark arrival was to [her]101-ida a manifest pleasure , and [their]1720-they talk unflagging from hour to hour . [She]101-ida did not show the spirit of holiday , seemed weary from time to time , was too often preoccupied and indisposed to talk . True , [she]101-ida had at length fulfilled [her]101-ida promise of telling [him]129-waymark the whole of [her]101-ida story , but even this increase of confidence [Waymark]129-waymark 's uneasy mind strangely converted into fresh source of discomfort to [himself]129-waymark . [She]101-ida had made this revelation [he]129-waymark half believed on purpose to keep up the distance between [them]1720-they , to warn [him]129-waymark how slight occasion had led [her]101-ida from what is called the path of virtue , that [he]129-waymark might not delude [himself]129-waymark into exaggerated estimates of [her]101-ida character . Such a thought could of course only be due to the fact that [Ida]101-ida 's story had indeed produced something of this impression upon [[her]101-ida hearer]1722-her hearer . [Waymark]129-waymark had often busied [himself]129-waymark with inventing all manner of excuses for [her]101-ida , had exerted [his]129-waymark imagination to the utmost to hit upon some most irresistible climax of dolorous circumstances to account for [her]101-ida downfall . [He]129-waymark had yet to realise that circumstances are as relative in their importance as everything else in [this world]3446-this world , and that ofttimes the greatest tragedies revolve on apparently the most insignificant outward events personality being all .

[He]129-waymark spent the hours of [her]101-ida absence in moving from place to place , fretting in mind . At one moment , [he]129-waymark half determined to bring things to some issue , by disregarding all considerations and urging [his]129-waymark love upon [her]101-ida . Yet this [he]129-waymark felt [he]129-waymark could not do . Surely [he]129-waymark asked [himself]129-waymark angrily [he]129-waymark was not still so much in the thraldom of conventionality as to be affected by [his]129-waymark fresh reminder of [her]101-ida position and antecedents ? Perhaps not quite so much prejudice as experience which disturbed [him]129-waymark . [He]129-waymark was well acquainted with the characteristics of [girls of this class]1724-girls of this class ; [he]129-waymark knew how all but impossible it is for [them]1724-girls of this class to tell the truth , the whole truth , and nothing but the truth . And there was one thing particularly in [Ida]101-ida 's story that [he]129-waymark found hard to credit ; was it indeed likely that [she]101-ida had not felt more than [she]101-ida would confess for [this man whose mistress [she]101-ida became so easily]1725-this man whose mistress she became so easily ? If [she]101-ida had not , if what [she]101-ida said were true , was not this something like a proof of [her]101-ida lack of that refined sentiment which is , the capacity for love , in its real sense ? Torturing doubts and reasonings of this kind once set going in a brain already confused with passion , there is no limit to the range of speculation opened ; [Waymark]129-waymark found [himself]129-waymark in spite of everything entertaining all [his]129-waymark old scepticism . In any case , had [he]129-waymark the slightest ground for the hope that [she]101-ida might ever feel to [him]129-waymark as warmly as [he]129-waymark did to [her]101-ida ? [He]129-waymark could not recall one instance of [Ida]101-ida 's having betrayed a trace of fondness in [her]101-ida intercourse with [him]129-waymark . The mere fact of [their]1726-their intercourse [he]129-waymark altogether lost sight of . Whereas [an outsider]1727-an outsider would , under the circumstances , have been justified in laying the utmost stress on this , [Waymark]129-waymark had grown to accept it as a matter of course , and only occupied [himself]129-waymark with [Ida]101-ida 's absolute self - control , [her]101-ida perfect calmness in all situations , the ease with which [she]101-ida met [his]129-waymark glance , the looseness of [her]101-ida hand in [his]129-waymark , the indifference with which [she]101-ida heard [him]129-waymark when [he]129-waymark had spoken of [his]129-waymark loneliness and frequent misery . Where was the key of [her]101-ida character ? [She]101-ida did not care for admiration ; it was quite certain that [she]101-ida was not leading [him]129-waymark about just to gratify [her]101-ida own vanity . Was it not purely an intellectual matter ? [She]101-ida was [a girl of superior intellect]1728-a girl of superior intellect , and , having found in [him]129-waymark some one with whom [she]101-ida could satisfy [her]101-ida desire for rational converse , did [she]101-ida not on this account keep up [their]1729-their relations ? For the rest well , [she]101-ida liked ease and luxury ; above all , ease . Of that [she]101-ida would certainly make no sacrifice . How well [he]129-waymark could imagine the half - annoyed , half - contemptuous smile which would rise to [her]101-ida beautiful face , if [he]129-waymark were so foolish as to become sentimental with [her]101-ida ! That , [he]129-waymark felt , would be a look not easy to bear . Humiliation [he]129-waymark dreaded .

When eight o'clock came , [he]129-waymark was leaning over the end of [the pier]1606-the pier , at the appointed spot , still busy in thought . There came a touch on [his]129-waymark arm .

" Well , are [you]101-ida thinking how [you]101-ida can make a book out of [my]129-waymark story ? "[129-waymark]

The touch , the voice , the smile , how all [his]129-waymark sophistry was swept away in a rush of tenderness and delight !

" [I]129-waymark must wait for the end of it , "[129-waymark] [he]129-waymark returned , holding out [his]129-waymark hand , which [she]101-ida did not take .

" The end ? Oh , [you]101-ida must invent one . Ends in real life are so commonplace and uninteresting . "[129-waymark]

" Commonplace or not , "[129-waymark] said [Waymark]129-waymark , with some lack of firmness in [his]129-waymark voice , " the end of [your]101-ida story should not be an unhappy one , if [I]129-waymark had the disposing of it . And [I]129-waymark might have but for one thing . "[129-waymark]

" What 's that ? "[101-ida] [she]101-ida asked , with sudden interest .

" [My]101-ida miserable poverty . If [I]101-ida only had money money "[101-ida]

" Money ! "[101-ida] [she]101-ida exclaimed , turning away almost angrily . Then [she]101-ida added , with the coldness which [she]101-ida did not often use , but which , when [she]101-ida did , chilled and checked [him]129-waymark " [I]101-ida do n't understand [you]101-ida . "[101-ida]

[He]129-waymark pointed with a bitter smile down to [the sands]4082-the sands .

" Look at that gold of the sunset in the pools the tide has left . It is the most glorious colour in nature , but it makes [me]129-waymark miserable by reminding [me]129-waymark of the metal it takes its name from . "[129-waymark]

[She]101-ida looked at [him]129-waymark with eyes which had in [them]1732-them a strange wonder , sad at first , then full of scorn , of indignation . And then [she]101-ida laughed , drawing [herself]101-ida away from [him]129-waymark . The laugh irritated [him]129-waymark . [He]129-waymark experienced a terrible revulsion of feeling , from the warmth and passion which had possessed [him]129-waymark , to that humiliation , which [he]129-waymark could not bear .

And just now [a number of [people]3402-people]1733-a number of people came and took [their]1733-a number of people stands close by , in [a gossiping group]1735-a gossiping group . [Ida]101-ida had half turned away , and was looking at [the golden pools]1736-the golden pools . [He]129-waymark tried to say something , but [his]129-waymark tongue was dry , and the word would not come . Presently , [she]101-ida faced [him]129-waymark again , and said , in very much [her]101-ida ordinary tone

" [I]101-ida was going to tell [you]129-waymark that [I]101-ida have just had news from [London]3-london , which makes it necessary for [me]101-ida to go back to - morrow . [I]101-ida shall have to take [an early train]4084-an early train . "[101-ida]

" This is because [I]129-waymark have offended [you]101-ida , "[129-waymark] [Waymark]129-waymark said , moving nearer to [her]101-ida . " [You]101-ida had no thought of going before that . "[129-waymark]

" [I]101-ida am not surprised that [you]129-waymark refuse to believe [me]101-ida , "[101-ida] returned [Ida]101-ida , smiling very faintly . " Still , it is the truth . And now [I]101-ida must go in again ; [I]101-ida am very tired . "[101-ida]

" No , "[129-waymark] [he]129-waymark exclaimed as [she]101-ida moved away , " [you]101-ida must not go in till till [you]101-ida have forgotten [me]129-waymark . At least come away to a quiet place , where [I]129-waymark can speak freely to [you]101-ida ; [these people]4085-these people "[129-waymark]

" To - morrow morning , "[101-ida] [she]101-ida said , waving [her]101-ida hand wearily . " [I]101-ida ca n't talk now and indeed there is no need to speak of this at all . [I]101-ida have forgotten it . "[101-ida]

" No , [you]101-ida have not ; how could [you]101-ida ? And [you]101-ida will not go to - morrow ; [you]101-ida shall not . "[101-ida]

" Yes , [I]101-ida must , "[101-ida] [she]101-ida returned firmly .

" Then [I]101-ida shall go with [you]129-waymark . "[101-ida]

" As [you]129-waymark like . [I]101-ida shall leave by the express at five minutes past nine . "[101-ida]

" Then [I]101-ida shall be at [the station]4086-the station . But at least [I]101-ida may walk [home]3157-home with [you]129-waymark ? "[101-ida]

" No , please . If [you]129-waymark wish [me]101-ida to think [you]129-waymark are sincere , if [you]129-waymark wish [us]4088-us still to be [friends]562-friends stay till [I]101-ida have left [the pier]1606-the pier . Good night . "[101-ida]

[He]1737-he muttered a return , and stood watching [her]101-ida as [she]101-ida walked quietly away .

When it was nearly midnight , [Ida]101-ida lay on [her]101-ida bed , dressed , as [she]101-ida had lain since [her]101-ida return [home]3157-home . For more than an hour [she]101-ida had cried and sobbed in blank misery , cried as never since the bitter days long ago , just after [[her]101-ida mother]377-her mother 's death . Then , the fit over , something like a reaction of calm followed , and as [she]101-ida lay perfectly still in the darkness , [her]101-ida regular breathing would have led [one]318-one to believe [her]101-ida asleep . But [she]101-ida was only thinking , and in deed very far from sleep The long day in the open air had so affected [her]101-ida eyes that , as [she]101-ida looked up at the ceiling , it seemed to [her]101-ida to be a blue space , with light clouds constantly flitting across [it]1741-it . Presently this impression became painful , and a growing restlessness made [her]101-ida rise . The heat of [the room]255-the room was stifling , for just above was the roof , upon which all day the sun had poured its rays . [She]101-ida threw open the window , and drank in the air . The night was magnificent , flooded with warm moonlight , and fragrant with sea breathings . [Ida]101-ida felt an irresistible desire to leave [the house]288-the house and go down to [the shore]1697-the shore , which [she]101-ida could not see from [her]101-ida window ; the tide , [she]101-ida remembered , would just now be full , and to walk by [it]1745-it in the solitude of midnight would bring [her]101-ida that peace and strength of soul [she]101-ida so much needed . [She]101-ida put on [her]101-ida hat and cloak , and went [downstairs]445-downstairs . The front door was only latched , and , as [she]101-ida had [her]101-ida key , no doubt [she]101-ida would be able to let [herself]101-ida in at any hour .

[The streets]3169-the streets were all but deserted , and , when [she]101-ida came to [the beach]1718-the beach , [no soul]1749-no soul was anywhere visible . [She]101-ida walked towards [the place where [she]101-ida had spent the afternoon with [Waymark]129-waymark , then onwards still further to the east]1750-the place where she had spent the afternoon with waymark , then onwards still further to the east , till there was but [a narrow space between [the water]1752-the water and [the cliffs]1753-the cliffs]1751-a narrow space between the water and the cliffs . [Breakers]201-breakers there were none , not more ripple at the clear tide - edge than on the border of [a little lake]1754-a little lake . So intense was the silence that every now and then could be distinctly heard a call on [one of the fishing - boats lying some distance from [shore]1756-shore]1755-one of the fishing - boats lying some distance from shore . [The town]1023-the town was no longer in sight .

[It]1023-the town was close even here ; what little breeze there was brushed the face like the warm wing of a passing bird . [Ida]101-ida dipped [her]101-ida hands in the water and sprinkled it upon [her]101-ida forehead . Then [she]101-ida took off [her]101-ida boots and stockings , and walked with [her]101-ida feet in the ripples . A moment after [she]101-ida stopped , and looked all around , as if hesitating at some thought , and wishing to see that [her]101-ida solitude was secure . Just then the sound of a clock came very faintly across the still air , striking the hour of one . [She]101-ida stepped from [the water]1752-the water a few paces , and began hastily to put off [her]101-ida clothing ; in a moment [her]101-ida feet were again in the ripples , and [she]101-ida was walking out from [the beach]1718-the beach , till [her]101-ida gleaming body was hidden . Then [she]101-ida bathed , breasting the full flow with delight , making the sundered and broken water flash myriad reflections of the moon and stars .

[Waymark]129-waymark was at [the station]4086-the station next morning half an hour before train - time . [He]129-waymark waited for [Ida]101-ida 's arrival before taking [his]129-waymark ticket . [She]101-ida did not come . [He]129-waymark walked about in feverish impatience , plaguing [himself]129-waymark with all manner of doubt and apprehension . [The train]1761-the train came into [the station]4086-the station , and yet [she]101-ida had not arrived . [It]1761-the train started , and no sign of [her]101-ida .

[He]129-waymark waited yet five minutes , then walked hastily into [the town]1023-the town , and to [[Ida]101-ida 's lodgings]1764-ida 's lodgings . [Miss Starr]189-miss starr , [he]129-waymark was told , had left very early that morning ; if [he]129-waymark was [Mr. Waymark]130-waymark , there was a note to be delivered to [him]129-waymark .

" [I]1765-i thought it better that [I]1765-i should go to [London]3-london by [an earlier train]4091-an earlier train , for [we]4092-we should not have been quite at [our]4092-we ease with [each other]459-each other . [I]1765-i beg [you]4094-you will not think [my]1765-i leaving [you]4094-you is due to anything but necessity indeed it is not . [I]1765-i shall not be living at [the old place]3850-the old place , but any letter [you]4094-you send [there]3249-there [I]1765-i shall get . [I]1765-i can not promise to reply at once , but hope [you]4094-you will let [me]1765-i do so when [I]1765-i feel able to .[1765-i]

[I.]1765-i S. "[1765-i]

[Waymark]130-waymark took [the next train]1766-the next train to [town]901-town .

CHAPTER XVIII

[THE ENDERBYS]202-the enderbys

Some twenty years before the date [we]1768-we have reached , [the Rev. Paul Enderby]203-paul , [a handsome young man , endowed with moral and intellectual qualities considerably above the average]1769-a handsome young man , endowed with moral and intellectual qualities considerably above the average , lived and worked in [a certain small town of [Yorkshire]66-yorkshire]1770-a certain small town of yorkshire .

[He]203-paul had been [here]3335-here for two years , [an unmarried man]1772-an unmarried man ; now it was made known that this state of things was to come to an end ; moreover , to the disappointment of [not a few households]1773-not a few households , it was understood that the future [Mrs. Enderby]204-mrs. enderby had been chosen from among [[his]203-paul own people]1774-his own people , in [London]3-london . [The lady]262-the lady came , and there was a field - day of criticism . [Mrs. Enderby]204-mrs. enderby looked very young , and was undeniably pretty ; [she]204-mrs. enderby had accomplishments , and evidently liked to exhibit them before [[her]204-mrs. enderby homely visitors]1776-her homely visitors . [She]204-mrs. enderby exaggerated the refinement of [her]204-mrs. enderby utterance that it might all the more strike off against the local accent . It soon became clear that [she]204-mrs. enderby would be anything but an assistance to [[her]204-mrs. enderby husband]584-her husband in [his]584-her husband parochial work ; one or two attempts were made , apparently with good will , at intercourse with [the poor parishioners]1778-the poor parishioners , but the enterprise was distinctly a failure ; it had to be definitively given up . Presently [a child]378-a child was born in [the parsonage]1780-the parsonage , and for a little while [the young mother]1781-the young mother 's attention was satisfactorily engaged at [home]3157-home . [The child]320-the child was [a girl]469-a girl and received the name of [Maud]103-maud .

[Paul Enderby]203-paul struggled to bate no jot of [his]203-paul former activity , but a change was obvious to all . No less obvious the reason of it . [Mrs. Enderby]204-mrs. enderby 's reckless extravagance had soon involved [[her]204-mrs. enderby husband]584-her husband in great difficulties . [He]203-paul was growing haggard ; [his]203-paul health was failing ; [his]203-paul activity shrank within the narrowest possible limits ; [he]203-paul shunned [men]3195-men 's gaze .

Yet all at once there happened something which revived much of [his]203-paul old zeal , and , in spite of everything , brought [him]203-paul once more prominently forward . A calamity had visited [the town]1023-the town . By a great explosion in [a neighbouring colliery]1788-a neighbouring colliery , numbers of [homes]1789-homes had been rendered destitute , and aid of every kind was imperatively called for on all sides . In former times , [Paul Enderby]203-paul would have been just [the man]491-the man for this occasion , and even now [he]203-paul was not wanting . Extensive subscriptions were raised , and [he]203-paul , as [chief man in the committee which had been formed]1791-chief man in the committee which had been formed , had chief control of the funds . [People]3402-people said afterwards that [they]3402-people had often remarked something singular in [his]203-paul manner as [he]203-paul went about in these duties . Whether that was true or not , something more than singular happened when , some two months later , accounts were being investigated and cleared up . Late one evening , [Mr. Enderby]205-mr. enderby left [home]3157-home , and never returned to [it]3157-home . It was very soon known that [he]205-mr. enderby must have appropriated to [his]205-mr. enderby own use considerable sums which had reached [his]205-mr. enderby hands for charitable purposes , and the scandal was terrific . [Mrs. Enderby]204-mrs. enderby and [[her]204-mrs. enderby child]524-her child disappeared in a day or two . It was said that [ladies from [London]3-london]1795-ladies from london had come and fetched [her]204-mrs. enderby away , and [she]204-mrs. enderby was no more heard of in [that little town]1796-that little town .

[Miss Bygrave]121-miss bygrave , [an elder sister of [Mrs. Enderby]204-mrs. enderby]1797-an elder sister of mrs. enderby , had received a letter from [Paul]203-paul summoning [her]121-miss bygrave to [the wife]1798-the wife 's aid : and this letter , dated from [Liverpool]67-liverpool , after disclosing in a few words the whole situation , went on to say that [the writer]833-the writer , though [he]833-the writer would never more be seen by [those who knew [him]833-the writer]1800-those who knew him , would not fail to send [[his]833-the writer wife]505-his wife what money [he]833-the writer could as often as [he]833-the writer could . And , after half a year , sums had begun to be remitted , in envelopes bearing a Californian postmark . They were not much use , however , to [Mrs. Enderby]204-mrs. enderby . A few days after [her]204-mrs. enderby arrival at [[her]204-mrs. enderby home in [London]3-london]1802-her home in london , [she]204-mrs. enderby had been discovered hanging , with a rope round [her]204-mrs. enderby neck , from a nail behind [her]204-mrs. enderby bedroom door . Cut down in time , [her]204-mrs. enderby life was saved , but reason had forsaken [her]204-mrs. enderby . [She]204-mrs. enderby was taken away to [an asylum]1803-an asylum , and remained [there]3249-there for five years .

By that time , [she]204-mrs. enderby seemed to have quite recovered . [[Her]204-mrs. enderby home]379-her home was now to be with [[her]204-mrs. enderby sister]1806-her sister , [Theresa Bygrave]206-theresa . [[Her]204-mrs. enderby child]524-her child , [Maud Enderby]103-maud , was nearly seven years old . [Mrs. Enderby]204-mrs. enderby returned to [the world]622-the world not quite [the same woman]1809-the same woman as when [she]204-mrs. enderby left [it]622-the world . [She]204-mrs. enderby had never lacked character , and this now showed itself in one immutable resolution . Having found that [the child]320-the child had learnt nothing of [its parents]1811-its parents , [she]204-mrs. enderby determined that this ignorance should continue ; or rather that it should be exchanged for the belief that [those parents]1812-those parents were both long dead . [She]204-mrs. enderby dwelt apart , supported by [[her]204-mrs. enderby sister]1806-her sister . Finally , after ten years ' absence , [Paul Enderby]203-paul returned to [England]15-england , and lived again with [[his]203-paul wife]505-his wife . But [Maud]103-maud , [[their]1815-their daughter]1816-their daughter , still believed [herself]103-maud alone in [the world]622-the world , save for [[her]103-maud aunt]737-her aunt , [Miss Bygrave]121-miss bygrave .

At the time when [Waymark]130-waymark and [Ida]101-ida were together at [Hastings]12-hastings , [Mrs. Enderby]204-mrs. enderby called one evening at [[Miss Bygrave]121-miss bygrave 's house]1819-miss bygrave 's house [the house of [Maud]103-maud 's childhood]1820-the house of maud 's childhood , still distinguished by the same coldness , bareness and gloom , the same silence echoing to a strange footfall . [Theresa Bygrave]206-theresa had not greatly altered ; tall , upright , clad in the plainest black garment , [she]206-theresa walked into [the room]255-the room with silent dignity , and listened to a suggestion made by [[her]206-theresa brother - in - law]1822-her brother - in - law .

" [We]4097-we have talked it over again , "[203-paul] said [Paul]203-paul , " and [we]4097-we have decided to take this step . "[203-paul]

[He]203-paul paused and watched [the listener]1823-the listener 's face eagerly , glancing quickly away as soon as [she]1823-the listener looked up .

" And [you]203-paul still wish [me]203-paul to break it to [Maud]103-maud , and in the way [you]203-paul said ? "[203-paul]

" If [you]203-paul will . But [I]203-paul do so wish [you]203-paul would let [me]203-paul know [your]203-paul own thoughts about this . [You]203-paul have so much claim to be considered . [Maud]103-maud is in reality [yours]203-paul far more than [she]103-maud is [ours]4097-we . Will it do [you]203-paul think now it will really be for [our]4097-we own happiness ? Will the explanation [you]203-paul are able to give be satisfactory to [her]103-maud ? What will be [her]103-maud attitude towards [us]4097-we ? [You]203-paul know [her]103-maud character [you]203-paul understand [her]103-maud . "[203-paul]

" If the future could be all as calm as the past year has been , "[121-miss bygrave] said [Miss Bygrave]121-miss bygrave , " [I]121-miss bygrave should have nothing to urge against [your]204-mrs. enderby wishes . "[121-miss bygrave]

" And this will contribute to it , "[204-mrs. enderby] exclaimed [Enderby]204-mrs. enderby . " This would give [Emily]207-emily the very support [she]207-emily needs . "[204-mrs. enderby]

[Miss Bygrave]121-miss bygrave looked into [his]1824-his face , which had a pleading earnestness , and a deep pity lay in [her]121-miss bygrave eyes .

" Let it be so , "[121-miss bygrave] [she]121-miss bygrave said with decision . " [I]121-miss bygrave [myself]121-miss bygrave have much hope from [Maud]103-maud 's influence . [I]121-miss bygrave will write and tell [her]207-emily not to renew [her]207-emily engagement , and [she]207-emily will be with [us]4098-us at the end of September . "[121-miss bygrave]

" But [you]121-miss bygrave will not tell [her]207-emily anything till [she]207-emily comes ? "[121-miss bygrave]

" No . "[121-miss bygrave]

[Miss Bygrave]121-miss bygrave lived in all but complete severance from [the world]622-the world . When [Maud Enderby]103-maud was at [school]306-school , [she]121-miss bygrave felt strongly and painfully the contrast between [her]121-miss bygrave own home life and that of [[her]121-miss bygrave companions]322-her companions . [The girl]316-the girl withdrew into solitary reading and thinking ; grew ever more afraid of [the world]622-the world ; and by degrees sought more of [[her]316-the girl aunt]737-her aunt 's confidence , feeling that here was a soul that had long since attained to the peace which [she]121-miss bygrave was vainly seeking .

But it was with effort that [Miss Bygrave]121-miss bygrave brought [herself]121-miss bygrave to speak to another of [her]121-miss bygrave form of faith . After that Christmas night when [she]121-miss bygrave addressed [Maud]103-maud for the first time on matters of religion , [she]121-miss bygrave had said no second word ; [she]121-miss bygrave waited the effect of [her]121-miss bygrave teaching , and [the girl]316-the girl 's spontaneous recurrence to the subject . There was something in the very air of [the still , chill house]1832-the still , chill house favourable to [ascetic gravity]1833-ascetic gravity . [A young girl , living under such circumstances]1834-a young girl , living under such circumstances , must either pine away , eating [her]121-miss bygrave own heart , or become [a mystic]1835-a mystic , and find [her]121-miss bygrave daily food in religious meditation .

Only when [[her]121-miss bygrave niece]1836-her niece was seventeen years old did [Miss Bygrave]121-miss bygrave speak to [her]1836-her niece of worldly affairs . [Her]121-miss bygrave own income , [she]121-miss bygrave explained , was but just sufficient for [their]1837-their needs , and would terminate upon [her]121-miss bygrave death ; had [Maud]103-maud thought at all of what course [she]103-maud would choose when the time for decision came ? Naturally , only one thing could suggest itself to [the girl]316-the girl 's mind , and that was to become [a teacher]589-a teacher . To begin with , [she]121-miss bygrave took subordinate work in [the school where [she]121-miss bygrave had been [a pupil]1841-a pupil]1840-the school where she had been a pupil ; later , [she]121-miss bygrave obtained the engagement at [Dr. Tootle 's]141-dr. tootle .

An education of this kind , working upon [Maud Enderby]103-maud 's natural temperament , resulted in an abnormal character , the chief trait of which was remarkable as being in contradiction to the spirit of [her]103-maud time . [She]103-maud was oppressed with the consciousness of sin . Every most natural impulse of [her]103-maud own heart [she]103-maud regarded as a temptation to be resisted with all [her]103-maud strength . [Her]103-maud ideal was the same as [Miss Bygrave]121-miss bygrave 's , but [she]103-maud could not pursue it with [the latter]425-the latter 's assured calm ; at every moment the voice of [her]103-maud youth spoke within [her]103-maud , and became to [her]103-maud the voice of [the enemy]1843-the enemy . [Her]103-maud faith was scarcely capable of formulation in creeds ; [her]103-maud sins were not of omission or commission in the literal sense ; it was an attitude of soul which [she]103-maud sought to attain , though ever falling away . What little [she]103-maud saw of [the world]622-the world in [London]3-london , and afterwards at [[her]103-maud home]379-her home by [the sea - side]1846-the sea - side , only served to increase the trouble of [her]103-maud conscience , by making [her]103-maud more aware of [her]103-maud own weakness . For instance , the matter of [her]103-maud correspondence with [Waymark]130-waymark . In very truth , the chief reason why [she]103-maud had given [him]130-waymark the permission [he]130-waymark asked of [her]103-maud was , that before so sudden and unexpected a demand [she]103-maud found [herself]103-maud confused and helpless ; had [she]103-maud been able to reflect , the temptation would probably have been resisted , for the pleasantness of the thought made [her]103-maud regard it as a grave temptation . Casuistry and sophistical reasoning with [her]103-maud own heart ensued , to the increase of [her]103-maud morbid sensitiveness ; [she]103-maud persuaded [herself]103-maud that greater insight into [the world]622-the world 's evil would be of aid in [her]103-maud struggle , and so the contents of [Waymark]130-waymark 's first letter led [her]103-maud to a continuance of the correspondence . A power of strong and gloomy description which [she]103-maud showed in [her]103-maud letters , and which impressed [Waymark]130-waymark , afforded the key to [her]103-maud sufferings ; [her]103-maud soul in reality was that of [an artist]1848-an artist , and , whereas [the artist]3782-the artist should be free from everything like moral prepossession , [Maud]103-maud 's aesthetic sensibilities were in perpetual conflict with [her]103-maud moral convictions . [She]103-maud could not understand [herself]103-maud , seeing that [her]103-maud opportunities had never allowed [her]103-maud to obtain an idea of the artistic character . This irrepressible delight and interest in the active life of [the world]622-the world , what could it be but the tendency to evil , most strongly developed ? These heart - burnings whenever [she]103-maud witnessed [men]3195-men and [women]3771-women rejoicing in the exercise of [their]1853-their natural affections , what could that be but the proneness to evil in its grossest form ?

It was naturally a great surprise to [Maud]103-maud when [she]103-maud received the letter from [[her]103-maud aunt]737-her aunt , which asked [her]103-maud not to continue [her]103-maud engagement into [the new quarter]1855-the new quarter , giving as a reason merely that [the writer]833-the writer wished for [her]103-maud at [home]3157-home . It was even with something of dread and shrinking that [she]103-maud looked forward to a renewal of the old life . Still , it was enough that [[her]103-maud aunt]737-her aunt had need of [her]103-maud . On [her]103-maud return to [London]3-london , [she]103-maud was met with strange revelations . [Miss Bygrave]121-miss bygrave 's story had been agreed upon between [herself]103-maud and [Paul]203-paul . It had been deemed best to make [Mrs. Enderby]204-mrs. enderby 's insanity the explanation of [Maud]103-maud 's removal from [[her]103-maud parents]511-her parents , and [the girl]316-the girl , stricken as [she]316-the girl was with painful emotions , seemed to accept this undoubtingly .

The five years or so since [Paul Enderby]203-paul 's reappearance in [England]15-england seemed to have been not unprosperous . [The house to which [Maud]103-maud]1861-the house to which maud was welcomed by [[her]103-maud father]514-her father and [mother]375-mother was not a large one , and not in [a very fashionable locality]1864-a very fashionable locality , but [it]1861-the house to which maud was furnished with elegance . [Mrs. Enderby]204-mrs. enderby frequently had [her]204-mrs. enderby hired brougham , and made use of it to move about a good deal where [people]3402-people see and are seen . [Mr. Enderby]205-mr. enderby 's business was " in [the City]463-the city . "[205-mr. enderby] How [he]205-mr. enderby had surmounted [his]205-mr. enderby difficulties was not very clear ; [[his]205-mr. enderby wife]505-his wife learned that [he]205-mr. enderby had brought with [him]205-mr. enderby from [America]69-america a scheme for the utilisation of waste product in some obscure branch of manufacture , which had been so far successful as to supply [him]205-mr. enderby with a small capital . [He]205-mr. enderby seemed to work hard , leaving [home]3157-home at nine each morning , getting back to dinner at half - past six , and , as often as not , spending the evening away from [home]3157-home , and not returning till the small hours . [He]205-mr. enderby had the feverish eye of [a man whose subsistence depends upon speculative acuteness and restless calculation]1869-a man whose subsistence depends upon speculative acuteness and restless calculation . No doubt [he]205-mr. enderby was still so far [the old Paul]203-paul , that , whatever [he]205-mr. enderby undertook , [he]205-mr. enderby threw [himself]205-mr. enderby into it with surpassing vigour .

[Mrs. Enderby]204-mrs. enderby was in [her]204-mrs. enderby thirty - eighth year , and still handsome . [Most men]3674-most men , at all events , would have called [her]204-mrs. enderby so , for [most men]3674-most men are attracted by a face which is long , delicate , characterless , and preserves late the self - conscious expression of [a rather frivolous girl of seventeen]1872-a rather frivolous girl of seventeen . [She]204-mrs. enderby had ideals of [her]204-mrs. enderby own , which [she]204-mrs. enderby pursued regardless of the course in which [they]1873-they led [her]204-mrs. enderby ; and these ideals were far from ignoble . To beauty of all kinds [she]204-mrs. enderby was passionately sensitive . As [a girl]469-a girl [she]204-mrs. enderby had played the piano well , and , though the power had gone from long disuse , music was still [her]204-mrs. enderby chief passion . Graceful ease , delicacy in [her]204-mrs. enderby surroundings , freedom from domestic cares , the bloom of flowers , sweet scents such things made up [her]204-mrs. enderby existence . [She]204-mrs. enderby loved [[her]204-mrs. enderby husband]584-her husband , and had once worshipped [him]584-her husband ; [she]204-mrs. enderby loved [[her]204-mrs. enderby recovered daughter]1876-her recovered daughter ; but both affections were in [her]204-mrs. enderby , so to speak , of aesthetic rather than of moral quality .

Intercourse between [Maud]103-maud and [[her]103-maud parents]511-her parents , now that [they]511-her parents lived together , was , as might have been expected , not altogether natural or easy . [She]103-maud came to [them]511-her parents with boundless longings , ready to expend in a moment the love of a lifetime ; [they]511-her parents , on [their]511-her parents side , were scarcely less full of warm anticipation ; yet something prevented the complete expression of this mutual yearning . The fault was not in [the father]1878-the father and [mother]375-mother if [they]511-her parents hung back somewhat ; in very truth , [Maud]103-maud 's pure , noble countenance abashed [them]511-her parents . This , [[their]511-her parents child]1880-their child , was so much the superior of [them]511-her parents both ; [they]511-her parents felt it from the first moment , and could never master the consciousness . [Maud]103-maud mistook this for coldness ; it checked and saddened [her]103-maud . Yet time brought about better things , though the ideal would never be attained . In [[her]103-maud father]514-her father , [the girl]316-the girl found much to love ; [[her]103-maud mother]377-her mother [she]377-her mother could not love as [she]377-her mother had hoped , but [she]377-her mother regarded [her]103-maud with a vast tenderness , often with deep compassion . Much of sympathy , moreover , there was between [these two]645-these two . [Maud]103-maud 's artistic temperament was inherited from [[her]103-maud mother]377-her mother , but [she]103-maud possessed it in a stronger degree , of purer quality , and under greater restraint . This restraint , however , did not long continue to be exercised as hitherto . Life for the first time was open before [her]103-maud , and the music which began to fill [her]103-maud ears , the splendour which shone into [her]103-maud eyes , gradually availed to still that inner voice which had so long spoken to [her]103-maud in dark admonishings . [She]103-maud could not resign [herself]103-maud absolutely to the new delight ; it was still a conflict ; but from the conflict itself [she]103-maud derived a kind of joy , born of the strength of [her]103-maud imagination .

Yes , there was one portion of the past which dwelt with [her]103-maud , and by degrees busied [her]103-maud thoughts more and more . The correspondence with [Waymark]130-waymark had ceased , and by [her]103-maud own negligence . In those days of mental disturbance which preceded [her]103-maud return to [London]3-london , [his]130-waymark last letter had reached [her]103-maud , and this [she]103-maud had not replied to . It had been [her]103-maud turn to write , but [she]103-maud had not felt able to do so ; it had seemed to [her]103-maud , indeed , that , with [her]103-maud return [home]3157-home , the correspondence would naturally come to an end ; with a strange ignorance of [herself]103-maud , such as now and then darkens [us]1887-us , [she]103-maud had suddenly come to attach little value to the connection .
