Perhaps [she]153-mrs. sprowl had acted hastily and unkindly , but [she]153-mrs. sprowl had [young girls working in the laundry]2192-young girls working in the laundry , and it behoved [her]153-mrs. sprowl to be careful of [them]2192-young girls working in the laundry .

[Julian]118-julian 's part in the trial had been limited to an examination as to [his]118-julian knowledge of [Ida]101-ida 's alleged thefts . [He]118-julian declared that [he]118-julian knew nothing save from [[his]118-julian wife]505-his wife 's statements to [him]118-julian . [He]118-julian had observed nothing in the least suspicious .

A verdict was returned of " Guilty . "[118-julian]

Had [the prisoner]2172-the prisoner anything to say ? Nothing whatever . There was a pause , a longer pause than seemed necessary . Then , without remark , [she]101-ida was sentenced to be imprisoned for six months with hard labour .

[Waymark]130-waymark had been drawn to [the court]1401-the court in spite of [himself]130-waymark . Strangely quiet hitherto , a fear fell upon [him]130-waymark the night be fore the trial . From an early hour in the morning [he]130-waymark walked about [the streets]3169-the streets , circling ever nearer to [the hateful place]2197-the hateful place . All at once [he]130-waymark found [himself]130-waymark facing [Mr. Woodstock]114-mr. woodstock . [The old man]1383-the old man 's face was darkly anxious , and [he]1383-the old man could not change its expression quickly enough .

" Are [you]1383-the old man going in ? "[1383-the old man] [he]1383-the old man said sharply .

" Are [you]1383-the old man ? "[1383-the old man]

" Yes . "[1383-the old man]

" Then [I]130-waymark shall not , "[130-waymark] said [Waymark]130-waymark . " [I]130-waymark 'll go to [[your]1383-the old man place]4376-your place , and wait [there]3249-there . "[130-waymark]

But when [Abraham]115-abraham , whose eyes had not moved from [the prisoner throughout the proceedings]2199-the prisoner throughout the proceedings , rose at length to leave , a step or two brought [him]130-waymark to [a man who was leaning against the wall , powerless from conflicting excitement , and deadly pale]2200-a man who was leaning against the wall , powerless from conflicting excitement , and deadly pale . It was [Waymark]130-waymark . [Mr. Woodstock]114-mr. woodstock took [him]1383-the old man by the arm and led [him]1383-the old man out .

" Why could n't [you]130-waymark keep away ? "[1383-the old man] [the old man]1383-the old man exclaimed hoarsely , and with more of age in [his]1383-the old man voice than [any one]3197-any one had ever yet heard in it .

[Waymark]130-waymark shook [himself]130-waymark free , and laughed as one laughs under torment .

CHAPTER XXV

[ART AND MISERY

One Monday]222-art and misery one monday afternoon at the end of October three months had gone by since the trial [Waymark]130-waymark carried [his]130-waymark rents to [St. John Street Road]7-st. john street road as usual .

" [I]114-mr. woodstock 'm going to [Tottenham]62-tottenham , "[114-mr. woodstock] said [Mr. Woodstock]114-mr. woodstock . " [You]130-waymark may as well come with [me]114-mr. woodstock . "[114-mr. woodstock]

" By the by , [I]130-waymark finished [my]130-waymark novel the other day , "[130-waymark] [Waymark]130-waymark said , as [they]2203-they drove northward .

" That 's right . No doubt [you]130-waymark 're on [your]130-waymark way to glory , as the hymn says . "[130-waymark]

[Abraham]115-abraham was in good spirits . [One]318-one would have said that [he]2205-he had grown younger of late . That heaviness and tendency to absent brooding which not long ago seemed to indicate the tightening grip of age , was disappearing ; [he]2205-he was once more active and loud and full of [his]2205-he old interests .

" How 's [Casti]118-julian ? "[114-mr. woodstock] [Mr. Woodstock]114-mr. woodstock went on to ask .

" A good deal better , [I]114-mr. woodstock think , but shaky . Of course things will be as bad as ever when [[his]1383-the old man wife]505-his wife comes out of [the hospital]3287-the hospital . "[114-mr. woodstock]

" Pity [she]505-his wife ca n't come out heels first , "[115-abraham] muttered [Abraham]115-abraham .

[Waymark]130-waymark found that the purpose of [their]2203-they journey was to inspect [a large vacant house]2206-a large vacant house , with [a good garden]2207-a good garden and some fine trees about [it]2206-a large vacant house . [The old man]1383-the old man wished for [his]1383-the old man opinion , and , by degrees , let it be known that [he]1383-the old man thought of buying [the property]2209-the property .

" [I]1383-the old man suppose [you]130-waymark think [me]1383-the old man [an old fool]4380-an old fool to want [a house like this]4381-a house like this at [my]1383-the old man time of life , eh ? "[1383-the old man]

There was a twinkle in [his]1383-the old man eye , and a moment after [he]1383-the old man fairly burst into a laugh of pleasure . [Waymark]130-waymark asked no questions , and received no more information ; but a thought rose in [his]130-waymark mind which occupied [him]130-waymark for the rest of the day .

In the evening [Julian]118-julian came . [He]118-julian looked like [one who had recovered from a long illness , very pale and thin]2210-one who had recovered from a long illness , very pale and thin , and [his]118-julian voice had tremblings and uncertainties of key . In fact , a feverish disorder had been upon [him]118-julian for some weeks , never severe enough to prevent [his]118-julian getting about , but weakening [him]118-julian to a serious degree . It would doubtless have developed into some more pronounced illness , but for the period of comparative rest and quietness which had begun shortly after the miseries of the trial . [Harriet]216-harriet 's ailments had all at once taken such a decided turn for the worse [her]216-harriet fits becoming incessant , and other disorders traceable to the same source suddenly taking hold upon [her]216-harriet that [Julian]118-julian had obtained [her]216-harriet admission to [the hospital]3287-the hospital , where [she]216-harriet still remained . [He]130-waymark went to see [her]216-harriet in [the ward]655-the ward two or three times a week , though [he]130-waymark dreaded the necessity . From little incidents which occurred at such times , [he]130-waymark was convinced that all [[her]216-harriet fellow - patients]2213-her fellow - patients , as well as [the ' sister " and nurses of [the wards]4383-the wards]4382-the ' sister " and nurses of the wards , had been prejudiced against [him]130-waymark by [her]216-harriet reports and accusations . To meet [their]2213-her fellow - patients looks occasioned [him]130-waymark the most acute suffering . Sometimes [he]130-waymark sat by the bedside for half an hour without speaking , then rose and hastened away to hide [himself]130-waymark and be alone with [his]130-waymark misery .[130-waymark]

[He]130-waymark was earnest and eager to - night in [his]130-waymark praise of [Waymark]130-waymark 's book , which [he]130-waymark had just read in manuscript .

" It is horrible , "[130-waymark] [he]130-waymark exclaimed ; " often hideous and revolting to [me]130-waymark ; but [I]130-waymark feel its absolute truth . Such a book will do more good than half a dozen religious societies . "[130-waymark]

" If only [people]3402-people can be got to read it . Yet [I]130-waymark care nothing for that aspect of the thing . Is it artistically strong ? Is it good as a picture ? There was a time when [I]130-waymark might have written in this way with a declared social object . That is all gone by . [I]130-waymark have no longer a spark of social enthusiasm . Art is all [I]130-waymark now care for , and as art [I]130-waymark wish [my]130-waymark work to be judged . "[130-waymark]

" [One]318-one would have thought , "[118-julian] said [Julian]118-julian , " that increased knowledge of these fearful things would have had just the opposite effect . "[118-julian]

" Yes , "[449-the other] exclaimed [the other]449-the other , with the smile which always prefaced some piece of self - dissection , " and so it would in the case of [a man born to be [a radical]3841-a radical]4386-a man born to be a radical . [I]449-the other often amuse [myself]449-the other with taking to pieces [[my]449-the other former self]4388-my former self . [I]449-the other was not [a conscious hypocrite in those days of violent radicalism]4389-a conscious hypocrite in those days of violent radicalism , [working - man's - club lecturing]4390-working - man's - club lecturing , and the like ; the fault was that [I]449-the other understood [myself]449-the other as yet so imperfectly . That zeal on behalf of [the suffering masses]4391-the suffering masses was nothing more nor less than disguised zeal on behalf of [my]449-the other own starved passions . [I]449-the other was poor and desperate , life had no pleasures , the future seemed hopeless , yet [I]449-the other was overflowing with vehement desires , every nerve in [me]449-the other was a hunger which cried to be appeased . [I]449-the other identified [myself]449-the other with [the poor and ignorant]4392-the poor and ignorant ; [I]449-the other did not make [their]4392-the poor and ignorant cause [my]449-the other own , but [my]449-the other own cause [theirs]4392-the poor and ignorant . [I]449-the other raved for freedom because [I]449-the other was [myself]449-the other in the bondage of unsatisfiable longing . "[449-the other]

" Well , "[2215-i] [he]2215-i went on , after regarding [[his]2215-i listener]2216-his listener with still the same smile , " [I]2215-i have come out of all that , in proportion as [my]2215-i artistic self - consciousness has developed . For one thing , [I]2215-i am not so miserable as [I]2215-i was then , personally ; then again , [I]2215-i have found [my]2215-i vocation . [You]4393-you know pretty well the phases [I]2215-i have passed through . Upon ranting radicalism followed a period of philosophical study . [My]2215-i philosophy , [I]2215-i have come to see , was worth nothing ; what philosophy is worth anything ? It had its use for [myself]2215-i , however ; it made [me]2215-i by degrees self - conscious , and brought [me]2215-i to see that in art alone [I]2215-i could find full satisfaction . "[2215-i]

" Yet , "[118-julian] urged [Julian]118-julian , " the old direction still shows itself in [your]4393-you choice of subjects . Granting that this is pure art , it is a kind of art only possible to an age in which the social question is predominant . "[118-julian]

" True , very likely . [Every strong individuality]4394-every strong individuality is more or less the expression of [its]4394-every strong individuality age . This direction may be imposed upon [me]2215-i ; for all that , [I]2215-i understand why [I]2215-i pursue it . "[2215-i]

After reflecting , [Julian]118-julian spoke in another tone . " Imagine [yourself]4393-you in [my]118-julian position . Could [you]4393-you appreciate the artistic effect of [your]4393-you own circumstances ? "[118-julian]

" Probably not . And it is because [I]2215-i recognise that , that [I]2215-i grow more and more careful to hold aloof from situations that would threaten [my]2215-i peace of mind . [My]2215-i artistic egotism bids fair to ally itself with vulgar selfishness . That tendency [I]2215-i must resist . For [the artist]3782-the artist ought to be able to make material of [his]3782-the artist own sufferings , even while the suffering is at its height . To what other end does [he]3782-the artist suffer ? In very deed , [he]3782-the artist is the only man whose misery finds justification in apparent result . "[2215-i]

" [I]118-julian am not [an artist]1848-an artist , "[118-julian] sighed [Julian]118-julian .

" On the contrary , [I]2215-i firmly believe that [you]4393-you are . And it makes [me]2215-i angry to see the impulse dying in [you]4393-you . "[2215-i]

" What am [I]118-julian to do ? "[118-julian] [Julian]118-julian cried , almost with a voice of anguish . " [I]118-julian am so helpless , so hopelessly fettered ! Release is impossible . No words could express the desperate struggles [I]118-julian go through when [I]118-julian recognise how [my]118-julian life is being wasted and [my]118-julian powers , whatever they may be , numbed and crushed . Something [I]118-julian might do , if [I]118-julian were free ; [I]118-julian feel that ! But there is no hope of freedom . [I]118-julian shall fall into darker and darker depths of weakness and ruin , always conscious of what [I]118-julian am losing . What will be the end ? "[118-julian]

" What the end will be , under the present circumstances , is only too clear to [me]2215-i . But it might easily be averted ? "[2215-i]

" How ? Give [me]118-julian some practical advice , [Waymark]130-waymark ! Let [us]4397-us talk of the matter freely . Tell [me]118-julian what [you]130-waymark would do ! "[118-julian]

[Waymark]130-waymark thought for a moment .

" Does there seem any chance of [her]4398-she health being permanently improved ? "[130-waymark] [he]130-waymark asked .

" [I]118-julian ca n't say . [She]4398-she says [she]4398-she is better . It 's no use [my]118-julian asking [the doctors]4399-the doctors ; [they]4399-the doctors despise [me]118-julian , and would not think of treating [me]118-julian with any consideration . "[118-julian]

" Why do n't [you]130-waymark do this ? "[130-waymark] began [Waymark]130-waymark , after another pause . " Use all means to find [some convalescent home where [she]4398-she can be received when [she]4398-she leaves [the hospital]3287-the hospital]4400-some convalescent home where she can be received when she leaves the hospital . Then , if [her]4398-she fits and the rest of it still continue , find some permanent place for [her]4398-she . [You]130-waymark can afford it . Never mind if it reduces [you]130-waymark for a time to a garret and a crust . "[130-waymark]

" [She]4398-she would refuse to go to [such places]4402-such places , "[118-julian] said [Julian]118-julian despondently .

" Then refuse to take [her]4398-she back ! Sell [your]130-waymark furniture ; take [one room]3802-one room for [yourself]130-waymark ; and tell [her]4398-she [she]4398-she must live where [she]4398-she likes on a sufficient allowance from [you]130-waymark . "[118-julian]

" [I]130-waymark dare not . It is impossible . [She]4398-she would never leave [me]130-waymark in peace . "[130-waymark]

" [You]130-waymark will have to do this ultimately , if [you]130-waymark are to continue to live . Of that there is no doubt . So why not now ? "[118-julian]

" [I]130-waymark must think ; it is impossible to make up [my]130-waymark mind to such a thing at once . [I]130-waymark know [you]130-waymark advise what is best ; [I]130-waymark have thought of it [myself]130-waymark . But [I]130-waymark shall never have the courage ! [I]130-waymark am so miserably weak . If only [I]130-waymark could get [my]130-waymark health back ! [Good God]123-god , how [I]130-waymark suffer ! "[130-waymark]

[Waymark]130-waymark did [his]130-waymark best to familiarise [Julian]118-julian with the thought , and to foster in [him]118-julian something of resoluteness , but [he]130-waymark had small hope of succeeding . [The poor fellow]990-the poor fellow was so incapable of anything which at all resembled selfishness , and so dreaded the results of any such severity on [his]990-the poor fellow part as that proposed . There were moments when indignation almost nerved [him]990-the poor fellow to independence , but there returned so soon the souse of pity , and , oftener still , the thought of that promise made to [[Harriet]216-harriet 's father]2218-harriet 's father , long ago , in [the dark little parlour which smelt of drugs]2219-the dark little parlour which smelt of drugs . [The poor chemist , whose own life was full of misery , had been everything to [him]990-the poor fellow]2220-the poor chemist , whose own life was full of misery , had been everything to him ; but for [Mr. Smales]106-mr. smales , [he]106-mr. smales might now have been [an ignorant , coarse - handed working man]2221-an ignorant , coarse - handed working man , if not worse . Was [Harriet]216-harriet past all rescue ? Was there not even yet a chance of saving [her]216-harriet from [herself]216-harriet and [those hateful friends of [hers]216-harriet]2222-those hateful friends of hers ?

This was the natural reaction after listening to [Waymark]130-waymark 's remorseless counsel . Going [home]3157-home , [Julian]118-julian fought once more the battle with [himself]118-julian , till the usual troubled sleep severed [his]118-julian thoughts into fragments of horrible dreams . The next day [he]118-julian felt differently ; [Waymark]130-waymark 's advice seemed more practical . In the afternoon [he]118-julian should have visited [Harriet]216-harriet in [the ward]655-the ward , but an insuperable repulsion kept [him]118-julian away , and for the first time . It was a bleak , cheerless day ; the air was cold with the breath of the nearing winter ; At night [he]118-julian found it impossible to sit in [[his]118-julian own room]2225-his own room , and dreaded to talk with [any one]3197-any one . [His]118-julian thoughts were fixed upon [one place]2227-one place ; a great longing drew [him]118-julian forth , into the darkness and the rain of [the streets]3169-the streets , onwards in a fixed direction . It brought [him]118-julian to [Westminster]34-westminster , and to [the gate of [Tothill Fields Prison]78-tothill fields prison]2229-the gate of tothill fields prison . The fetters upon the great doors were hideous in the light of the lamps above them ; [the mean houses around [the gaol]2231-the gaol]2230-the mean houses around the gaol seemed to be rotting in [its]2230-the mean houses around the gaol accursed shadow . A deadly stillness possessed the air ; there was blight in the dropping of the rain .

[He]118-julian leaned against the great , gloomy wall , and thought of [Ida]101-ida . At this hour [she]101-ida was most likely asleep , unless sorrow kept [her]101-ida waking . What unimagined horrors did [she]101-ida suffer day after day in [that accursed prison - house]2232-that accursed prison - house ? How did [she]101-ida bear [her]101-ida torments ? Was [she]101-ida well or ill ? What brutality might [she]101-ida not be subjected to ? [He]118-julian pictured [her]101-ida face wasted with secret tears , those eyes which were the light of [his]118-julian soul fixed on the walls of [the cell]2233-the cell , hour after hour , in changeless despair , the fire of passionate resentment feeding at [her]101-ida life 's core .

The night became calmer . The rained ceased , and a sudden gleam made [him]118-julian look up , to behold the moon breaking [her]101-ida way through billows of darkness .

CHAPTER XXVI

STRAYING

[The Enderbys]202-the enderbys were at [Brighton]79-brighton during the autumn . [Mr. Enderby]205-mr. enderby only remained with [them]2234-them two or three days at a time , business requiring [his]205-mr. enderby frequent presence in [town]901-town . [Maud]103-maud would have been glad to spend [her]103-maud holidays at some far quieter place , but [[her]103-maud mother]377-her mother enjoyed [Brighton]79-brighton , and threw [herself]377-her mother into its amusements of the place with spirits which seemed to grow younger . [They]2234-them occupied [handsome rooms]2237-handsome rooms , and altogether lived in a more expensive way than when at [home]3157-home .

[Maud]103-maud was glad to see [[her]103-maud mother]377-her mother happy , but could not be at ease [herself]103-maud in this kind of life . It was soon arranged that [she]103-maud should live in [her]103-maud own way , withholding from the social riot which [she]103-maud dreaded , and seeking rest in [out - of - the - way]2240-out - of - the - way parts of [the shore]1697-the shore , where more of nature was to be found and less of fashion . [Maud]103-maud feared lest [[her]103-maud mother]377-her mother should feel this as an unkind desertion , but [Mrs. Enderby]204-mrs. enderby was far from any such trouble ; it relieved [her]204-mrs. enderby from the occasional disadvantage of having by [her]204-mrs. enderby side [a grown - up daughter , whose beauty so strongly contrasted with [her]204-mrs. enderby own]2243-a grown - up daughter , whose beauty so strongly contrasted with her own . So [Maud]103-maud spent [her]103-maud days very frequently in exploring [the Downs]2244-the downs , or in seeking out [retired nooks beneath [the cliffs]1753-the cliffs]2245-retired nooks beneath the cliffs , where there was no sound in [her]103-maud ears but that of [the waves]2247-the waves . [She]103-maud would sit for hours with no companion save [her]103-maud thoughts , which were unconsciously led from phase to phase by the moving lights and shadows upon [the sea]1626-the sea , and the soft beauty of unstable clouds .

Even before leaving [London]3-london , [she]103-maud had begun to experience a frequent sadness of mood , tending at times to weariness and depression , which foreshadowed new changes in [her]103-maud inner life . The fresh delight in nature and art had worn off in some degree ; [she]103-maud read less , and [her]103-maud thoughts took the habit of musing upon [the people]3247-the people and circumstances about [her]103-maud , also upon the secrets of the years to come . [She]103-maud grew more conscious of the mystery in [her]103-maud own earlier life , and in the conditions which now surrounded [her]103-maud . A sense which at times besets all imaginative minds came upon [her]103-maud now and then with painful force ; a fantastic unreality would suddenly possess all [she]103-maud saw and heard ; it seemed as if [she]103-maud had been of a sudden transported out of the old existence into this new and unrealised position ; if [any person]2250-any person spoke to [her]103-maud , it was difficult to feel that [she]103-maud was really addressed and must reply ; was it not all a mere vision [she]103-maud was beholding , out of which [she]103-maud would presently awake ! Such moments were followed by dark melancholy . This life [she]103-maud was leading could not last , but would pass away in some fearful shock of soul . Once [she]103-maud half believed [herself]103-maud endowed with the curse of a hideous second - sight . Sitting with [[her]103-maud father]514-her father and [mother]375-mother , silence all at once fell upon [the room]255-the room , and everything was transfigured in a ghostly light . Distinctly [she]103-maud saw [[her]103-maud mother]377-her mother throw [her]377-her mother head back and raise to [her]377-her mother throat what seemed to be a sharp , glistening piece of steel ; then came a cry , and all was darkened before [her]103-maud eyes in a rush of crimson mist . The cry [she]103-maud had [herself]103-maud uttered , much to [[her]103-maud parents]511-her parents ' alarm ; what [[her]103-maud mother]377-her mother held was in reality only a paper - knife , with which [she]377-her mother had been tapping [her]377-her mother lips in thought . A slight attack of illness followed on this disturbance , and it was some days before [she]103-maud recovered from the shock ; [she]103-maud kept to [herself]103-maud , however , the horrible picture which [her]103-maud imagination had conjured up .

[She]103-maud began to pay more frequent visits to [[her]103-maud aunt]737-her aunt [Theresa]206-theresa , whom at first [she]103-maud had seen very seldom . There was not the old confidence between [them]2258-them . [Maud]103-maud shrank from any direct reference to the change in [herself]103-maud , and [Miss Bygrave]121-miss bygrave spoke no word which could suggest a comparison between past and present . [Maud]103-maud tried once more to draw near to [the pale , austere woman , whose life ever remained the same]2259-the pale , austere woman , whose life ever remained the same . [She]103-maud was not repelled , but neither did any movement respond to [her]103-maud yearning . [She]103-maud always came away with a sad heart .

One evening in the week [she]103-maud looked forward to with eagerness ; it was that on which [Waymark]130-waymark was generally expected . In [Waymark]130-waymark 's presence [she]103-maud could forget those dark spirits that hovered about [her]103-maud ; [she]103-maud could forget [herself]103-maud , and be at rest in the contemplation of strength and confidence . There was a ring in [his]130-waymark voice which inspired faith ; whatever might be [his]130-waymark own doubts and difficulties and [his]130-waymark face testified to [his]130-waymark knowledge of both it was so certain that [he]130-waymark had power to overcome [them]2260-them . This characteristic grew stronger in [him]130-waymark to [her]103-maud observation ; [he]130-waymark was [a far other man]2261-a far other man now than when [she]103-maud first knew [him]130-waymark ; the darkness had passed from [his]130-waymark eyes , which seemed always to look straight forward , and with perception of an end [he]130-waymark was nearing . Why could [she]103-maud not make opportunities of speaking freely with [him]130-waymark , alone with [him]130-waymark ? [They]2262-they were less near to [each other]459-each other , it seemed , after a year of constant meeting , than in the times when , personally all but [strangers]477-strangers , [they]2262-they had corresponded so frankly and unconventionally . Of course [he]130-waymark came to [the house]288-the house for [her]103-maud sake ; it could not but be so ; yet at times [he]130-waymark seemed to pay so little attention to [her]103-maud . [[Her]103-maud mother]377-her mother often monopolised [him]130-waymark through a whole evening , and not apparently to [his]130-waymark annoyance . And all the time [he]130-waymark had in [his]130-waymark heart the message for which [she]103-maud longed ; support and comfort were waiting for [her]103-maud there , [she]103-maud felt sure , could [he]130-waymark but speak unrestrainedly . In [herself]103-maud was no salvation ; but [he]130-waymark had already overcome , and why could [she]103-maud not ask [him]130-waymark for the secret of [his]130-waymark confidence ? Often , as the evening drew to an end , and [he]130-waymark was preparing to leave , an impatience scarcely to be repressed took hold upon [her]103-maud ; [her]103-maud face grew hot , [her]103-maud hands trembled , [she]103-maud would have followed [him]130-waymark from [the room]255-the room and begged for one word to [herself]103-maud had it been possible . And when [he]130-waymark was gone , there came the weakest moments [her]103-maud life had yet known ; a childish petulance , a tearful fretting , an irritable misery of which [she]103-maud was ashamed . [She]103-maud went to [[her]103-maud room]2268-her room to suffer in silence , and often to read through that packet of [his]130-waymark letters , till the night was far spent .

It had cost [her]103-maud much to leave [London]3-london . [She]103-maud feared lest , during [her]103-maud absence , something should occur to break off the wonted course of things , and that [Waymark]130-waymark might not resume [his]130-waymark visits on [their]2269-their return . After the feverish interval of those first weeks , [she]103-maud tried sometimes to distract [her]103-maud thoughts by reading , and got from [a library]2270-a library a book which [Waymark]130-waymark had recommended to [her]103-maud at [their]2269-their last meeting [Rossetti]223-rossetti 's poems . These gave [her]103-maud much help in restoring [her]103-maud mind to quietness . Their perfect beauty entranced [her]103-maud , and the rapturous purity of ideal passion , the mystic delicacies of emotion , which made every verse gleam like a star , held [her]103-maud for the time high above that gloomy cloudland of [her]103-maud being , rife with weird shapes and muffled voices . That Beauty is solace of life , and Love the end of being , this faith [she]103-maud would cling to in spite of all ; [she]103-maud grasped it with the desperate force of [one who dreaded lest it should fade and fail]2271-one who dreaded lest it should fade and fail from [her]103-maud . Beauty alone would not suffice ; too often it was perceived as a mere mask , veiling horrors ; but in the passion and the worship of love was surely a never - failing fountain of growth and power ; this the draught that would leave no bitter aftertaste , its enjoyment the final and all - sufficient answer to the riddle of life . [Rossetti]223-rossetti put into utterance for [her]103-maud so much that [she]103-maud had not dared to entrust even to the voice of thought . [Her]103-maud spirit and flesh became one and indivisible ; the old antagonism seemed at an end for ever .

Such dreamings as these naturally heightened [Maud]103-maud 's dislike for the kind of life [[her]103-maud mother]377-her mother led , and [she]103-maud longed unspeakably for the time of [her]103-maud return to [London]3-london . [They]2273-they had been at [Brighton]79-brighton already nearly a month , when a new circumstance was added to [her]103-maud discomfort . As [she]103-maud walked with [[her]103-maud mother]377-her mother one day , [they]2273-they met [[their]2273-they acquaintance]2275-their acquaintance , [Mr. Budge]224-mr. budge . [This gentleman]793-this gentleman dined with [them]2273-they that evening at [Mrs. Enderby]204-mrs. enderby 's invitation , and persuaded [the latter]425-the latter to join a party [he]793-this gentleman had made up for an excursion on the following day . [Maud]103-maud excused [herself]103-maud . [She]103-maud did not like [Mr. Budge]224-mr. budge , and [his]224-mr. budge demeanour during the evening only strengthened [her]103-maud prejudice . [He]224-mr. budge was unduly excited and fervent , and allowed [himself]224-mr. budge a certain freedom in [his]224-mr. budge conversation with [Mrs. Enderby]204-mrs. enderby which [Maud]103-maud resented strongly .

When [they]2273-they were once more in [London]3-london , [Maud]103-maud did not win back the former quiet of mind . [Waymark]130-waymark came again as usual , but if anything the distance between [him]224-mr. budge and [herself]103-maud seemed more hopeless . [He]224-mr. budge appeared preoccupied ; [his]224-mr. budge talk , when [he]224-mr. budge spoke with [her]103-maud , was of a more general kind than formerly ; [she]103-maud was conscious that [her]103-maud presence did not affect [him]224-mr. budge as it had done . [She]103-maud sank again into despondency ; books were insipid , and society irritated [her]103-maud . [She]103-maud began the habit of taking long walks , an aimless wandering about [the streets]3169-the streets and parks within [her]103-maud reach . One evening , wending wearily homewards , [she]103-maud was attracted by the lights in [[a church]2279-a church in [Marylebone Road]18-marylebone road]2280-a church in marylebone road , and , partly for a few minutes ' rest , partly out of a sudden attraction to a religious service , [she]103-maud entered . It was [the church of Our Lady of the Rosary]2281-the church of our lady of the rosary . [She]103-maud had not noticed that [it]2281-the church of our lady of the rosary was [a Roman Catholic place of worship]2282-a roman catholic place of worship , but the discovery gave [her]103-maud an unexpected pleasure . [She]103-maud was soothed and filled with a sense of repose . Sinking into the attitude of prayer , [she]103-maud let [her]103-maud thoughts carry [her]103-maud whither they would ; they showed [her]103-maud nothing but images of beauty and peace . It was with reluctance that [she]103-maud arose and went back into [the dark street]2283-the dark street , where [the world]622-the world met [her]103-maud with a chill blast , sleet - laden .

[Our Lady of the Rosary]2285-our lady of the rosary received [her]103-maud frequently after this . But there were days when the thought of repose was far from [her]103-maud . At one such time , on an evening in November , a sudden desire possessed [her]103-maud mind ; [she]103-maud would go out into [the streets of [the town]1023-the town]2286-the streets of the town and see something of that life which [she]103-maud knew only in imagination , the traffic of [highway and byway]2288-highway and byway after dark , the masque of pleasure and misery of sin of which [a young girl]2289-a young girl can know nothing , save from hints here and there in [her]2289-a young girl reading , or from the occasional whispers and head - shakings of [society]3471-society 's gossip . [Her]103-maud freedom was complete ; [her]103-maud absence , if noticed , would entail no questions ; [[her]103-maud mother]377-her mother doubtless would conclude that [she]103-maud was at [[her]103-maud aunt]737-her aunt [Theresa]206-theresa 's . So [she]103-maud clad [herself]103-maud in walking attire of a kind not likely to attract observation , and set forth . The tumult which had been in [her]103-maud blood all day received fresh impulse from the excitement of the adventure . [She]103-maud had veiled [her]103-maud face , but the veil hindered [her]103-maud observation , and [she]103-maud threw it back . First into [Edgware Road]63-edgware road , then down [Oxford Street]19-oxford street . [Her]103-maud thoughts pointed to [an eastern district]2293-an eastern district , though [she]103-maud feared the distance would be too great ; [she]103-maud had frequently talked with [Waymark]130-waymark of [his]130-waymark work in [Litany Lane]45-litany lane and [Elm Court]46-elm court , and a great curiosity possessed [her]103-maud to see [these places]2294-these places . [She]103-maud entered [an omnibus]1084-an omnibus , and so reached [the remote neighbourhood]2296-the remote neighbourhood . Here , by inquiry of [likely people]2297-likely people , [she]103-maud found [her]103-maud way to [Litany Lane]45-litany lane , and would have penetrated [its]45-litany lane darkness , but was arrested by a sudden event characteristic of [the locality]301-the locality .

Forth from [the alley]2299-the alley , just before [her]103-maud , rushed [a woman of hideous aspect]2300-a woman of hideous aspect , pursued by another , younger , but , if possible , yet more foul , who shrieked curses and threats . In the way of [the fugitive]2301-the fugitive was [[a costermonger]3967-a costermonger 's stall]2303-a costermonger 's stall ; unable to check [herself]103-maud , [the woman]448-the woman rushed against this , overturning it , and [herself]103-maud falling among the ruin . [The one in pursuit , with a yell of triumph]2305-the one in pursuit , with a yell of triumph , sprang upon [[her]103-maud prostrate enemy]2306-her prostrate enemy , and attacked [her]103-maud with fearful violence , leaping on [her]103-maud body , dashing [her]103-maud head against the pavement , seemingly bent on murder . In a moment there was [a thick crowd]2307-a thick crowd rushing round , amid which [Maud]103-maud was crushed and swayed without possibility of disengaging [herself]103-maud . The screams of [the one woman]2308-the one woman , and the terrific objurgations of the other , echoed through [the street]340-the street . From the words of those about [her]103-maud , [Maud]103-maud understood that [the two women]2310-the two women were [mother]375-mother and [daughter]413-daughter , and that it was no rare occurrence for [the younger woman]2313-the younger woman to fall just short of killing [[her]2313-the younger woman parent]2314-her parent . But only for a moment or two could [Maud]103-maud understand anything ; horror and physical oppression overcame [her]103-maud senses . [Her]103-maud fainting caused a diversion in [the crowd]2315-the crowd , and [she]103-maud was dragged without much delay to [the nearest doorstep]2316-the nearest doorstep .

[She]103-maud was not long unconscious , and presently so far recovered as to know that [she]103-maud was being helped to enter [a cab]648-a cab . [The cab]2318-the cab began to drive off . Then [she]103-maud saw that [some one]3153-some one was sitting opposite [her]103-maud . " Who is it ? "[103-maud] [she]103-maud asked , trying to command [herself]103-maud , and to see clearly by the light of the street lamps . At the sound of the voice which answered , [she]103-maud started , and , looking again , at length recognised [Waymark]130-waymark .

" Do [you]103-maud feel better ? "[130-waymark] [he]130-waymark asked . " Are [you]103-maud able to go on homewards ? "[130-waymark]

" Quite able , "[103-maud] [she]103-maud answered , leaning back again , and speaking with strange calmness .

" What on earth is the meaning of this ? "[130-waymark] was [Waymark]130-waymark 's next inquiry . " How came [you]103-maud [here]3335-here at this time ? "[130-waymark]

" [Curiosity]225-curiosity brought [me]103-maud , "[103-maud] [Maud]103-maud answered , with the same unnatural composure .

" Had [you]103-maud been [there]3249-there long ? "[103-maud]

" No ; [I]130-waymark had asked [my]130-waymark way to [Litany Lane]45-litany lane , and all at once found [myself]130-waymark in [the crowd]2315-the crowd . "[130-waymark]

" Thank goodness [I]103-maud happened to be by ! [I]103-maud had just been looking up [a defaulting tenant]4407-a defaulting tenant . [I]103-maud could n't believe [my]103-maud eyes when [I]103-maud saw [you]103-maud lying in that doorway . Why did n't [you]103-maud ask [me]103-maud to come with [you]103-maud , and show [you]103-maud [these places]2294-these places ? "[103-maud]

" It would have been better , "[103-maud] [she]103-maud said , with [her]103-maud eyes closed . [Waymark]130-waymark leaned back . Conversation was difficult in the noise of [the vehicle]2320-the vehicle , and for a long time [neither]2321-neither spoke .

" [I]130-waymark told [the man]491-the man to drive to [Edgware Road]63-edgware road , "[130-waymark] [Waymark]130-waymark said then . " Shall [he]491-the man go on to [the house]288-the house ? "[130-waymark]

" No ; [I]2322-i had rather walk the last part . "[2322-i]

[They]2322-i talked brokenly of [the Lane]1392-the lane and [[its]1392-the lane inhabitants]2324-its inhabitants . When at length [Maud]103-maud alighted [Waymark]130-waymark offered [his]130-waymark arm , and [she]103-maud just laid [her]103-maud hand upon it .

" [I]103-maud have seen dreadful things to - night , "[103-maud] [she]103-maud said , in a voice that still trembled ; ' seen and heard things that will haunt [me]0-i . "[103-maud]

" [You]130-waymark give too much weight to the impressions of the moment . [That world]1934-that world is farther removed from [yours]130-waymark than the farthest star ; [you]130-waymark must forget this glimpse of it . "[103-maud]

" Oh , [I]103-maud fear [you]130-waymark do not know [me]103-maud ; [I]103-maud do not know [myself]103-maud . "[103-maud]

[He]130-waymark made no reply , and , on [their]2325-their coming near to [the house]288-the house , [Maud]103-maud paused .

" [Mother]375-mother 's sending [you]130-waymark a note this evening , "[103-maud] [she]103-maud said , as [she]103-maud held out [her]103-maud hand , " to ask [you]130-waymark to come on Thursday instead of to - morrow . [She]103-maud will be from [home]3157-home to - morrow night . "[103-maud]

" Shall [you]130-waymark also be from [home]3157-home ? "[130-waymark]

" [I]103-maud ? No . "[103-maud]

" Then may [I]130-waymark not come and see [you]130-waymark ? Not if it would be troublesome . "[130-waymark]

" It would not , at all . "[103-maud]

" It is good of [you]130-waymark . [I]130-waymark will come . "[130-waymark]

CHAPTER XXVII

THE WILL TO [LIVE

Waymark]130-waymark made [his]130-waymark way to [Paddington]80-paddington at the usual time on the following evening , and found [Maud]103-maud alone . There was agitation in [her]103-maud manner as [she]103-maud welcomed [him]130-waymark , and [she]103-maud resumed [her]103-maud seat as if the attitude of rest was needful to [her]103-maud . In reply to [his]130-waymark inquiries about [her]103-maud health , [she]103-maud assured [him]130-waymark [she]103-maud was well , and that [she]103-maud felt no painful results from the previous evening . [Waymark]130-waymark also showed an unusual embarrassment . [He]130-waymark stood for some moments by the table , turning over the leaves of a book .

" [I]130-waymark did n't know [you]103-maud had [Rossetti]223-rossetti , "[130-waymark] [he]130-waymark said , without looking up . " [You]103-maud never mentioned [him]4415-him . "[130-waymark]

" [I]130-waymark seem to have had no opportunity . "[130-waymark]

" No . [I]130-waymark too have many things that [I]130-waymark have wanted to speak to [you]103-maud about , but opportunity was wanting . [I]130-waymark have sometimes been on the point of asking [you]103-maud to let [me]130-waymark write to [you]103-maud again . "[130-waymark]

[He]130-waymark glanced inquiringly at [her]103-maud . [Her]103-maud eyes fell , and [she]103-maud tried to speak , but failed . [Waymark]130-waymark went to a seat at a little distance from [her]103-maud .

" [You]103-maud do not look as well as when [I]130-waymark met [you]103-maud in the summer , "[130-waymark] [he]130-waymark said . " [I]130-waymark have feared [you]103-maud might be studying too hard . [I]130-waymark hope [you]103-maud threw away [your]103-maud books whilst [you]103-maud were at [the sea - side]1846-the sea - side . "[130-waymark]

" [I]130-waymark did , but it was because [I]130-waymark found little pleasure in them . It was not rest that took the place of reading . "[130-waymark]

" Are [your]103-maud difficulties of a kind [you]103-maud could speak of to [me]130-waymark ? "[130-waymark] [he]130-waymark asked , with some hesitation .

[She]103-maud kept [her]103-maud eyes lowered , and [her]103-maud fingers writhed nervously on the arm of the chair .

" [My]103-maud only fear would be lest [you]103-maud should think [my]103-maud troubles unreal . Indeed it is so hard to make them appear anything more than morbid fancies . They are traceable , no doubt , to [my]103-maud earliest years . To explain them fully , [I]103-maud should have to tell [you]103-maud circumstances of [my]103-maud life which could have little interest for [you]103-maud . "[103-maud]

" Tell [me]130-waymark do , "[130-waymark] [Waymark]130-waymark replied earnestly .

" Will [you]130-waymark let [me]103-maud ? "[103-maud] [she]103-maud said , with a timid pleasure in [her]103-maud voice . " [I]103-maud believe [you]130-waymark could understand [me]103-maud . [I]103-maud have a feeling that [you]103-maud must have experienced something of these troubles [yourself]103-maud , and have overcome them . Perhaps [you]103-maud could help [me]103-maud to understand [myself]103-maud . "[103-maud]

" If [I]103-maud thought [I]103-maud could , it would give [me]103-maud great happiness . "[103-maud]

[She]103-maud was silent a little , then , with diffidence which lessened as [she]103-maud went on , [she]103-maud related the history , as far as [she]103-maud knew it , of [her]103-maud childhood , and described the growth of [her]103-maud mind up to the time when [she]103-maud had left [home]3157-home to begin life as [a governess]2328-a governess . It was all very simply , but very vividly , told ; that natural command of impressive language which had so struck [Waymark]130-waymark in [her]103-maud letters displayed itself as soon as [she]103-maud had gained confidence . Glimpses of [her]103-maud experience [Waymark]130-waymark had already had , but now for the first time [he]130-waymark understood the full significance of [her]103-maud early years . Whilst [she]103-maud spoke , [he]130-waymark did not move [his]130-waymark eyes from [her]103-maud face . [He]130-waymark was putting [himself]130-waymark in [her]103-maud position , and imagining [himself]130-waymark to be telling [his]130-waymark own story in the same way . [His]130-waymark relation , [he]130-waymark knew , would have been a piece of more or less clever acting , howsoever true ; [he]130-waymark would have been considering , all the time , the effect of what [he]130-waymark said , and , indeed , could not , on this account , have allowed [himself]130-waymark to be quite truthful . How far was this the case with [Maud Enderby]103-maud ? Could [he]130-waymark have surprised the faintest touch of insincerity in look or accent , it would have made [a world]2329-a world 's difference in [his]130-waymark position towards [her]103-maud . [His]130-waymark instinct was unfailing in the detection of the note of affected feeling ; so much the stronger the impression produced upon [him]130-waymark by a soul unveiling itself in the naivete of genuine emotion . That all was sincere [he]130-waymark could have no doubt . Gradually [he]130-waymark lost [his]130-waymark critical attitude , and at moments surprised [himself]130-waymark under the influence of a sympathetic instinct . Then [he]130-waymark would lose consciousness of [her]103-maud words for an interval , during which [he]130-waymark pondered [her]103-maud face , and was wrought upon by its strange beauty . The pure and touching spirituality of [Maud]103-maud 's countenance had never been so present to [him]130-waymark as now ; [she]103-maud was pale with very earnestness , [her]103-maud eyes seemed larger than their wo nt , there was more than womanly sweetness in the voice which so unconsciously modulated itself to the perfect expression of all [she]103-maud uttered . Towards the end , [he]130-waymark could but yield [himself]130-waymark completely to the spell , and , when [she]103-maud ceased , [he]130-waymark , like [Adam]226-adam at the end of [the angel]2330-the angel 's speech , did not at once perceive that [her]103-maud voice was silent .

" It was long , "[103-maud] [she]103-maud said , after telling the outward circumstances of [her]103-maud life with [[her]103-maud aunt]737-her aunt , " before [I]103-maud came to understand how differently [I]103-maud had been brought up from [other children]4417-other children . Partly [I]103-maud began to see it at [the school where [we]4419-we first met]4418-the school where we first met ; but it only grew quite clear to [me]103-maud when [I]103-maud shared in the home life of [[my]103-maud pupils]3496-my pupils in [the country]3594-the country . [I]103-maud found [I]103-maud had an entirely different view of [the world]622-the world from what was usual . That which was [my]103-maud evil , [I]103-maud discovered to be often [others]256-others ' good ; and [my]103-maud good , [their]256-others abhorrence . [[My]103-maud aunt]4424-my aunt 's system was held to be utterly unchristian . Little things which [I]103-maud sometimes said , in perfect innocence , excited grave disapproval . All this frightened [me]103-maud , and made [me]103-maud even more reserved than [I]103-maud should have been naturally .[103-maud]

" In [my]103-maud letters to [you]4425-you [I]103-maud began to venture for the first time to speak of things which were making [my]103-maud life restless . [I]103-maud did little more than hint [my]103-maud opinions ; [I]103-maud wonder , in looking back , that [I]103-maud had the courage to do even that . But [I]103-maud already knew that [your]4425-you mind was broader and richer than [mine]103-maud , and [I]103-maud suppose [I]103-maud caught with a certain desperation at the chance of being understood . It was the first opportunity [I]103-maud had ever had of discussing intellectual things . With [[my]103-maud aunt]4424-my aunt [I]103-maud had never ventured to discuss anything ; [I]103-maud reverenced [her]4424-my aunt too much for that ; [she]4424-my aunt spoke , and [I]103-maud received all [she]4424-my aunt said . [I]103-maud thought that from [you]4425-you [I]103-maud should obtain confirmation where [I]103-maud needed it , but [your]4425-you influence was of the opposite kind . [Your]4425-you letters so abounded with suggestion that was quite new to [me]103-maud , referred so familiarly to beliefs and interests of which [I]103-maud was quite ignorant , showed such a boldness in judging all things , that [I]103-maud drifted further and further from certainty . The result of it all was that [I]103-maud fell ill .[103-maud]

" [You]4425-you see now what it is that has burdened [me]103-maud from the day when [I]103-maud first began to ask [myself]103-maud about [my]103-maud beliefs . [I]103-maud was taught to believe that [the world]622-the world was sin , and that the soul only freed itself from sin in proportion as it learned to live apart from and independently of [the world]622-the world . Everything was dark because of sin ; only in the still , secret places of the soul was the light of purity and salvation .[103-maud]

" [I]103-maud thought [I]103-maud had passed out of this . When [I]103-maud returned to [London]3-london , and began this new life , the burden seemed all at once lifted from [me]103-maud . [I]103-maud could look here and there with freedom ; the sky was bright above [me]103-maud ; human existence was cheerful and noble and justified in itself . [I]103-maud began to learn a thousand things . Above all , [my]103-maud mind fixed on Art ; in that [I]103-maud thought [I]103-maud had found a support that would never fail [me]103-maud .[103-maud]

" Oh , why could it not last ? The clouds began to darken over [me]103-maud again . [I]103-maud heard voices once which [I]103-maud had hoped were for ever silenced . That sense of sin and horror came upon [me]103-maud last night in [the streets]3169-the streets . [I]103-maud suffered dreadfully . "[103-maud]

[She]2332-you was silent , and , meeting [Waymark]130-waymark 's eyes so fixed on [her]2332-you own , became conscious of the eagerness and fervour with which [she]2332-you had spoken .

" Have [you]130-waymark any experience of such things ? "[2332-you] [she]2332-you asked nervously . " Did [you]130-waymark ever suffer in the same way ? "[2332-you]

" It is all very strange , "[130-waymark] [he]130-waymark said , without answering [her]2332-you question . " This overpowering consciousness of sin is an anachronism in [our]4430-our time . But , from the way in which [you]2332-you express [yourself]2332-you , [I]130-waymark should have thought [you]2332-you had been studying [Schopenhauer]227-schopenhauer . [I]130-waymark suppose [you]2332-you know nothing of [him]227-schopenhauer ? "[130-waymark]

" Nothing . "[130-waymark]

" Some of [your]2332-you phrases were precisely [his]227-schopenhauer . [Your]2332-you doctrine is simply Pessimism , with an element of dogmatic faith added . With [Schopenhauer]227-schopenhauer , the will to live is the root of sin ; mortify this , deny the first instincts of [your]2332-you being , and [you]2332-you approach righteousness . Buddhism has the same system . And , in deducing all this from the plain teachings of Christianity , [I]130-waymark am disposed to think [you]2332-you are right and consistent . Christianity is pessimism , so far as [this world]3446-this world is concerned ; [we]4432-we see that in such things as the thanksgiving for [a ' person]4433-a ' person 's death in the burial service , and the prayer that the end of [the world]622-the world may soon come . "[130-waymark]

[He]2333-he paused , and thought for a moment .

" But all this , "[2333-he] [he]2333-he resumed , rising from [his]2333-he seat , and going to stand with one arm upon the mantelpiece , " is of course , with [me]2333-he , mere matter of speculation . There are two allegories , which define Pessimism and Optimism . First that of [Adam]226-adam and [Christ]122-christ . [Adam]226-adam falls through eating of the tree of knowledge ; in other words , sin only comes with self - consciousness , sin is the conscious enjoyment of life . And , according to this creed , it can only be overcome by abnegation , by the denial of the will to live . Accordingly , [Christ]122-christ enters [the world]622-the world , and , representing Humanity , as [Adam]226-adam had done , saves [the world]622-the world by denial , of [Himself]226-adam , even to death . The other allegory is that of [Prometheus]228-prometheus . [He]228-prometheus also represents [mankind]3553-mankind , and [his]228-prometheus stealing of the fire means [man]1474-man 's acquirement of [a conscious soul]4439-a conscious soul , whereby [he]228-prometheus makes [himself]228-prometheus capable of sin . [The gods]3886-the gods put [him]228-prometheus in bondage and torment , representing the subjection to the flesh . But [Prometheus]228-prometheus is saved in a different way from [Adam]226-adam ; not by renunciation , but by the prowess of [Hercules]229-hercules , that is to say , the triumphant aspiration of [Humanity]230-humanity . [Man]118-julian triumphs by asserting [his]118-julian right to do so . Self - consciousness [he]118-julian claims as a good thing , and embraces [the world]622-the world as [his]118-julian birthright . Here , [you]4442-you see , there is no room for the crushing sense of sin . Sin , if anything , is weakness . Let [us]4443-us rejoice in [our]4443-us strength , whilst [we]4443-us have it . The end of course will come , but it is [a wise man]4444-a wise man 's part not to heed the inevitable . Let [us]4443-us live whilst it is called to - day ; [we]4443-us shall go to sleep with all the better conscience for having used the hours of daylight . "[2333-he]

[Maud]103-maud listened with head bent .

" [My]130-waymark own temperament , "[130-waymark] [Waymark]130-waymark went on , " is , [I]130-waymark suppose , exceptional , at all events among [men who have an inner life]4445-men who have an inner life . [I]130-waymark never knew what goes by the name of religious feeling ; impulses of devotion , in the common sense of the phrase , have always been strange to [me]130-waymark . [I]130-waymark have known fear at the prospect of death ; religious consolation , never . Sin , above all , has been a word without significance to [me]130-waymark . As [a boy]3219-a boy , it was so ; it is so still , now that [I]130-waymark am self - conscious . [I]130-waymark have never been [a deep student of philosophy]4447-a deep student of philosophy , but the doctrine of philosophical necessity , the idea of Fate , is with [me]130-waymark an instinct . [I]130-waymark know that [I]130-waymark could not have acted otherwise than [I]130-waymark did in any juncture of [my]130-waymark life ; [I]130-waymark know that the future is beyond [my]130-waymark control . [I]130-waymark shall do this , and avoid that , simply owing to a preponderance of motives , which [I]130-waymark can gauge , but not control . Certain things [I]130-waymark hate and shrink from ; but [I]130-waymark try to avoid , even in thought , such words as vice and crime ; [the murderer]4448-the murderer could not help [himself]4448-the murderer , and [the saint]4449-the saint has no merit in [his]4449-the saint sanctity . Does all this seem horrible to [you]2334-you ? "[130-waymark]

[Maud]103-maud raised [her]103-maud eyes , and looked steadily at [him]2334-you , but did not speak . It was the gaze of one who tries humbly to understand , and longs to sympathise . But there was a shadow of something like fear upon [her]103-maud face .

[Waymark]130-waymark spoke with more earnestness .

" [You]2334-you will not think [me]130-waymark incapable of what [we]4450-we call noble thought and feeling ? [I]130-waymark have in [me]130-waymark the elements of [an enthusiast]4451-an enthusiast ; they might have led [me]130-waymark to strange developments , but for that cold , critical spirit which makes [me]130-waymark so intensely self - conscious . This restless scepticism has often been to [me]130-waymark a torment in something the same way as that burden of which [you]2334-you speak . Often , often , [I]130-waymark would so gladly surrender [myself]130-waymark to [my]130-waymark instincts of passion and delight . [I]130-waymark may change ; [I]130-waymark may perhaps some day attain rest in an absolute ideal . If [I]130-waymark do , it will be through the help of [one who shall become to [me]130-waymark that ideal personified , who shall embody all the purer elements of [my]130-waymark nature , and speak to [me]130-waymark as with the voice of [my]130-waymark own soul]4452-one who shall become to me that ideal personified , who shall embody all the purer elements of my nature , and speak to me as with the voice of my own soul . "[130-waymark]

[She]2335-you hung upon [his]2336-i words , and an involuntary sigh , born of the intensity of the moment , trembled on [her]2335-you lips .

" [I]2336-i have spoken to [you]2335-you , "[2336-i] [he]2336-i said , after what seemed a long silence , " with a sincerity which was the due return for [your]2335-you own . [I]2336-i could have shown [myself]2336-i in a more pleasing light . [You]2335-you see how little able [I]2336-i am to help [you]2335-you ; the centre - thought of [your]2335-you being is wholly strange to [me]2336-i . And for all that may [I]2336-i speak [my]2336-i thought ? [we]4453-we are nearer to [each other]459-each other than before . "[2336-i]

" Yes , nearer , "[2335-you] [she]2335-you repeated , under [her]2335-you breath .

" [You]2336-i think that ? [You]2336-i feel that ? [I]2336-i have not repelled [you]2336-i ? "[2336-i]

" [You]2336-i have not "[2336-i]

" And if [I]2336-i stood before [you]2335-you , now , as [you]2335-you know [me]2336-i egotistic , sceptical , calm and told [you]2335-you that [you]2335-you are [the only being in whom [I]2336-i have ever felt complete confidence , whose word and thought [I]2336-i felt to be one]4455-the only being in whom i have ever felt complete confidence , whose word and thought i felt to be one ; that [you]2335-you exercise more power over [me]2336-i than any other ever did or shall ; that life in [your]2335-you companionship might gain the unity [I]2336-i long for ; that in [your]2335-you presence [I]2336-i feel [myself]2336-i face to face with a higher and nobler nature than [my]2336-i own , one capable of sustaining [me]2336-i in effort and leading [me]2336-i to great results "[2336-i]

[He]2337-he became silent , for [her]2338-her face had turned deadly pale . But this passed , and in [her]2338-her eyes , as they met [his]2337-he , trouble grew to a calm joy . Without speaking , [she]2338-her held [her]2338-her hand to [him]2337-he .

" [You]2335-you are not afraid , "[130-waymark] [Waymark]130-waymark said , " to link [your]2335-you fate with [mine]130-waymark ? [My]130-waymark life is made up of uncertainties . [I]130-waymark have no position ; it may be a long time before [I]130-waymark can see even the promise of success in [my]130-waymark work . [I]130-waymark have chosen that work , however , and by it [I]130-waymark stand or fall . Have [you]2335-you sufficient faith in [me]130-waymark to wait with confidence ? "[130-waymark]

" [I]2338-her have absolute faith in [you]2335-you . [I]2338-her ask no greater happiness than to have a share in [your]2335-you aims . It will give [me]2338-her the strength [I]2338-her need , and make [my]2338-her life full of hope . "[2338-her]

It had come then , and just as [he]2337-he had foreseen it would . It was no result of deliberate decision , [he]2337-he had given up the effort to discover [his]2337-he true path , knowing sufficiently that neither reason nor true preponderance of inclination was likely to turn the balance . The gathering emotion of the hour had united with opportunity to decide [his]2337-he future . The decision was a relief ; as [he]2337-he walked homewards , [he]2337-he was lighthearted .

On the way , [he]2337-he thought over everything once more , reviewing former doubts from [his]2337-he present position . On the whole , [he]2337-he felt that fate had worked for [his]2337-he happiness .

And yet there was discontent . [He]2337-he had never known , felt that perhaps [he]2337-he might never know , that sustained energy of imaginative and sensual longing which ideal passion demands . The respectable make - believe which takes the form of domestic sentiment , that everyday love , which , become [the servant of habit]2339-the servant of habit , suffices to cement [the ordinary household]2340-the ordinary household , is not the state in which [such men]2341-such men as [Waymark]130-waymark seek or find repose ; the very possibility of falling into it unawares is a dread to [them]2341-such men . If [he]2337-he could but feel at all times as [he]2337-he had felt at moments in [Maud]103-maud 's presence . It might be that the growth of intimacy , of mutual knowledge , would make [his]2337-he love for [her]103-maud a more real motive in [his]2337-he life . [He]2337-he would endeavour that it should be so . Yet there remained that fatal conviction of the unreality of every self - persuasion save in relation to the influences of the moment . To love was easy , inevitable ; to concentrate love finally on one object might well prove , in [his]2337-he case , an impossibility . Clear enough to [him]2337-he already was the likelihood of a strong revulsion of feeling when [Ida]101-ida once more came back , and the old life if it could be was resumed . [Compassion]231-compassion would speak so loudly for [her]103-maud ; [her]103-maud face , pale and illuminated with sorrow , would throw a stronger spell than ever upon [his]2337-he senses . Well , there was no help . Whatever would be , would be . [It]2342-it availed nothing to foresee and scheme and resolve .

And , in the same hour , [Maud]103-maud was upon [her]103-maud knees , in the silence of [[her]103-maud own chamber]2343-her own chamber , shedding tears which were at once both sweet and bitter , in [her]103-maud heart a tumult of emotion , joy and thanksgiving at strife with those dark powers which shadowed [her]103-maud existence . [She]103-maud had do doubts of the completeness and persistency of [her]103-maud love . But was not this love a sin , and its very strength the testimony of [her]103-maud soul 's loss ?

CHAPTER XXVIII

SLIMY 'S DAY

[Waymark]130-waymark had written to [Ida]101-ida just after [her]101-ida imprisonment began , a few words of such comfort as [he]130-waymark could send . No answer came ; perhaps the prison rules prevented it . When the term was drawing to a close , [he]130-waymark wrote again , to let [her]101-ida know that [he]130-waymark would meet [her]101-ida on the morning of [her]101-ida release .

It would be on a Tuesday morning . As the time drew near , [Waymark]130-waymark did [his]130-waymark best to think of the matter quietly . [The girl]316-the girl had [no one else]4236-no one else to help [her]316-the girl ; it would have been brutality to withdraw and leave [her]316-the girl to [her]316-the girl fate , merely because [he]130-waymark just a little feared the effect upon [himself]130-waymark of such a meeting . And the feeling on [her]101-ida side ? Well , that [he]130-waymark could not pretend to be ignorant of , and , in spite of everything , there was still the same half - acknowledged pleasure in the thought . [He]130-waymark tried to persuade [himself]130-waymark that [he]130-waymark should have the moral courage to let [her]101-ida as soon as possible understand [his]130-waymark new position ; [he]130-waymark also tried to believe that this would not involve any serious shock to [Ida]101-ida . For all that , [he]130-waymark knew only too well that [man]1474-man is " ein erbarmlicher Schuft , "[1474-man] and there was always the possibility that [he]130-waymark might say nothing of what had happened , and let things take their course .

On the Monday [he]130-waymark was already looking forward to the meeting with restlessness . Could [he]130-waymark have foreseen that anything would occur to prevent [his]130-waymark keeping [his]130-waymark promise , it would have caused [him]130-waymark extreme anxiety . But such a possibility never entered [his]130-waymark thoughts , and , shortly before mid - day , [he]130-waymark went down to collect [his]130-waymark rents as usual .

The effect of a hard winter was seen in the decrease of [the collector]2347-the collector 's weekly receipts . The misery of cold and starvation was growing familiar to [Waymark]130-waymark 's eyes , and scarcely excited the same feelings as formerly ; yet there were some cases in which [he]130-waymark had not the heart to press for the payment of rent , and [his]130-waymark representations to [Mr. Woodstock]114-mr. woodstock on behalf of [the poor creatures]2348-the poor creatures were more frequently successful than in former times . Still , in the absence of then but eviction , and [Waymark]130-waymark more than once knew what ideal philanthropy , there was nothing for it every now and it was to be cursed to [his]130-waymark face by [suffering wretches whom despair made incapable of discrimination]2349-suffering wretches whom despair made incapable of discrimination . " Where are [we]2353-one family of seven to go ? "[2349-suffering wretches whom despair made incapable of discrimination] was the oft - repeated question , and the only reply was a shrug of the shoulders ; impossible to express [oneself]2350-oneself otherwise . [They]2348-the poor creatures clung desperately to habitations so vile that [brutes]3386-brutes would have forsaken [them]2348-the poor creatures for cleaner and warmer retreats in [archway]2352-archway and by roadside . [One family of seven]2353-one family of seven , [a man]1260-a man and [wife both ill with five children]2355-wife both ill with five children , could not be got out , even when [a man]1260-a man had been sent by [Mr. Woodstock]114-mr. woodstock to remove the window - frames and take the door away , furniture having already been seized ; only by force at length were [they]2348-the poor creatures thrown into [the street]340-the street , to find [their]2348-the poor creatures way to perdition as best [they]2348-the poor creatures might . [Waymark]130-waymark did not relish all this ; it cost [him]130-waymark a dark hour now and then . But it was rich material ; every item was stored up for future use .

Among others , [the man named [Slimy]156-slimy]2358-the man named slimy just managed to hold [his]156-slimy footing . Times were hard with [Slimy]156-slimy , that was clear ; still , [he]156-slimy somehow contrived to keep no more than a fortnight behind with [his]156-slimy rent . [Waymark]130-waymark was studying [this creature]2359-this creature , and found in [him]156-slimy the strangest matter for observation ; in [Slimy]156-slimy there were depths beyond [Caliban]232-caliban , and , at the same time , curious points of contact with [average humanity]2360-average humanity , unexpectedly occurring . [He]156-slimy was not ungrateful for [the collector]2347-the collector 's frequent forbearance , and , when able to speak coherently , tried at times to show this . [Waymark]130-waymark had got into the habit of sitting with [him]156-slimy in [[his]156-slimy room]979-his room for a little time , whenever [he]130-waymark found [him]156-slimy at [home]3157-home . Of late , [Slimy]156-slimy had seemed not quite in [his]156-slimy usual health ; this exhibited itself much as it would in some repulsive animal , which suffers in captivity , and tries to find a remote corner when pains come on . At times [Waymark]130-waymark experienced a certain fear in [the man]491-the man 's presence ; if ever [he]130-waymark met the dull glare of that one bleared blood - shot eye , a chill ran through [him]130-waymark for a moment , and [he]130-waymark drew back a little . Personal uncleanliness made [Slimy]156-slimy 's proximity at all times unpleasant ; and occasionally [his]156-slimy gaunt , grimed face grew to an expression suggestive of disagreeable possibilities .

On the present day , [Waymark]130-waymark was told by [a woman who lived on the ground - floor]2365-a woman who lived on the ground - floor that [Slimy]156-slimy had gone out , but had left word with [her]2365-a woman who lived on the ground - floor , in case [the collector]2347-the collector called , that [he]156-slimy should be back in less than half - an - hour . Doubtless this meant that the rent was not forthcoming . [The people who lived on the first floor]2367-the people who lived on the first floor were out as usual , but had left [their]2367-the people who lived on the first floor rent . Of [the two rooms at the top]2368-the two rooms at the top , one was just now vacant . [Waymark]130-waymark went on to [the two or three houses that remained]2369-the two or three houses that remained . On turning back , [he]130-waymark met [Slimy]156-slimy at the door ; [the man]491-the man nodded in [his]491-the man wonted way , grinning like a grisly phantom , and beckoned [Waymark]130-waymark to follow [him]491-the man [upstairs]434-upstairs . [The woman below]2372-the woman below had closed [her]2372-the woman below door again , and in all probability [no one]3702-no one observed [the two entering together]2374-the two entering together .

[Waymark]130-waymark sat down amid the collection of nondescript articles which always filled [the room]255-the room , and waited for [the tenant]2376-the tenant to produce [his]491-the man rent . [Slimy]156-slimy seemed to have other things in mind . After closing the door , [he]156-slimy too had taken a seat , upon a heap of filthy sacking , and was running [his]156-slimy fingers through the shock of black hair which made [his]156-slimy beard . [Waymark]130-waymark examined [him]156-slimy . There was no sign of intoxication , but something was evidently working in [the man]491-the man 's mind , and [his]491-the man breath came quickly , with a kind of asthmatic pant , from between [his]491-the man thin lips , still parted in the uncanny grin .

" [Mr. Waymark]130-waymark , "[491-the man] [he]491-the man began at length .

" Well ? "[491-the man]

" [I]491-the man ai n't got no rent . "[491-the man]

" That 's bad . [You]130-waymark 're two weeks behind , [you]130-waymark know . "[491-the man]

" [Mr. Waymark]130-waymark . "[491-the man]

The single eye fixed itself on [Waymark]130-waymark 's face in a way which made [the latter]425-the latter feel uncomfortable .

" Well ? "[491-the man]

" [I]491-the man ai n't a - gem ' to pay [you]130-waymark no more rent , nor yet [no one else]4236-no one else , maybe . "[491-the man]

" How 's that ? "[491-the man]

" 'Cos [I]491-the man ai n't , and 'cos [I]491-the man 'm tired o ' payin ' rent . "[491-the man]

" [I]130-waymark 'm afraid [you]130-waymark 'll find it difficult to get on without , though , "[130-waymark] said [Waymark]130-waymark , trying to get into the jocular tone [he]130-waymark sometimes adopted with [Slimy]156-slimy , but scarcely succeeding .

" [Mr. Waymark]130-waymark . "[491-the man]

There was clearly something wrong . [Waymark]130-waymark rose to [his]130-waymark feet . [Slimy]156-slimy rose also , and at the same time took up a heavy piece of wood , looking like a piece of a cart - shaft , which had lain on the floor beside [him]156-slimy . [His]156-slimy exclamation elicited no answer , and [he]156-slimy spoke again , hoarsely as always , but with a calmness which contrasted strangely with the words [he]156-slimy uttered .

" Do [you]130-waymark believe in the devil and hell ? "[156-slimy]

" Why ? "[130-waymark] returned [Waymark]130-waymark , trying hard to command [himself]130-waymark , and to face down [the man as a wild beast has been known to be out - gazed]2379-the man as a wild beast has been known to be out - gazed .

" 'Cos , by [the devil]3448-the devil [himself]3448-the devil , as 'll have [me]130-waymark before many weeks is over , and by the fires of hell , as 'll burn [me]130-waymark , if [you]130-waymark stir a step , or speak a word above [your]130-waymark breath , [I]130-waymark 'll bring [you]130-waymark down just like [they]4458-they do the bullocks . [Y]130-waymark ' understand ! "[130-waymark]

[Waymark]130-waymark saw that the threat was [no idle one]2380-no idle one . [He]130-waymark could scarcely have spoken , had [he]130-waymark wished . [Slimy]156-slimy grinned at the effect [he]130-waymark had produced , and continued in the same matter - of - fact way .

" It takes [you]130-waymark back a bit , do n't it ! Never mind ; [you]130-waymark 'll get over it . [I]156-slimy do n't mean [you]130-waymark no ' arm , [Mr. Waymark]130-waymark , but [I]156-slimy 'll have to put [you]130-waymark to a little ill - convenience , that 's all . See now ; here 's a bit o ' stout rope . With this ' ere , [I]156-slimy 'm a - goin' jist to tie [you]130-waymark up , ' and an ' foot , [you]130-waymark see . As [I]156-slimy said before , if [you]130-waymark give [me]156-slimy any trouble , well , [I]156-slimy 'll ' ave to knock the senses out o ' [you]130-waymark fust , that 's all . "[156-slimy]

Vain to think of grappling with [the man]491-the man , whose strength [Waymark]130-waymark knew to be extraordinary . For a moment , the shock of alarm had deprived [him]130-waymark of thought and power of movement ; but this passed , and [he]130-waymark was able to consider [his]130-waymark position . [He]130-waymark looked keenly into [Slimy]156-slimy 's face . Had [the man]491-the man gone mad ! [His]491-the man manner was scarcely consistent with that supposition . As the alternative before [him]130-waymark was of such a kind , [Waymark]130-waymark could but choose the lesser evil . [He]130-waymark allowed [Slimy]156-slimy to remove from [his]130-waymark shoulders the satchel which contained the sums of money [he]130-waymark had just collected . It was quietly put aside .

" Now , "[156-slimy] said [Slimy]156-slimy , with the same deliberation , " [I]156-slimy have to arst [you]130-waymark just to lay down on the floor , just ' ere , see . It 's better to lay down quiet than to be knocked down , [you]130-waymark see . "[156-slimy]

[Waymark]130-waymark mentally agreed that it was . [His]130-waymark behaviour might seem cowardly , but to say nothing of the loathsomeness of a wrestle with [Slimy]156-slimy [he]130-waymark knew very well that any struggle , or a shout for help , would mean [his]130-waymark death . [He]130-waymark hesitated , felt ashamed , but looked at [Slimy]156-slimy 's red eye , and lay down . In taking the position indicated , [he]130-waymark noticed that three very large iron hooks had been driven firmly into the floor , in a triangular shape . Just beside the lower one of these [his]130-waymark feet had to rest ; [his]130-waymark head lay between the other two . [Slimy]156-slimy now proceeded to bind [[his]156-slimy captive]2383-his captive 's feet together with strong cord , and then attach them firmly to the hook ; then bidding [him]130-waymark sit up for a moment , [he]156-slimy made [his]156-slimy hands fast behind [his]156-slimy back ; lastly , [Waymark]130-waymark being again recumbent , a rope was passed once round [his]130-waymark neck , and each end of it firmly fastened to one of the remaining hooks . This was not a pleasant moment , but , the operation completed , [Waymark]130-waymark found that , though [he]130-waymark could not move [his]130-waymark head an inch , there was no danger of strangulation as long as [he]130-waymark remained quiet . In short , [he]130-waymark was bound as effectually as [a man]1260-a man could be , yet without much pain . The only question was , how long [he]130-waymark would have to remain thus .

[Slimy]156-slimy examined [his]156-slimy work , and nodded with satisfaction . Then [he]130-waymark took up the satchel again , opened it , and for a few moments kept diving [his]130-waymark long black fingers into the coins , whilst [his]130-waymark face was transformed to an expression of grim joy . Presently , having satisfied [himself]130-waymark with the feel of the money , [he]130-waymark transferred it all to a pocket inside [his]130-waymark ragged coat .

" Now , [Mr. Waymark]130-waymark , "[130-waymark] [he]130-waymark recommenced , seating [himself]130-waymark on the chair [Waymark]130-waymark had previously occupied , " [I]130-waymark ai n't quite done with ill - conveniencin ' [you]130-waymark . [I]130-waymark 'm sorry to say [I]130-waymark 'll ' ave jist to put a bit of a gag on , to prevent [you]130-waymark from ' ollerin ' out too soon ; but before [I]130-waymark do that , [I]130-waymark 've jist got a word or two to say . Let 's spend [our]2386-our last time together in a friendly way . "[130-waymark]

In spite of [his]130-waymark alarm , [Waymark]130-waymark observed with astonishment the change which had come over [the man]491-the man 's mode of speech . In all [their]2386-our previous intercourse , [Slimy]156-slimy had shown [himself]156-slimy barely articulate ; for the most part it was difficult to collect meaning from [his]156-slimy grunts and snarls . [His]156-slimy voice was still dreadfully husky , and indeed seemed unused to the task of uttering so many words , but for all that [he]156-slimy spoke without hesitation , and with a reserve of force which made [his]156-slimy utterances all the more impressive . Having bespoken [[his]156-slimy hearer]2387-his hearer 's attention in this deliberate way , [he]156-slimy became silent , and for a while sat brooding , [his]156-slimy fingers still busy among the coins in [his]156-slimy pocket .

" [I]156-slimy do n't rightly know how old [I]156-slimy may be , "[156-slimy] [he]156-slimy began at length , " but it 's most like about fifty ; [we]2386-our 'll say fifty . For fifty years [I]156-slimy 've lived in [this world]3446-this world , and in all that time [I]156-slimy ca n't remember not one single ' appy day , not one . [I]156-slimy never knowed neither [father]902-father nor [mother]375-mother ; [I]156-slimy never knowed not a soul as belonged to [me]156-slimy . [Friends]562-friends [I]156-slimy ' ave had ; four of ['em]4463-'em ; and [their]562-friends names was Brandy , Whisky , Rum , an ' Gin . But [they]562-friends 've cost [me]156-slimy a good deal , an ' somehow [they]562-friends ai n't quite what [they]562-friends used to be . [They]562-friends used to make [me]156-slimy merry for a while , now and then ; but [they]562-friends 've taken now to burnin ' up [my]156-slimy inside , an ' filling [my]156-slimy ' ead with devils ; an ' [I]156-slimy 'm gettin ' afeard of 'em , an ' [they]562-friends 'll ' ave to see [me]156-slimy through to the end .[156-slimy]

" Fifty year , "[2388-i] [he]2388-i resumed , after another interval of brooding , " an ' not one ' appy day . [I]2388-i was a - thinkin ' of it over to [myself]2388-i , and , says [I]2388-i , ' What 's the reason on it ? ' The reason is , 'cos [I]2388-i ai n't never ' ad money . Money means ' appiness , an ' [them]562-friends as never ' as money , 'll never be ' appy , live as long as [they]562-friends may . Well , [I]2388-i went on a - sayin ' to [myself]2388-i , ' Ai n't [I]2388-i to ' ave not one ' appy day in all [my]2388-i life ? ' An ' it come to [me]2388-i all at once , with a flash like , that money was to be ' ad for the trouble o ' takin ' it money an ' ' appiness . "[2388-i]

The bleared eye rolled with a sort of self - congratulation , and the coins jingled more loudly .

" A pound ai n't no use ; nor yet two pound ; nor yet five pound . An ' five pound 's what [I]2388-i never ' ad in fifty year .
