" Very well , "[101-ida] [Ida]101-ida broke in hastily . " [I]101-ida 'll see if [I]101-ida can do anything . "[101-ida]

Paying no attention to the blessings showered upon [her]101-ida by [the counsel in this case]3125-the counsel in this case , blessings to which [she]101-ida was accustomed , and of which [she]101-ida well understood the value , [Ida]101-ida went out into [the Lane]1392-the lane , and walked away quickly . [She]101-ida did not pause at [the Clock House]3127-the clock house , but walked as far as [a quiet street]3128-a quiet street some little distance off , and then paced [the pavement]1274-the pavement for a while , in thought . Who this " [Mrs. Casty]250-mrs. casty "[101-ida] was [she]101-ida could have little doubt . The calumnies against [[her]101-ida husband]584-her husband were just such as [Harriet Casti]216-harriet would be likely to circulate .

For a moment it had seemed possible to go to [the public - house]3131-the public - house and make personal inquiries , but reflection showed [her]101-ida that this would be a needless imprudence , even had [she]101-ida been able to overcome [herself]101-ida sufficiently for such an interview . [She]101-ida went [home]3157-home instead , and at once despatched [Miss Hurst]238-miss hurst to [the Clock House]96-the clock house to discover whether it was indeed [Harriet Casti]216-harriet who lay there , and , if so , what [her]216-harriet real condition was . [That lady]305-that lady returned with evidence establishing [the sick woman]455-the sick woman 's identity . [Harriet]216-harriet , [she]305-that lady reported , was indeed in a sad state , clearly incapable of supporting [herself]216-harriet by any kind of work . [[Her]101-ida husband]584-her husband [Miss Hurst]238-miss hurst was told had deserted [her]101-ida , leaving [her]101-ida entirely without means , and now , but for [Mrs. Sprowl]153-mrs. sprowl 's charity , [she]101-ida would have been in [the workhouse]3951-the workhouse . This story sounded very strangely to [Ida]101-ida . It might mean that [Julian]118-julian was dead . [She]101-ida wrote a few lines to [Waymark]130-waymark , at [the old address]3137-the old address , and had a speedy reply . Yes , [Julian Casti]118-julian was dead , but the grave had not yet closed over [him]118-julian . [Harriet]216-harriet had been in receipt of money , and need have wanted for nothing ; but now [she]216-harriet must expect no more .

The result of it all was that , in the course of a week , [Harriet]216-harriet was informed by [Miss Hurst]238-miss hurst that a place was open to [her]216-harriet in [a hospital near [London]3-london]3138-a hospital near london , where [she]216-harriet could remain as long as [her]216-harriet ailments rendered it necessary ; the expense would be provided for by [a lady who had been told of the case]3139-a lady who had been told of the case , and wished to give what aid [she]3139-a lady who had been told of the case could . The offer was rejected , and with insult . When next [she]101-ida visited [Litany Lane]45-litany lane , [Ida]101-ida learnt that " pore [Mrs. Casty]250-mrs. casty , "[153-mrs. sprowl] after a quarrel with [[her]101-ida friend]669-her friend [Mrs. Sprowl]153-mrs. sprowl , had fallen [downstairs]445-downstairs in a fit and broken [her]101-ida neck .

[Waymark]130-waymark lived on in [the Isle of Wight]3142-the isle of wight , until a day when there came to [him]130-waymark a letter from [Miss Bygrave]121-miss bygrave . [It]3143-it told [him]130-waymark that [Maud]103-maud 's resolve was immutable , and added that [aunt]3318-aunt and [niece]3145-niece , having become members of " [the true Church]4827-the true church , "[3143-it] were about to join [a sisterhood in [a midland town]3147-a midland town , where [their]3148-their lives would be devoted to work of charity]3146-a sisterhood in a midland town , where their lives would be devoted to work of charity .

Not many days after this , [Ida]101-ida , in [London]3-london , received a letter , addressed in a hand [she]101-ida knew well . There was a flush on [her]101-ida face as [she]101-ida began to read ; but presently came the pallor of a sudden joy almost too great to be borne . The letter was a long one , containing the story of several years of [the writer]833-the writer 's life , related with unflinching sincerity , bad and good impartially set down , and all leading up to words which danced in golden sunlight before [her]101-ida tear - dimmed eyes .

For an hour [she]101-ida sat alone , scarce moving . Yet it seemed to [her]101-ida that only a few minutes were allowed to pass before [she]101-ida took [her]101-ida pen and wrote .
